59527_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	In the ordinary course of our business, we face various strategic, operating, compliance and financial risks.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	These risks could have a material impact on our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Our Enterprise Risk Management ("ERM") process seeks to identify and address significant risks.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Our ERM process is a company-wide initiative that is designed with the intent of prioritizing risks and assigning appropriate consideration for such risks.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	We use the integrated risk framework of the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations to assess, manage and monitor risks.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Management has identified and prioritized critical risks based on the severity and likelihood of each risk and assigned an executive to address each major identified risk area and lead action plans to monitor and mitigate risks, where possible.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Our Board of Directors provides oversight of the ERM process and systematically reviews identified critical risks.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P6_S2	The Audit Committee also reviews major financial risk exposures and the steps management has taken to monitor and control them.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our goal is to proactively manage risks in a structured approach and in conjunction with strategic planning, with the intent to preserve and enhance shareholder value.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	However, these and other risks and uncertainties could cause our results to vary materially from recent results or from our anticipated future results.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The risk factors and uncertainties described below together with information incorporated by reference or otherwise included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K should be carefully considered.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties of which we are currently unaware or that we currently believe to be immaterial may also adversely affect our business.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	General economic and market conditions may adversely affect the Company's financial condition, results of operations and access to capital markets.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The Company's operating results are sensitive to changes in general economic conditions.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Recessionary economic cycles, higher interest rates, inflation, trade barriers in the world markets and changes in tax laws or other economic factors affecting the countries and industries in which we do business could adversely affect demand for the Company's products, thereby impacting our results of operations, financial condition and access to capital markets.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Availability of and volatility in energy costs or raw material prices may adversely affect our performance.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	In the normal course of business, we are exposed to market risks related to the availability of and price fluctuations in the purchase of energy and commodities used in the manufacture of our products (primarily steel, brass, copper, silver, aluminum alloys, electronic components, electricity and natural gas).
59527_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	The availability and prices for raw materials are subject to volatility and are influenced by worldwide economic conditions, speculative action, world supply and demand balances, inventory levels, availability of substitute materials, currency exchange rates, our competitors' production costs, anticipated or perceived shortages and other factors.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	shortages due to global economic factors.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P13_S1	We have also experienced substantial volatility in prices for other raw materials, including metals, chemicals and energy costs.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Increases in the cost of raw materials and components may adversely affect our profitability if we are unable to pass along to our customers these cost increases in the form of price increases or otherwise reduce our cost of goods sold.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Although most of the raw materials and components used in our products are commercially available from a number of sources and in adequate supply, any disruption in the availability of such raw materials and components, our inability to timely or otherwise obtain substitutes for such items, or any deterioration in our relationships with or the financial viability of our suppliers could adversely affect our business.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We are a co-defendant in litigation alleging manganese induced illness and litigation alleging asbestos induced illness.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P15_S1	Liabilities relating to such litigation could reduce our profitability and impair our financial condition.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	At December 31, 2010, we were a co-defendant in cases alleging manganese induced illness involving claims by approximately 1,975 plaintiffs and a co-defendant in cases alleging asbestos induced illness involving claims by approximately 16,865 plaintiffs.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	In each instance, we are one of a large number of defendants.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	In the manganese cases, the claimants allege that exposure to manganese contained in welding consumables caused the plaintiffs to develop adverse neurological conditions, including a condition known as manganism.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	In the asbestos cases, the claimants allege that exposure to asbestos contained in welding consumables caused the plaintiffs to develop adverse pulmonary diseases, including mesothelioma and other lung cancers.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Since January 1, 1995, we have been a co-defendant in manganese cases that have been resolved as follows: 14,859 of those claims were dismissed, 23 were tried to defense verdicts in favor of us and five were tried to plaintiff verdicts (three of which were reversed on appeal and one of which has post-trial motions pending).
59527_11_ITEM1A_P18_S1	In addition, 13 claims were resolved by agreement for immaterial amounts and one claim was decided in favor of the Company following a summary judgment motion.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Since January 1, 1995, we have been a co-defendant in asbestos cases that have been resolved as follows: 38,968 of those claims were dismissed, 17 were tried to defense verdicts, seven were tried to plaintiff verdicts (two of which are being appealed), one was resolved by agreement for an immaterial amount and 573 were decided in favor of the Company following summary judgment motions.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	The long-term impact of the manganese and asbestos loss contingencies, in each case in the aggregate, on operating results, operating cash flows and access to capital markets is difficult to assess, particularly since claims are in many different stages of development and we benefit significantly from cost-sharing with co-defendants and insurance carriers.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	While we intend to contest these lawsuits vigorously, and believe we have applicable insurance relating to these claims, there are several risks and uncertainties that may affect our liability for personal claims relating to exposure to manganese and asbestos, including the future impact of changing cost sharing arrangements or a change in our overall trial experience.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Manganese is an essential element of steel and cannot be eliminated from welding consumables.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Asbestos use in welding consumables in the U.S. ceased in 1981.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We may incur material losses and costs as a result of product liability claims that may be brought against us.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Our business exposes us to potential product liability risks that are inherent in the design, manufacture, sale and application of our products and the products of third-party suppliers that we utilize or resell.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	pipelines and platforms, buildings, bridges and power generation facilities, the manufacture of transportation and heavy equipment and machinery, and various other construction projects.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P24_S1	We face risk of exposure to product liability claims in the event that accidents or failures on these projects result, or are alleged to result, in bodily injury or property damage.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P24_S2	Further, our products are designed for use in specific applications, and if a product is used inappropriately, personal injury or property damage may result.

59527_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	The cyclicality and maturity of the arc welding and cutting industry in developed markets may adversely affect our performance.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	The arc welding and cutting industry is generally a mature industry in developed markets such as North America and Western Europe and is very cyclical in nature.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Overall demand for arc welding and cutting products is largely determined by the level of capital spending in manufacturing and other industrial sectors, and the welding industry has historically experienced contraction during periods of slowing industrial activity.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P27_S2	If economic, business and industry conditions deteriorate, capital spending in those sectors may be substantially decreased, which could reduce demand for our products, our revenues and our results of operations.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We may not be able to complete our acquisition strategy or successfully integrate acquired businesses.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Part of our business strategy is to pursue targeted business acquisition opportunities, including foreign investment opportunities.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P29_S1	For example, we have completed and continue to pursue acquisitions in emerging markets including, but not limited to Brazil, Russia, India and China in order to strategically position resources to increase our presence in growing markets.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P29_S2	We cannot be certain that we will be successful in pursuing potential acquisition candidates or that the consequences of any acquisition would be beneficial to us.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P29_S3	Future acquisitions may expose us to unexpected liabilities and involve the expenditure of significant funds and management time.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P29_S4	Further, we may not be able to successfully integrate any acquired business with our existing businesses or recognize the expected benefits from any completed acquisition.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Depending on the nature, size and timing of future acquisitions, we may be required to raise additional financing, which may not be available to us on acceptable terms.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P30_S1	Our current operational cash flow is sufficient to fund our current acquisition plans, but a significant acquisition could require access to the capital markets.

59527_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	We conduct our sales and distribution operations on a worldwide basis and maintain manufacturing facilities in a number of foreign countries, which subjects us to risks associated with doing business outside the United States.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Our long-term strategy is to continue to increase our market share in growing international markets, particularly Asia (with emphasis in China and India), Latin America, Eastern Europe, Russia and other developing markets.

59527_11_ITEM1A_P61_S0	There is a growing political and scientific belief that emissions of greenhouse gases ("GHG") alter the composition of the global atmosphere in ways that are affecting the global climate.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P61_S1	Various stakeholders, including legislators and regulators, shareholders and non-governmental organizations, as well as companies in many business sectors, are considering ways to reduce GHG emissions.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P61_S2	These concerns may lead to international, national, regional or local legislative or regulatory responses in the near future.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P61_S3	Such regulation could result in new or additional regulatory or product standard requirements for the Company's global businesses.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P61_S4	We are unable, at this time, to predict the significance of these requirements as the impact of any future GHG legislative, regulatory or product standards is dependent on the timing and design of the mandates or standards.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P62_S0	Furthermore, the potential physical impacts of theorized climate change on the Company's customers, and therefore on the Company's operations, are speculative and highly uncertain, and would be particular to the circumstances developing in various geographical regions.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P62_S1	These may include changes in weather patterns (including drought and rainfall levels), water availability, storm patterns and intensities, and temperature levels.
59527_11_ITEM1A_P62_S2	These potential physical effects may adversely impact the cost, production, sales and financial performance of the Company's operations which we are unable, at this time, to predict.

59527_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company is the world's largest designer and manufacturer of arc welding and cutting products, manufacturing a broad line of arc welding equipment, consumable welding products and other welding and cutting products.
59527_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company is one of only a few worldwide broad-line manufacturers of welding and cutting products.
59527_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	Welding products include arc welding power sources, wire feeding systems, robotic welding packages, fume extraction equipment, consumable electrodes and fluxes.
59527_11_ITEM7_P2_S2	The Company's product offering also includes regulators and torches used in oxy-fuel welding and cutting.
59527_11_ITEM7_P2_S3	In addition, the Company has a leading global position in the brazing and soldering alloys market.
59527_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Company invests in the research and development of arc welding products in order to continue its market leading product offering.
59527_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	The Company continues to invest in technologies that improve the quality and productivity of welding products.
59527_11_ITEM7_P3_S2	In addition, the Company continues to actively increase its patent application process in order to secure its technology advantage in the United States and other major international jurisdictions.
59527_11_ITEM7_P3_S3	The Company believes its significant investment in research and development and its highly trained technical sales force coupled with its extensive distributor network provide a competitive advantage in the marketplace.
59527_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	The Company's products are sold in both domestic and international markets.
59527_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	In North America, products are sold principally through industrial distributors, retailers and also directly to users of welding products.
59527_11_ITEM7_P4_S2	Outside of North America, the Company has an international sales organization comprised of Company employees and agents who sell products from the Company's various manufacturing sites to distributors and product users.
59527_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	The Company's major end-user markets include:
59527_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	general metal fabrication, power generation and process industry, structural steel construction (buildings and bridges), heavy equipment fabrication (farming, mining and rail), shipbuilding, automotive, pipe mills and pipelines, and offshore oil and gas exploration and extraction.
59527_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Company has, through wholly-owned subsidiaries or joint ventures, manufacturing facilities located in the United States, Australia, Brazil, Canada, China, Colombia, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Mexico, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Russia,Turkey, United Kingdom and Venezuela.
59527_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	The Company has aligned its business units into five operating segments to enhance the utilization of the Company's worldwide resources and global sourcing initiatives.
59527_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	The operating segments consist of North America Welding, Europe Welding, Asia Pacific Welding, South America Welding and The Harris Products Group.
59527_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	The North America Welding segment includes welding operations in the United States, Canada and Mexico.
59527_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	The other three welding segments include welding operations in Europe, Asia Pacific and South America, respectively.
59527_11_ITEM7_P9_S2	The fifth segment, The Harris Products Group, includes the Company's global cutting, soldering and brazing businesses as well as the retail business in the United States.

59527_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	The principal raw materials essential to the Company's business are steel, electronic components, engines, brass, copper, silver, aluminum alloys and various chemicals, all of which are normally available for purchase in the open market.
59527_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	The Company's facilities are subject to environmental regulations.
59527_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	To date, compliance with these environmental regulations has not had a material adverse effect on the Company's earnings.

59527_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	In addition, the Company is ISO 14001 certified at most significant manufacturing facilities in North America and Europe and is working to gain certification at its remaining facilities worldwide.

59527_11_ITEM7_P13_S1	Key industries which provide a relative indication of demand drivers to the Company include steel, farm machinery and equipment, construction and transportation, fabricated metals, electrical equipment, ship and boat building, defense, truck manufacturing, energy and railroad equipment.
59527_11_ITEM7_P13_S2	Although these measures provide key information on trends relevant to the Company, the Company does not have available a more direct correlation of leading indicators which can provide a forward-looking view of demand levels in the markets which ultimately use the Company's welding products.

59527_11_ITEM7_P62_S3	Where possible, the Company utilizes operational cash flows and raises capital in the most efficient market, usually the U.S., and then lends funds to the specific subsidiary that requires funding.

59527_11_ITEM7_P122_S0	The Company's consolidated financial statements are based on the selection and application of significant accounting policies, which require management to make estimates and assumptions.
59527_11_ITEM7_P122_S1	These estimates and assumptions are reviewed periodically by management and compared to historical trends to determine the accuracy of estimates and assumptions used.
59527_11_ITEM7_P122_S2	If warranted, these estimates and assumptions may be changed as current trends are assessed and updated.
59527_11_ITEM7_P123_S0	Historically, the Company's estimates have been determined to be reasonable.
59527_11_ITEM7_P123_S1	No material changes to the Company's accounting policies were made during 2010.
59527_11_ITEM7_P123_S2	The Company believes the following are some of the more critical judgment areas in the application of its accounting policies that affect its financial condition and results of operations.
59527_11_ITEM7_P124_S0	The Company, like other manufacturers, is subject from time to time to a variety of civil and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
59527_11_ITEM7_P124_S1	Such claims and litigation include, without limitation, product liability claims and health, safety and environmental claims, some of which relate to cases alleging asbestos and manganese-induced illnesses.
59527_11_ITEM7_P124_S2	The costs associated with these claims are predominantly defense costs, which are recognized in the periods incurred.
59527_11_ITEM7_P124_S3	Insurance reimbursements mitigate these costs and, where reimbursements are probable, they are recognized in the applicable period.
59527_11_ITEM7_P125_S0	With respect to costs other than defense costs (i.e., for liability and/or settlement or other resolution), reserves are recorded when it is probable that the contingencies will have an unfavorable outcome.
59527_11_ITEM7_P125_S1	The Company accrues its best estimate of the probable costs, after a review of the facts with management and counsel and taking into account past experience.
59527_11_ITEM7_P125_S2	If an unfavorable outcome is determined to be reasonably possible but not probable, or if the amount of loss cannot be reasonably estimated, disclosure is provided for material claims or litigation.
59527_11_ITEM7_P126_S0	are in differing procedural stages and information on the circumstances of each claimant, which forms the basis for judgments as to the validity or ultimate disposition of such actions, varies greatly.
59527_11_ITEM7_P126_S1	Therefore, in many situations a range of possible losses cannot be made.
59527_11_ITEM7_P126_S2	Reserves are adjusted as facts and circumstances change and related management assessments of the underlying merits and the likelihood of outcomes change.
59527_11_ITEM7_P126_S3	Moreover, reserves only cover identified and/or asserted claims.
59527_11_ITEM7_P126_S4	Future claims could, therefore, give rise to increases to such reserves.
59527_11_ITEM7_P126_S5	See Note 14 to the Company's consolidated financial statements and the "Legal Proceedings" section of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for further discussion of legal contingencies.
59527_11_ITEM7_P127_S0	The Company is subject to taxation from U.S. federal, state, municipal and international jurisdictions.
59527_11_ITEM7_P128_S0	The calculation of current income tax expense is based on the best information available and involves significant management judgment.
59527_11_ITEM7_P128_S1	The actual income tax liability for each jurisdiction in any year can in some instances be ultimately determined several years after the financial statements are published.
59527_11_ITEM7_P129_S0	The Company maintains reserves for estimated income tax exposures for many jurisdictions.
59527_11_ITEM7_P129_S1	Exposures are settled primarily through the completion of audits within each individual tax jurisdiction or the closing of a statute of limitation.
59527_11_ITEM7_P129_S2	Exposures can also be affected by changes in applicable tax law or other factors, which may cause management to believe a revision of past estimates is appropriate.
59527_11_ITEM7_P129_S3	Management believes that an appropriate liability has been established for income tax exposures; however, actual results may materially differ from these estimates.
59527_11_ITEM7_P130_S0	Asset and liability accounts are translated into U.S. dollars using exchange rates in effect at the dates of the Consolidated Balance Sheets; revenue and expense accounts are translated at monthly exchange rates.
59527_11_ITEM7_P130_S1	Translation adjustments are reflected as a component of Total equity.
59527_11_ITEM7_P130_S2	For subsidiaries operating in highly inflationary economies, both historical and current exchange rates are used in translating balance sheet accounts, and translation adjustments are included in Net income.
59527_11_ITEM7_P131_S0	Foreign currency transaction losses are included in "Selling, general administrative expenses" and were $118, $226 and $10,409 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
59527_11_ITEM7_P132_S0	Effective January 1, 2010, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation have been remeasured into the Company's reporting currency (U.S. dollar).
59527_11_ITEM7_P133_S0	A currency control board exists in Venezuela that is responsible for foreign exchange procedures, including approval of requests for exchanges of the Venezuelan currency (the "bolivar") for U.S. dollars at the official (government established) exchange rates.
59527_11_ITEM7_P133_S1	An unregulated parallel market that existed for exchanging bolivars for U.S. dollars through securities transactions was terminated by the Venezuelan government on May 17, 2010 and subsequently established as a regulated market on June 9, 2010.
59527_11_ITEM7_P134_S0	The official exchange rate in Venezuela had been fixed at 2.15 bolivars to 1 U.S. dollar for several years.
59527_11_ITEM7_P135_S0	On January 8, 2010, the Venezuelan government announced the devaluation of its currency relative to the U.S. dollar.
59527_11_ITEM7_P135_S1	The official exchange rate for imported goods classified as essential changed from 2.15 to 2.60 (the "Essential Rate"), while the official exchange rate for other non-essential goods moved to an exchange rate of 4.30 (the "Non-Essential Rate").
59527_11_ITEM7_P135_S2	In remeasuring the financial statements the Non-Essential Rate is used as this is the rate expected to be applicable to dividend repatriations.
59527_11_ITEM7_P136_S0	In December 2010, the Venezuelan government announced the elimination of the Essential Rate effective as of January 1, 2011.
59527_11_ITEM7_P136_S1	The impact of the elimination of the Essential Rate on the Company's consolidated results of operations is not expected to be significant.
59527_11_ITEM7_P137_S0	An economy is considered highly inflationary under GAAP if the cumulative inflation rate for a three-year period meets or exceeds 100 percent.
59527_11_ITEM7_P137_S1	The Venezuelan three-year cumulative inflation rate exceeded 100 percent during the fourth quarter of 2009.
59527_11_ITEM7_P137_S2	As a result, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation are reported under highly inflationary accounting rules as of January 1, 2010.
59527_11_ITEM7_P138_S0	Under highly inflationary accounting, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation have been remeasured into the Company's reporting currency and exchange gains and losses from the remeasurement of monetary assets and liabilities are reflected in current earnings, rather than "Accumulated other comprehensive loss" on the Company's Consolidated Balance Sheet.
59527_11_ITEM7_P139_S0	Future impacts to earnings of applying highly inflationary accounting for Venezuela on the Company's consolidated financial statements will be dependent upon movements in the applicable exchange rates between the bolivar and the U.S. dollar and the amount of monetary assets and liabilities included in the Company's Venezuelan operation's balance sheet.
59527_11_ITEM7_P139_S1	At December 31, 2010, the net bolivar-denominated monetary liability position was $4,715.
59527_11_ITEM7_P139_S2	In addition, the Company participates in Venezuelan sovereign debt offerings from time to time as a means of converting bolivars to U.S. dollars.
59527_11_ITEM7_P139_S3	The conversion of bolivars to U.S. dollars through Venezuelan sovereign debt offerings generates foreign currency transaction losses as the debt is purchased at the Non-Essential Rate and subsequently sold at a discount.
59527_11_ITEM7_P140_S0	During the second half of 2010, the Company acquired $7,672 of Venezuelan sovereign debt at the Non-Essential Rate, which was immediately sold at a discount for $6,022.
59527_11_ITEM7_P141_S0	The devaluation of the bolivar and the change to the U.S. dollar as the functional currency resulted in a foreign currency transaction gain of $2,632 in "Selling, general administrative expenses" and higher "Cost of goods sold" of $5,755 due to the liquidation of inventory valued at the historical exchange rate for the year ended December 31, 2010.
59527_11_ITEM7_P142_S0	Deferred income taxes are recognized at currently enacted tax rates for temporary differences between the financial reporting and income tax bases of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
59527_11_ITEM7_P142_S1	The Company does not provide deferred income taxes on unremitted earnings of certain non-U.S. subsidiaries, which are deemed permanently reinvested.
59527_11_ITEM7_P142_S2	It is not practicable to calculate the deferred taxes associated with the remittance of these earnings.
59527_11_ITEM7_P142_S3	Deferred income taxes associated with earnings of $4,690 that are not expected to be permanently reinvested were not significant.
59527_11_ITEM7_P142_S4	At December 31, 2010, the Company had approximately $136,814 of gross deferred tax assets related to deductible temporary differences and tax loss and credit carryforwards which may reduce taxable income in future years.
59527_11_ITEM7_P143_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, the Company assesses whether it is more likely than not that a portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
59527_11_ITEM7_P143_S1	The Company considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities, tax planning strategies, and projected future taxable income in making this assessment.
59527_11_ITEM7_P143_S2	At December 31, 2010, a valuation allowance of $38,451 was recorded against these deferred tax assets based on this assessment.
59527_11_ITEM7_P143_S3	The Company believes it is more likely than not that the tax benefit of the remaining net deferred tax assets will be realized.
59527_11_ITEM7_P143_S4	The amount of net deferred tax assets considered realizable could be increased or reduced in the future if the Company's assessment of future taxable income or tax planning strategies changes.
59527_11_ITEM7_P144_S0	The Company maintains a number of defined benefit and defined contribution plans to provide retirement benefits for employees.
59527_11_ITEM7_P144_S1	These plans are maintained and contributions are made in accordance with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ("ERISA"), local statutory law or as determined by the Board of Directors.
59527_11_ITEM7_P144_S2	The plans generally provide benefits based upon years of service and compensation.
59527_11_ITEM7_P144_S3	Pension plans are funded except for a domestic non-qualified pension plan for certain key employees and certain foreign plans.
59527_11_ITEM7_P145_S0	A substantial portion of the Company's pension amounts relates to its defined benefit plan in the United States.
59527_11_ITEM7_P146_S0	The fair value of plan assets is determined at December 31 of each year.
59527_11_ITEM7_P147_S0	A significant element in determining the Company's pension expense is the expected return on plan assets.
59527_11_ITEM7_P147_S1	At the end of each year, the expected return on plan assets is determined based on the weighted average expected return of the various asset classes in the plan's portfolio and the targeted allocation of plan assets.
59527_11_ITEM7_P147_S2	The asset class return is developed using historical asset return performance as well as current market conditions such as inflation, interest rates and equity market performance.
59527_11_ITEM7_P147_S3	The Company determined this rate to be 7.9% and 8.2% at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
59527_11_ITEM7_P148_S0	The assumed long-term rate of return on assets is applied to the market value of plan assets.
59527_11_ITEM7_P148_S1	This produces the expected return on plan assets included in pension expense.
59527_11_ITEM7_P148_S2	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is deferred and amortized over the average remaining service period of active employees expected to receive benefits under the plan.
59527_11_ITEM7_P148_S3	The amortization of the net deferral of past losses will increase future pension expense.
59527_11_ITEM7_P149_S0	During 2010, investment returns were 13.2% compared with a return of 16.3% in 2009.
59527_11_ITEM7_P149_S1	A 25 basis point change in the expected return on plan assets would increase or decrease pension expense by approximately $1,600.
59527_11_ITEM7_P150_S0	Another significant element in determining the Company's pension expense is the discount rate for plan liabilities.
59527_11_ITEM7_P150_S1	To develop the discount rate assumption to be used, the Company refers to the yield derived from matching projected pension payments with maturities of a portfolio of available non-callable bonds rated AA- or better.
59527_11_ITEM7_P150_S2	The Company determined this rate to be 5.3% at December 31, 2010.
59527_11_ITEM7_P150_S3	A 25 basis point change in the discount rate would increase or decrease pension expense by approximately $2,000.
59527_11_ITEM7_P151_S0	Pension expense relating to the Company's defined benefit plans was $29,123, $34,774 and $4,613 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
59527_11_ITEM7_P151_S1	The Company expects 2011 defined benefit pension expense to decrease by approximately $4,000 to $5,000.
59527_11_ITEM7_P152_S0	The Company made voluntary contributions to its U.S. defined benefit plans of $41,500, $45,000 and $20,000 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
59527_11_ITEM7_P152_S1	The Company expects to voluntarily contribute $30,000 to its U.S. plans in 2011.
59527_11_ITEM7_P152_S2	Based on current pension funding rules, the Company does not anticipate that contributions to the plans would be required in 2011.
59527_11_ITEM7_P153_S0	Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
59527_11_ITEM7_P153_S1	Fixed manufacturing overhead costs are allocated to inventory based on normal production capacity and abnormal manufacturing costs are recognized as period costs.
59527_11_ITEM7_P154_S0	For most domestic inventories, cost is determined principally by the last-in, first-out ("LIFO") method, and for non-U.S. inventories, cost is determined by the first-in, first-out ("FIFO") method.
59527_11_ITEM7_P155_S0	An actual valuation of the inventory under the LIFO method can be made only at the end of each year based on the inventory levels and costs at that time.
59527_11_ITEM7_P155_S1	Accordingly, interim LIFO calculations are based on management's estimates of expected year-end inventory levels and costs.
59527_11_ITEM7_P156_S0	results as they are subject to the final year-end LIFO inventory valuation.
59527_11_ITEM7_P156_S1	The excess of current cost over LIFO cost was $70,906 at December 31, 2010 and $62,447 at December 31, 2009.
59527_11_ITEM7_P157_S0	The Company reviews the net realizable value of inventory on an on-going basis, with consideration given to deterioration, obsolescence and other factors.
59527_11_ITEM7_P157_S1	If actual market conditions differ from those projected by management, and the Company's estimates prove to be inaccurate, write-downs of inventory values and adjustments to cost of sales may be required.
59527_11_ITEM7_P158_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_11_ITEM7_P159_S0	The Company maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses from the failure of its customers to make required payments for products delivered.
59527_11_ITEM7_P159_S1	The Company estimates this allowance based on the age of the related receivable, knowledge of the financial condition of customers, review of historical receivables and reserve trends and other pertinent information.
59527_11_ITEM7_P159_S2	If the financial condition of customers deteriorates or an unfavorable trend in receivable collections is experienced in the future, additional allowances may be required.
59527_11_ITEM7_P160_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_11_ITEM7_P161_S0	The Company periodically evaluates whether current facts or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of its depreciable long-lived assets to be held and used may not be recoverable.
59527_11_ITEM7_P161_S1	If such circumstances are determined to exist, an estimate of undiscounted future cash flows produced by the long-lived asset, or the appropriate grouping of assets, is compared to the carrying value to determine whether impairment exists.
59527_11_ITEM7_P162_S0	If an asset is determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized to the extent that carrying value exceeds fair value.
59527_11_ITEM7_P163_S0	Fair value is measured based on quoted market prices in active markets, if available.
59527_11_ITEM7_P163_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, the estimate of fair value is based on various valuation techniques, including the discounted value of estimated future cash flows.
59527_11_ITEM7_P164_S0	The Company performs an annual impairment test of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets in the fourth quarter using the same dates each year or more frequently if changes in circumstances or the occurrence of events indicate potential impairment.
59527_11_ITEM7_P164_S1	The fair value of each indefinite-lived intangible asset is compared to its carrying value and an impairment charge is recorded if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
59527_11_ITEM7_P165_S0	Goodwill is tested by comparing the fair value of each reporting unit with its carrying value.
59527_11_ITEM7_P165_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the implied value of goodwill is compared to its carrying value and impairment is recognized to the extent that the carrying value exceeds the implied fair value.
59527_11_ITEM7_P166_S0	Fair values are determined using established business valuation multiples and models developed by the Company that incorporate allocations of certain assets and cash flows among reporting units, estimates of market participant assumptions of future cash flows, future growth rates and the applicable discount rates to value estimated cash flows.
59527_11_ITEM7_P166_S1	Changes in economic and operating conditions impacting these assumptions could result in asset impairments in future periods.
59527_11_ITEM7_P167_S0	The fair value of goodwill for all of the Company's operating business units exceeded its carrying value by at least 10% as of the testing date during the fourth quarter of 2010.
59527_11_ITEM7_P167_S1	Key assumptions in estimating the reporting unit's fair value include assumed market participant assumptions of revenue growth, operating margins and the rate used to discount future cash flows.
59527_11_ITEM7_P168_S0	rate would have a negative impact on the fair value of the reporting unit that could result in a goodwill impairment charge in a future period.

59527_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	In the ordinary course of our business, we face various strategic, operating, compliance and financial risks.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	These risks could have a material impact on our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Our Enterprise Risk Management ("ERM") process seeks to identify and address significant risks.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Our ERM process is a company-wide initiative that is designed with the intent of prioritizing risks and assigning appropriate consideration for such risks.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P4_S2	We use the integrated risk framework of the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations to assess, manage and monitor risks.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Management has identified and prioritized critical risks based on the severity and likelihood of each risk and assigned an executive to address each major identified risk area and lead action plans to monitor and mitigate risks, where possible.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Our Board of Directors provides oversight of the ERM process and systematically reviews identified critical risks.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P5_S2	The Audit Committee also reviews major financial risk exposures and the steps management has taken to monitor and control them.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our goal is to proactively manage risks in a structured approach and in conjunction with the strategic planning process, with the intent to preserve and enhance shareholder value.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	However, these and other risks and uncertainties could cause our results to vary materially from recent results or from our anticipated future results.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	The risk factors and uncertainties described below, together with information incorporated by reference or otherwise included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, should be carefully considered.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Additional risks and uncertainties of which we are currently unaware or that we currently believe to be immaterial may also adversely affect our business.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	General economic and market conditions may adversely affect the Company's financial condition, results of operations and access to capital markets.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The Company's operating results are sensitive to changes in general economic conditions.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Recessionary economic cycles, higher interest rates, inflation, higher labor costs, trade barriers in the world markets, financial turmoil related to sovereign debt and changes in tax laws or other economic factors affecting the countries and industries in which we do business could adversely affect demand for the Company's products, thereby impacting our results of operations, financial condition and access to capital markets.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Economic and supply disruptions associated with events beyond our control, such as war, acts of terror, political unrest, public health concerns, labor disputes or natural disasters could adversely affect our supply chain and distribution channels or result in loss of sales and customers.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our facilities and operations, and the facilities and operations of our suppliers and customers, could be disrupted by events beyond our control, such as war, political unrest, public health concerns, labor disputes or natural disasters.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Any such disruption could cause delays in the production and distribution of our products and the loss of sales and customers.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Insurance proceeds may not adequately compensate the Company for the losses.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Availability of and volatility in energy costs or raw material prices may adversely affect our performance.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	In the normal course of business, we are exposed to market risks related to the availability of and price fluctuations in the purchase of energy and commodities used in the manufacture of our products (primarily steel, brass, copper, silver, aluminum alloys, electronic components, electricity and natural gas).
59527_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	The availability and prices for raw materials are subject to volatility and are influenced by worldwide economic conditions, speculative action, world supply and demand balances, inventory levels, availability of substitute materials, currency exchange rates, our competitors' production costs, anticipated or perceived shortages and other factors.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P12_S2	The price of steel used to manufacture our products has experienced periods of significant price volatility and has been subject to periodic shortages due to global economic factors.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P12_S3	We have also experienced substantial volatility in prices for other raw materials, including nonferrous metals, chemicals and energy costs.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Increases in the cost of raw materials and components may adversely affect our profitability if we are unable to pass along to our customers these cost increases in the form of price increases or otherwise reduce our cost of goods sold.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Although most of the raw materials and components used in our products are commercially available from a number of sources and in adequate supply, any disruption in the availability of such raw materials and components, our inability to timely or otherwise obtain substitutes for such items, or any deterioration in our relationships with or the financial viability of our suppliers could adversely affect our business.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We are a co-defendant in litigation alleging manganese induced illness and litigation alleging asbestos induced illness.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Liabilities relating to such litigation could reduce our profitability and impair our financial condition.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P15_S0	At December 31, 2011, we were a co-defendant in cases alleging manganese induced illness involving claims by approximately 806 plaintiffs and a co-defendant in cases alleging asbestos induced illness involving claims by approximately 16,781 plaintiffs.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P15_S1	In each instance, we are one of a large number of defendants.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P16_S0	In the manganese cases, the claimants allege that exposure to manganese contained in welding consumables caused the plaintiffs to develop adverse neurological conditions, including a condition known as manganism.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P17_S0	contained in welding consumables caused the plaintiffs to develop adverse pulmonary diseases, including mesothelioma and other lung cancers.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Since January 1, 1995, we have been a co-defendant in manganese cases that have been resolved as follows: 16,031 of those claims were dismissed, 23 were tried to defense verdicts in favor of us and five were tried to plaintiff verdicts (three of which were reversed on appeal and one of which has post-trial motions pending).
59527_12_ITEM1A_P18_S1	In addition, 13 claims were resolved by agreement for immaterial amounts and one claim was decided in favor of the Company following a summary judgment motion.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Since January 1, 1995, we have been a co-defendant in asbestos cases that have been resolved as follows: 39,199 of those claims were dismissed, 18 were tried to defense verdicts, seven were tried to plaintiff verdicts (two of which are being appealed), one was resolved by agreement for an immaterial amount and 585 were decided in favor of the Company following summary judgment motions.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P19_S0	The long-term impact of the manganese and asbestos loss contingencies, in each case in the aggregate, on operating results, operating cash flows and access to capital markets is difficult to assess, particularly since claims are in many different stages of development and we benefit significantly from cost-sharing with co-defendants and insurance carriers.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P19_S1	While we intend to contest these lawsuits vigorously, and believe we have applicable insurance relating to these claims, there are several risks and uncertainties that may affect our liability for personal claims relating to exposure to manganese and asbestos, including the future impact of changing cost sharing arrangements or a change in our overall trial experience.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P19_S2	In addition, in January 2012, the Company and 18 co-defendants entered into an agreement that provides for the dismissal with prejudice of substantially all of the pending manganese claims if certain conditions precedent are satisfied.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P19_S3	Failure to satisfy those conditions could lead to the resumption of that litigation and increased defense costs.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Manganese is an essential element of steel and cannot be eliminated from welding consumables.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Asbestos use in welding consumables in the U.S. ceased in 1981.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We may incur material losses and costs as a result of product liability claims that may be brought against us.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Our business exposes us to potential product liability risks that are inherent in the design, manufacture, sale and application of our products and the products of third-party suppliers that we utilize or resell.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Our products are used in a variety of applications, including infrastructure projects such as oil and gas pipelines and platforms, buildings, bridges and power generation facilities, the manufacture of transportation and heavy equipment and machinery, and various other construction projects.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P23_S2	We face risk of exposure to product liability claims in the event that accidents or failures on these projects result, or are alleged to result, in bodily injury or property damage.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P23_S3	Further, our products are designed for use in specific applications, and if a product is used inappropriately, personal injury or property damage may result.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P24_S0	The occurrence of defects in or failures of our products, or the misuse of our products in specific applications, could cause termination of customer contracts, increased costs and losses to us, our customers and other end users.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P24_S1	We cannot be assured that we will not experience any material product liability losses in the future or that we will not incur significant costs to defend those claims.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P24_S2	Further, we cannot be assured that our product liability insurance coverage will be adequate for any liabilities that we may ultimately incur or that product liability insurance will continue to be available on terms acceptable to us.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P25_S0	The cyclicality and maturity of the arc welding and cutting industry in developed markets may adversely affect our performance.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P26_S0	The arc welding and cutting industry is generally a mature industry in developed markets such as North America and Western Europe and is cyclical in nature.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P26_S1	Overall demand for arc welding and cutting products is largely determined by the level of capital spending in manufacturing and other industrial sectors, and the welding industry has historically experienced contraction during periods of slowing industrial activity.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P26_S2	If economic, business and industry conditions deteriorate, capital spending in those sectors may be substantially decreased, which could reduce demand for our products, our revenues and our results of operations.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P27_S0	We may not be able to complete our acquisition strategy or successfully integrate acquired businesses.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Part of our business strategy is to pursue targeted business acquisition opportunities, including foreign investment opportunities.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P28_S1	For example, we have completed and continue to pursue acquisitions in emerging markets including, but not limited to, Brazil, Russia, India and China in order to strategically position resources to increase our presence in growing markets.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P28_S2	We cannot be certain that we will be successful in pursuing potential acquisition candidates or that the consequences of any acquisition would be beneficial to us.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P28_S3	Future acquisitions may expose us to unexpected liabilities and involve the expenditure of significant funds and management time.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P28_S4	Further, we may not be able to successfully integrate any acquired business with our existing businesses or recognize the expected benefits from any completed acquisition.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Depending on the nature, size and timing of future acquisitions, we may be required to raise additional financing, which may not be available to us on acceptable terms.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Our current operational cash flow is sufficient to fund our current acquisition plans, but a significant acquisition could require access to the capital markets.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P30_S0	If we cannot continue to develop, manufacture and market products that meet customer demands, our revenues and gross margins may suffer.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Our continued success depends, in part, on our ability to continue to meet our customers' needs for welding and cutting products through the introduction of innovative new products and the enhancement of existing product design and performance characteristics.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P31_S1	We must remain committed to product research and development and customer service in order to remain competitive.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P31_S2	We cannot be assured that new products or product improvements, once developed, will meet with customer acceptance and contribute positively to our operating results, or that we will be able to continue our product development efforts at a pace to sustain future growth.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P31_S3	Further, we may lose customers to our competitors if they demonstrate product design, development or manufacturing capabilities superior to ours.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P32_S0	The competitive pressures we face could harm our revenue, gross margins and prospects.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We operate in a highly competitive global environment and compete in each of our businesses with other broad-line manufacturers and numerous smaller competitors specializing in particular products.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P33_S1	We compete primarily on the basis of brand, product quality, price, performance, warranty, delivery, service and technical support.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P33_S2	We have previously initiated, and may in the future initiate significant rationalization activities to align our business to market conditions.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P33_S3	Such rationalization activities could fail to deliver the desired competitive cost structure and could result in disruptions in customer service.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P33_S4	If our products, services, support and cost structure do not enable us to compete successfully based on any of the criteria listed above, our operations, results and prospects could suffer.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Further, in the past decade, the arc welding industry in the United States and other developed countries has been subject to increased levels of foreign competition as low cost imports have become more readily available.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P34_S1	Our competitive position could also be harmed if new or emerging competitors become more active in the arc welding business.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P34_S2	For example, while steel manufacturers traditionally have not been significant competitors in the domestic arc welding industry, some foreign integrated steel producers manufacture selected consumable arc welding products.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P34_S3	Our sales and results of operations, as well as our plans to expand in some foreign countries, could be adversely affected by this practice.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P35_S0	The loss of any of our largest customers could adversely affect our revenue, gross margins and profit.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We have a large and varied customer base due, in part, to our extensive distribution channels in the industries and regions that we serve.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P36_S1	Although no individual customer currently accounts for more than ten percent of total Net sales, there are customers to which we sell a large amount of product.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P36_S2	The loss of any of these customers could have an adverse effect on our revenue, gross margins and profit.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P37_S0	We conduct our sales and distribution operations on a worldwide basis and maintain manufacturing facilities in a number of foreign countries, which subjects us to risks associated with doing business outside the United States.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Our long-term strategy is to continue to increase our market share in growing international markets, particularly Asia (with emphasis in China and India), Latin America, Eastern Europe, Russia and other developing markets.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P39_S0	The share of sales and profits we derive from our international operations and exports from the United States is significant and growing.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P39_S1	This trend increases our exposure to the performance of many developing economies in addition to the developed economies outside of the United States.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P40_S0	There are a number of risks in doing business internationally, which may impede our ability to achieve our strategic objectives relating to our foreign operations.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Many developing countries have a significant degree of political and economic uncertainty and social turmoil that may impede our ability to implement and achieve our international growth objectives.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Conducting business internationally subjects us to corporate governance and management challenges in consideration of the numerous U.S. and foreign laws and regulations, including regulations relating to import-export control, technology transfer restrictions, repatriation of earnings and funds, exchange controls, labor regulations, nationalization, anti-boycott provisions and anti-bribery laws (such as the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development Convention).
59527_12_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Failure by the Company or its sales representatives, agents or distributors to comply with these laws and regulations could result in administrative, civil or criminal liabilities, all or any of which could negatively impact our business and reputation.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P41_S2	Our foreign operations also subject us to the risks of international terrorism and hostilities.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Our operations depend on maintaining a skilled workforce, and any interruption in our workforce could negatively impact our results of operations and financial condition.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Our success depends in part on the efforts and abilities of our management team and key employees.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P43_S1	Their skills, experience and industry knowledge significantly benefit our operations and performance.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P43_S2	Our future success will also depend on our ability to identify, attract, and retain highly qualified managerial, technical (including research and development), sales and marketing, and customer service personnel.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P43_S3	Competition for these individuals is intense, and we may not succeed in identifying, attracting, or retaining qualified personnel.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P43_S4	With our strategy to expand internationally into developing markets, we may incur additional risks as some developing economies lack a sufficiently trained labor pool.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Any interruption of our workforce, including interruptions due to unionization efforts, changes in labor relations or shortages of appropriately skilled individuals could impact our results of operations and financial condition.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Our revenues and results of operations may suffer if we cannot continue to enforce the intellectual property rights on which our business depends or if third parties assert that we violate their intellectual property rights.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P46_S0	We rely upon patent, trademark, copyright and trade secret laws in the United States and similar laws in foreign countries, as well as agreements with our employees, customers, suppliers and other third parties, to establish and maintain our intellectual property rights.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P46_S1	However, any of our intellectual property rights could be challenged, invalidated or circumvented, or our intellectual property rights may not be sufficient to provide a competitive advantage.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P46_S2	Further, the laws and their application in certain foreign countries do not protect our proprietary rights to the same extent as U.S. laws.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P46_S3	Accordingly, in certain countries, we may be unable to protect our proprietary rights against unauthorized third-party copying or use, which could impact our competitive position.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Further, third parties may claim that we or our customers are infringing upon their intellectual property rights.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P47_S1	Even if we believe that those claims are without merit, defending those claims and contesting the validity of patents can be time-consuming and costly.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P47_S2	Claims of intellectual property infringement also might require us to redesign affected products, enter into costly settlement or license agreements or pay costly damage awards, or face a temporary or permanent injunction prohibiting us from manufacturing, marketing or selling certain of our products.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P48_S0	Our defined benefit pension plans are subject to financial market trends, such as changes in discount rates and actual investment return on pension assets, which could adversely affect our results of operations and cash flows.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P49_S0	The performance of the financial markets and interest rates impact our funding obligations under our defined benefit pension plans.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Significant changes in discount rates, decreases in the fair value of plan assets and investment losses on plan assets may increase our benefit obligations and adversely impact our results of operations, shareholders' equity and cash flows through our annual measurement of plan assets and liabilities.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P49_S2	For a discussion regarding how the financial statements have been affected by significant changes in 2011, refer to the pension related disclosure under "Part II, Item 7 Critical Accounting Policies" and Note 10 to the Company's consolidated financial statements.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P50_S0	A significant fluctuation between the U.S. dollar and other currencies could adversely impact our operating income.

59527_12_ITEM1A_P51_S1	Our profitability is affected by movements of the U.S. dollar against other foreign currencies in which we generate revenues and incur expenses.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P51_S2	Significant long-term fluctuations in relative currency values, in particular an increase in the value of the U.S. dollar against foreign currencies, could have an adverse effect on our profitability and financial condition.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P52_S0	Changes in tax rates or exposure to additional income tax liabilities could affect profitability.

59527_12_ITEM1A_P54_S0	with differing statutory tax rates, changes in the valuation allowance of deferred tax assets or changes in tax laws.

59527_12_ITEM1A_P55_S1	If these audits result in assessments different from amounts reserved, future financial results may include unfavorable adjustments which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.

59527_12_ITEM1A_P58_S0	Our global operations are subject to increasingly complex environmental regulatory requirements.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P59_S0	We are subject to increasingly complex environmental regulations affecting international manufacturers, including those related to air and water emissions, waste management and climate change.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P60_S0	There is a growing political and scientific belief that emissions of greenhouse gases ("GHG") alter the composition of the global atmosphere in ways that are affecting the global climate.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P60_S1	Various stakeholders, including legislators and regulators, shareholders and non-governmental organizations, as well as companies in many business sectors, are considering ways to reduce GHG emissions.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P60_S2	These concerns may lead to international, national, regional or local legislative or regulatory responses in the future.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P60_S3	Such regulation could result in new or additional regulatory or product standard requirements for the Company's global businesses.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P60_S4	We are unable, at this time, to predict the significance of these requirements as the impact of any future GHG legislative, regulatory or product standards is dependent on the timing and design of the mandates or standards.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P60_S5	Furthermore, the potential physical impacts of theorized climate change on the Company's customers, and therefore on the Company's operations, are speculative and highly uncertain, and would be particular to the circumstances developing in various geographical regions.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P60_S6	These may include changes in weather patterns (including drought and rainfall levels), water availability, storm patterns and intensities, and temperature levels.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P60_S7	These potential physical effects may adversely impact the cost, production, sales and financial performance of the Company's operations which we are unable, at this time, to predict.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P61_S0	It is our policy to apply strict standards for environmental protection to all of our operations inside and outside the United States, even when we are not subject to local government regulations.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P61_S1	We may incur substantial costs, including cleanup costs, fines and civil or criminal sanctions, liabilities resulting from third-party property damage or personal injury claims, or our products could be enjoined from entering certain jurisdictions, if we were to violate or become liable under environmental laws or if our products become non-compliant with environmental laws.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P62_S0	We also face increasing complexity in our products design and procurement operations as we adjust to new and future requirements relating to the design, production and labeling of our products that are sold worldwide in multiple jurisdictions.
59527_12_ITEM1A_P63_S0	The ultimate costs under environmental laws and the timing of these costs are difficult to predict, and liability under some environmental laws relating to contaminated locations can be imposed retroactively and on a joint and several basis.

59527_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	This Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations should be read together with "Selected Financial Data," the Company's consolidated financial statements and other financial information included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. This Annual Report on Form 10-K contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
59527_12_ITEM7_P0_S1	Actual results may differ materially from those indicated in the forward-looking statements.
59527_12_ITEM7_P0_S2	See "Item 1A. Risk Factors" for more information regarding forward-looking statements.
59527_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company is the world's largest designer and manufacturer of arc welding and cutting products, manufacturing a broad line of arc welding equipment, consumable welding products and other welding and cutting products.
59527_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company is one of only a few worldwide broad-line manufacturers of welding, cutting and brazing products.
59527_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	Welding products include arc welding power sources, wire feeding systems, robotic welding packages, fume extraction equipment, consumable electrodes and fluxes.
59527_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	The Company's product offering also includes CNC plasma and oxy-fuel cutting systems, regulators and torches used in oxy-fuel welding, cutting and brazing.
59527_12_ITEM7_P2_S3	In addition, the Company has a leading global position in the brazing and soldering alloys market.
59527_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Company invests in the research and development of arc welding products in order to continue its market leading product offering.
59527_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	The Company continues to invest in technologies that improve the quality and productivity of welding products.
59527_12_ITEM7_P3_S2	In addition, the Company continues to actively increase its patent application process in order to secure its technology advantage in the United States and other major international jurisdictions.
59527_12_ITEM7_P3_S3	The Company believes its significant investment in research and development and its highly trained technical sales force coupled with its extensive distributor network provide a competitive advantage in the marketplace.
59527_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	The Company's products are sold in both domestic and international markets.
59527_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	In North America, products are sold principally through industrial distributors, retailers and also directly to users of welding products.
59527_12_ITEM7_P4_S2	Outside of North America, the Company has an international sales organization comprised of Company employees and agents who sell products from the Company's various manufacturing sites to distributors and product users.
59527_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	The Company's major end-user markets include:
59527_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	general metal fabrication, power generation and process industry, structural steel construction (buildings and bridges), heavy equipment fabrication (farming, mining and rail), shipbuilding, automotive, pipe mills and pipelines, and offshore oil and gas exploration and extraction.
59527_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Company has, through wholly-owned subsidiaries or joint ventures, manufacturing facilities located in the United States, Australia, Brazil, Canada, China, Colombia, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Mexico, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Russia, Turkey, the United Kingdom and Venezuela.
59527_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	The Company has aligned its business units into five operating segments to enhance the utilization of the Company's worldwide resources and global end user and sourcing initiatives.
59527_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	The operating segments consist of North America Welding, Europe Welding, Asia Pacific Welding, South America Welding and The Harris Products Group.
59527_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	The North America Welding segment includes welding operations in the United States, Canada and Mexico.
59527_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	The Europe Welding segment includes welding operations in Europe, Russia and Africa.
59527_12_ITEM7_P9_S2	The other two welding segments include welding operations in Asia Pacific and South America, respectively.
59527_12_ITEM7_P9_S3	The fifth segment, The Harris Products Group, includes the Company's global cutting, soldering and brazing businesses as well as the retail business in the United States.
59527_12_ITEM7_P9_S4	See Note 4 to the Company's consolidated financial statements for segment and geographic area information, which is incorporated herein by reference.
59527_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	The principal raw materials essential to the Company's business are steel, electronic components, engines, brass, copper, silver, aluminum alloys and various chemicals, all of which are normally available for purchase in the open market.
59527_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	The Company's facilities are subject to environmental regulations.
59527_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	To date, compliance with these environmental regulations has not had a material adverse effect on the Company's earnings.
59527_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	The Company is ISO 9001 certified at nearly all facilities worldwide.
59527_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	In addition, the Company is ISO 14001 certified at most significant manufacturing facilities in North America and Europe and is progressing towards certification at its remaining facilities worldwide.
59527_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	Key economic measures relevant to the Company include industrial production trends, steel consumption, purchasing manager indices, capacity utilization within durable goods manufacturers and consumer confidence indicators.
59527_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	Key industries which provide a relative indication of demand drivers to the Company include steel, farm machinery and equipment, construction and transportation, fabricated metals, electrical equipment, ship and boat building, defense, truck manufacturing, energy and railroad equipment.
59527_12_ITEM7_P13_S2	Although these measures provide key information on trends relevant to the Company, the Company does not have available a more direct correlation of leading indicators which can provide a forward-looking view of demand levels in the markets which ultimately use the Company's welding products.
59527_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	Key operating measures utilized by the operating units to manage the Company include orders, sales, inventory and fill-rates, all of which provide key indicators of business trends.
59527_12_ITEM7_P14_S1	These measures are reported on various cycles including daily, weekly and monthly depending on the needs established by operating management.
59527_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	Key financial measures utilized by the Company's executive management and operating units in order to evaluate the results of its business and in understanding key variables impacting the current and future results of the Company include: sales; gross profit; selling, general and administrative expenses; operating income; earnings before interest and taxes; earnings before interest, taxes and bonus; net income; adjusted operating income; adjusted net income; adjusted diluted earnings per share; operating cash flows; and capital expenditures, including applicable ratios such as return on invested capital and average operating working capital to sales.
59527_12_ITEM7_P15_S1	These measures are reviewed at monthly, quarterly and annual intervals and compared with historical periods, as well as objectives established by the Board of Directors of the Company.

59527_12_ITEM7_P108_S0	Product liability costs have been significant particularly with respect to welding fume claims.
59527_12_ITEM7_P108_S1	Costs incurred are volatile and are largely related to trial activity.
59527_12_ITEM7_P108_S2	The costs associated with these claims are predominantly defense costs which are recognized in the periods incurred.
59527_12_ITEM7_P108_S3	Product liability costs decreased $1,387 in 2011 compared with 2010 primarily due to reduced trial activity.
59527_12_ITEM7_P109_S0	The long-term impact of the welding fume loss contingency, in the aggregate, on operating results, operating cash flows and access to capital markets is difficult to assess, particularly since claims are in many different stages of development and the Company benefits significantly from cost sharing with co-defendants and insurance carriers.
59527_12_ITEM7_P109_S1	Moreover, the Company has been largely successful to date in its defense of these claims and indemnity payments have been immaterial.
59527_12_ITEM7_P109_S2	In January 2012, the Company and 18 co-defendants entered into an agreement that provides for the dismissal with prejudice of substantially all of the pending manganese claims if certain conditions precedent are satisfied.
59527_12_ITEM7_P109_S3	Lastly, if cost sharing dissipates for some currently unforeseen reason, or the Company's trial experience changes overall, it is possible on a longer term basis that the cost of resolving this loss contingency could materially reduce the Company's operating results, cash flows and restrict capital market access.
