59527_13_ITEM7_P78_S0	Product Liability Costs Product liability costs have historically been significant particularly with respect to welding fume claims.
59527_13_ITEM7_P78_S1	Costs incurred are volatile and are largely related to trial activity.
59527_13_ITEM7_P78_S2	The costs associated with these claims are predominantly defense costs which are recognized in the periods incurred.
59527_13_ITEM7_P78_S3	Product liability costs decreased $2,922 in 2012 compared with 2011 primarily due to reduced trial activity.
59527_13_ITEM7_P78_S4	The long-term impact of the welding fume loss contingency, in the aggregate, on operating results, operating cash flows and access to capital markets is difficult to assess, particularly since claims are in many different stages of development and the Company benefits significantly from cost sharing with co-defendants and insurance carriers.
59527_13_ITEM7_P78_S5	Moreover, the Company has been largely successful to date in its defense of these claims.
59527_13_ITEM7_P79_S0	The Company utilizes letters of credit to back certain payment and performance obligations.
59527_13_ITEM7_P79_S1	Letters of credit are subject to limits based on amounts outstanding under the Company's Credit Agreement.
59527_13_ITEM7_P79_S2	New Accounting Pronouncements New Accounting Standards to be Adopted:
59527_13_ITEM7_P80_S0	No. 2013-02, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Reporting of Amounts Reclassified Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income.
59527_13_ITEM7_P80_S1	ASU 2013-02 requires an entity to provide information about the amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by component.
59527_13_ITEM7_P80_S2	In addition, an entity is required to present, either on the face of the statement where net income is presented or in the notes, significant amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by the respective line items of net income but only if the amount reclassified is required under U.S. GAAP to be reclassified to net income in its entirety in the same reporting period.
59527_13_ITEM7_P80_S3	For other amounts, an entity is required to cross-reference to other disclosures required under U.S. GAAP that provide additional detail about those amounts.
59527_13_ITEM7_P80_S4	The amendments are effective prospectively for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2012.
59527_13_ITEM7_P80_S5	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of ASU 2013-02 on the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM7_P81_S0	In July 2012, the FASB issued ASU No. 2012-02, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Testing Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets for Impairment.
59527_13_ITEM7_P81_S1	ASU 2012-02 permits an entity first to assess qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that an indefinite-lived intangible asset is impaired as a basis for determining whether it is necessary to perform the quantitative impairment test in accordance with Subtopic 350-30, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other - General Intangibles Other than Goodwill .
59527_13_ITEM7_P82_S0	The more-likely-than-not threshold is defined as having a likelihood of more than 50 percent.
59527_13_ITEM7_P82_S1	In accordance with this update, an entity will have an option not to calculate annually the fair value of an indefinite-lived intangible asset if the entity determines that it is not more likely than not that the asset is impaired.
59527_13_ITEM7_P82_S2	The amendments are effective for annual and interim impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after September 15, 2012.
59527_13_ITEM7_P83_S0	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of ASU 2012-02 on the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM7_P84_S0	ASU 2011-11 requires an entity to disclose information about financial instruments and derivative instruments that are subject to offsetting, master netting or other similar arrangements, to illustrate the effect or potential effect of those arrangements on the Company's financial position.
59527_13_ITEM7_P84_S1	In January 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-01, Balance Sheet (Topic 210): Clarifying the Scope of Disclosures about Offsetting Assets and Liabilities , which clarifies the scope of ASU 2011-11.
59527_13_ITEM7_P84_S2	The amendments are effective for annual periods beginning on or after January 1, 2013 and interim periods within those annual periods.
59527_13_ITEM7_P84_S3	The amendments should be applied retrospectively for all prior periods presented.
59527_13_ITEM7_P84_S4	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of ASU 2011-11 on the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM7_P85_S0	The Company's consolidated financial statements are based on the selection and application of significant accounting policies, which require management to make estimates and assumptions.
59527_13_ITEM7_P85_S1	These estimates and assumptions are reviewed periodically by management and compared to historical trends to determine the accuracy of estimates and assumptions used.
59527_13_ITEM7_P85_S2	If warranted, these estimates and assumptions may be changed as current trends are assessed and updated.
59527_13_ITEM7_P86_S0	Historically, the Company's estimates have been determined to be reasonable.
59527_13_ITEM7_P86_S1	No material changes to the Company's accounting policies were made during 2012 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P86_S2	The Company believes the following are some of the more critical judgment areas in the application of its accounting policies that affect its financial condition and results of operations.
59527_13_ITEM7_P87_S0	Legal and Tax Contingencies The Company, like other manufacturers, is subject from time to time to a variety of civil and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
59527_13_ITEM7_P87_S1	Such claims and litigation include, without limitation, product liability claims and health, safety and environmental claims, some of which relate to cases alleging asbestos induced illnesses.
59527_13_ITEM7_P87_S2	The costs associated with these claims are predominantly defense costs, which are recognized in the periods incurred.
59527_13_ITEM7_P87_S3	Insurance reimbursements mitigate these costs and, where reimbursements are probable, they are recognized in the applicable period.
59527_13_ITEM7_P88_S0	With respect to costs other than defense costs (i.e., for liability and/or settlement or other resolution), reserves are recorded when it is probable that the contingencies will have an unfavorable outcome.
59527_13_ITEM7_P88_S1	The Company accrues its best estimate of the probable costs, after a review of the facts with management and counsel and taking into account past experience.
59527_13_ITEM7_P88_S2	If an unfavorable outcome is determined to be reasonably possible but not probable, or if the amount of loss cannot be reasonably estimated, disclosure is provided for material claims or litigation.
59527_13_ITEM7_P89_S0	Many of the current cases are in differing procedural stages and information on the circumstances of each claimant, which forms the basis for judgments as to the validity or ultimate disposition of such actions, varies greatly.
59527_13_ITEM7_P89_S1	Therefore, in many situations a range of possible losses cannot be made.
59527_13_ITEM7_P89_S2	Reserves are adjusted as facts and circumstances change and related management assessments of the underlying merits and the likelihood of outcomes change.
59527_13_ITEM7_P89_S3	Moreover, reserves only cover identified and/or asserted claims.
59527_13_ITEM7_P89_S4	Future claims could, therefore, give rise to increases to such reserves.
59527_13_ITEM7_P90_S0	The Company is subject to taxation from U.S. federal, state, municipal and international jurisdictions.
59527_13_ITEM7_P91_S0	The calculation of current income tax expense is based on the best information available and involves significant management judgment.
59527_13_ITEM7_P91_S1	The actual income tax liability for each jurisdiction in any year can in some instances be ultimately determined several years after the financial statements are published.
59527_13_ITEM7_P91_S2	The Company maintains reserves for estimated income tax exposures for many jurisdictions.
59527_13_ITEM7_P91_S3	Exposures are settled primarily through the completion of audits within each individual tax jurisdiction or the closing of a statute of limitation.
59527_13_ITEM7_P91_S4	Exposures can also be affected by changes in applicable tax law or other factors, which may cause management to believe a revision of past estimates is appropriate.
59527_13_ITEM7_P91_S5	Management believes that an appropriate liability has been established for income tax exposures; however, actual results may materially differ from these estimates.
59527_13_ITEM7_P91_S6	See Note 12 to the Company's consolidated financial statements and "Item 3.
59527_13_ITEM7_P91_S7	Legal Proceedings" section of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for further discussion of tax contingencies.
59527_13_ITEM7_P92_S0	Translation of Foreign Currencies Asset and liability accounts are translated into U.S. dollars using exchange rates in effect at the dates of the Consolidated Balance Sheets; revenue and expense accounts are translated at average monthly exchange rates.
59527_13_ITEM7_P92_S1	Translation adjustments are reflected as a component of Total equity.
59527_13_ITEM7_P92_S2	For subsidiaries operating in highly inflationary economies, both historical and current exchange rates are used in translating balance sheet accounts, and translation adjustments are included in Net income.
59527_13_ITEM7_P93_S0	Foreign currency transaction losses are included in "Selling, general administrative expenses" and were $4,608 , $4,904 and $118 in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
59527_13_ITEM7_P94_S0	Venezuela Highly Inflationary Economy Venezuela is a highly inflationary economy under U.S. GAAP.
59527_13_ITEM7_P94_S1	As a result, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation are reported under highly inflationary accounting rules as of January 1, 2010.
59527_13_ITEM7_P95_S0	Under highly inflationary accounting, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation have been remeasured into the Company's reporting currency and exchange gains and losses from the re-measurement of monetary assets and liabilities are reflected in current earnings.
59527_13_ITEM7_P95_S1	In remeasuring the financial statements, the official exchange rate for non-essential goods of 4.3 (the "Non-Essential Rate") is used as this is the rate expected to be applicable to dividend repatriations.
59527_13_ITEM7_P95_S2	Future impacts to earnings of applying highly inflationary accounting for Venezuela on the Company's consolidated financial statements will be dependent upon movements in the applicable exchange rates between the bolivar and the U.S. dollar and the amount of monetary assets and liabilities included in the Company's Venezuelan operation's balance sheet.
59527_13_ITEM7_P95_S3	The bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position was $31,545 at December 31, 2012 and $6,826 at December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P95_S4	The increased exposure was due to the limited opportunities to convert bolivars into U.S. dollars.
59527_13_ITEM7_P96_S0	The Company's ability to effectively manage sales and profit levels in Venezuela will be impacted by several factors.
59527_13_ITEM7_P96_S1	These include, but are not limited to, the Company's ability to mitigate the effect of any potential devaluation and Venezuelan government price exchange controls.
59527_13_ITEM7_P97_S0	If in the future the Company were to convert bolivars at a rate other than the official exchange rate or the official exchange rate is revised, the Company may realize a loss to earnings.
59527_13_ITEM7_P97_S1	In 2010, the Company participated in Venezuelan sovereign debt offerings as a means of converting bolivars to U.S. dollars.
59527_13_ITEM7_P97_S2	The conversion of bolivars to U.S. dollars through Venezuelan sovereign debt offerings generated foreign currency transaction losses as the debt was purchased at the Non-Essential Rate and subsequently sold at a discount.
59527_13_ITEM7_P97_S3	During 2010, the Company acquired $7,672 of Venezuelan sovereign debt at the Non-Essential Rate, which was immediately sold at a discount for $6,022 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P98_S0	The sale of the Venezuelan sovereign debt resulted in a loss of $1,650 recognized in Selling, general administrative expenses.
59527_13_ITEM7_P98_S1	In 2012 and 2011, the Company was not successful in utilizing this vehicle as a means of converting bolivars to U.S. dollars.
59527_13_ITEM7_P98_S2	The devaluation of the bolivar and the change to the U.S. dollar as the functional currency resulted in a foreign currency transaction gain of $2,632 in "Selling, general administrative expenses" and higher "Cost of goods sold" of $5,755 due to the liquidation of inventory valued at the historical exchange rate for the year ended December 31, 2010.
59527_13_ITEM7_P99_S0	On February 8, 2013, the Venezuelan government announced the devaluation of its currency relative to the U.S. dollar.
59527_13_ITEM7_P99_S1	The Non-Essential Rate moved from 4.3 to 6.3 bolivars to one U.S. dollar.
59527_13_ITEM7_P99_S2	The devaluation of the bolivar is expected to result in a foreign currency transaction charge of approximately $8,500 in Selling, general administrative expenses.
59527_13_ITEM7_P99_S3	This charge will be recognized during the first quarter of 2013.
59527_13_ITEM7_P99_S4	The impact of selling inventories carried at the previous exchange rate is expected to decrease gross profit by approximately $4,000 in 2013.
59527_13_ITEM7_P99_S5	These charges will be recognized during the first half of 2013.
59527_13_ITEM7_P99_S6	The Company also expects that its Venezuelan subsidiary's results of operations will decrease significantly in 2013 due to the new exchange rate.
59527_13_ITEM7_P100_S0	Deferred Income Taxes Deferred income taxes are recognized at currently enacted tax rates for temporary differences between the financial reporting and income tax bases of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carry-forwards.
59527_13_ITEM7_P100_S1	The Company does not provide deferred income taxes on unremitted earnings of certain non-U.S. subsidiaries, which are deemed permanently reinvested.
59527_13_ITEM7_P100_S2	It is not practicable to calculate the deferred taxes associated with the remittance of these earnings.
59527_13_ITEM7_P100_S3	Deferred income taxes associated with earnings of $3,776 that are not expected to be permanently reinvested were not significant.
59527_13_ITEM7_P100_S4	At December 31, 2012 , the Company had approximately $170,175 of gross deferred tax assets related to deductible temporary differences and tax loss and credit carry-forwards which may reduce taxable income in future years.
59527_13_ITEM7_P101_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, the Company assesses whether it is more likely than not that a portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
59527_13_ITEM7_P101_S1	The Company considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities, tax planning strategies, and projected future taxable income in making this assessment.
59527_13_ITEM7_P101_S2	At December 31, 2012 , a valuation allowance of $38,799 was recorded against these deferred tax assets based on this assessment.
59527_13_ITEM7_P101_S3	The Company believes it is more likely than not that the tax benefit of the remaining net deferred tax assets will be realized.
59527_13_ITEM7_P101_S4	The amount of net deferred tax assets considered realizable could be increased or reduced in the future if the Company's assessment of future taxable income or tax planning strategies changes.
59527_13_ITEM7_P102_S0	Pensions The Company maintains a number of defined benefit and defined contribution plans to provide retirement benefits for employees.
59527_13_ITEM7_P102_S1	These plans are maintained and contributions are made in accordance with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ("ERISA"), local statutory law or as determined by the Board of Directors.
59527_13_ITEM7_P102_S2	The plans generally provide benefits based upon years of service and compensation.
59527_13_ITEM7_P102_S3	Pension plans are funded except for a domestic non-qualified pension plan for certain key employees and certain foreign plans.
59527_13_ITEM7_P102_S4	A substantial portion of the Company's pension amounts relates to its defined benefit plan in the United States.
59527_13_ITEM7_P103_S0	The fair value of plan assets is determined at December 31 of each year.
59527_13_ITEM7_P104_S0	A significant element in determining the Company's pension expense is the expected return on plan assets.
59527_13_ITEM7_P104_S1	At the end of each year, the expected return on plan assets is determined based on the weighted average expected return of the various asset classes in the plan's portfolio and the targeted allocation of plan assets.
59527_13_ITEM7_P104_S2	The asset class return is developed using historical asset return performance as well as current market conditions such as inflation, interest rates and equity market performance.
59527_13_ITEM7_P104_S3	The Company determined this rate to be 7.7% and 7.9% at December 31, 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
59527_13_ITEM7_P105_S0	The assumed long-term rate of return on assets is applied to the market value of plan assets.
59527_13_ITEM7_P105_S1	This produces the expected return on plan assets included in pension expense.
59527_13_ITEM7_P105_S2	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is deferred and amortized over the average remaining service period of active employees expected to receive benefits under the plan.
59527_13_ITEM7_P105_S3	The amortization of the net deferral of past losses will increase future pension expense.
59527_13_ITEM7_P106_S0	During 2012 , investment returns were 11.1% compared with a return of 4.1% in 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P106_S1	A 25 basis point change in the expected return on plan assets would increase or decrease pension expense by approximately $1,800 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P107_S0	Another significant element in determining the Company's pension expense is the discount rate for plan liabilities.
59527_13_ITEM7_P107_S1	To develop the discount rate assumption to be used, the Company refers to the yield derived from matching projected pension payments with maturities of a portfolio of available non-callable bonds rated AA- or better.
59527_13_ITEM7_P107_S2	The Company determined this rate to be 3.8% at December 31, 2012 and 4.2% at December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P107_S3	A 10 basis point change in the discount rate would increase or decrease pension expense by approximately $1,100 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P107_S4	Pension expense relating to the Company's defined benefit plans was $36,258 , $26,370 and $29,123 in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
59527_13_ITEM7_P107_S5	The Company expects 2013 defined benefit pension expense to increase by approximately $200 to $500 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P108_S0	The Accumulated other comprehensive loss, excluding tax effects, recognized on the Consolidated Balance Sheet was $417,967 as of December 31, 2012 and $408,000 as of December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P108_S1	The increase is primarily the result of an increase in actuarial losses.
59527_13_ITEM7_P108_S2	Actuarial losses arising during 2012 are primarily attributable to a lower discount rate.
59527_13_ITEM7_P109_S0	The Company made voluntary contributions to its U.S. defined benefit plans of $60,277 , $30,000 and $41,500 in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
59527_13_ITEM7_P109_S1	The Company expects to voluntarily contribute $103,000 to its U.S. plans in 2013 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P109_S2	Based on current pension funding rules, the Company does not anticipate that contributions to the plans would be required in 2013 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P110_S0	Inventories Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
59527_13_ITEM7_P110_S1	Fixed manufacturing overhead costs are allocated to inventory based on normal production capacity and abnormal manufacturing costs are recognized as period costs.
59527_13_ITEM7_P111_S0	For most domestic inventories, cost is determined principally by the last-in, first-out ("LIFO") method, and for non-U.S. inventories, cost is determined by the first-in, first-out ("FIFO") method.
59527_13_ITEM7_P112_S0	The valuation of LIFO inventories is made at the end of each year based on inventory levels and costs at that time.
59527_13_ITEM7_P112_S1	Accordingly, interim LIFO calculations are based on management's estimates of expected year-end inventory levels and costs.
59527_13_ITEM7_P112_S2	Actual year-end costs and inventory levels may differ from interim LIFO inventory valuations.
59527_13_ITEM7_P112_S3	The excess of current cost over LIFO cost was $72,173 at December 31, 2012 and $78,292 at December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM7_P113_S0	The Company reviews the net realizable value of inventory on an on-going basis, with consideration given to deterioration, obsolescence and other factors.
59527_13_ITEM7_P113_S1	If actual market conditions differ from those projected by management, and the Company's estimates prove to be inaccurate, write-downs of inventory values and adjustments to Cost of goods sold may be required.
59527_13_ITEM7_P114_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_13_ITEM7_P114_S1	The Company maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses from the failure of its customers to make required payments for products delivered.
59527_13_ITEM7_P114_S2	The Company estimates this allowance based on the age of the related receivable, knowledge of the financial condition of customers, review of historical receivables and reserve trends and other pertinent information.
59527_13_ITEM7_P114_S3	If the financial condition of customers deteriorates or an unfavorable trend in receivable collections is experienced in the future, additional allowances may be required.
59527_13_ITEM7_P115_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_13_ITEM7_P116_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company periodically evaluates whether current facts or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of its depreciable long-lived assets to be held and used may not be recoverable.
59527_13_ITEM7_P116_S1	If such circumstances are determined to exist, an estimate of undiscounted future cash flows produced by the long-lived asset, or the appropriate grouping of assets, is compared to the carrying value to determine whether impairment exists.
59527_13_ITEM7_P117_S0	If an asset is determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized to the extent that carrying value exceeds fair value.
59527_13_ITEM7_P118_S0	Fair value is measured based on quoted market prices in active markets, if available.
59527_13_ITEM7_P118_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, the estimate of fair value is based on various valuation techniques, including the discounted value of estimated future cash flows.
59527_13_ITEM7_P119_S0	Goodwill and Intangibles The Company performs an annual impairment test of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets in the fourth quarter using the same dates each year or more frequently if changes in circumstances or the occurrence of events indicate potential impairment.
59527_13_ITEM7_P119_S1	The fair value of each indefinite-lived intangible asset is compared to its carrying value and an impairment charge is recorded if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
59527_13_ITEM7_P120_S0	Goodwill is tested by comparing the fair value of each reporting unit with its carrying value.
59527_13_ITEM7_P120_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the implied value of goodwill is compared to its carrying value and impairment is recognized to the extent that the carrying value exceeds the implied fair value.
59527_13_ITEM7_P121_S0	Fair values are determined using established business valuation multiples and models developed by the Company that incorporate allocations of certain assets and cash flows among reporting units, estimates of market participant assumptions of future cash flows, future growth rates and the applicable discount rates to value estimated cash flows.
59527_13_ITEM7_P121_S1	Changes in economic and operating conditions impacting these assumptions could result in asset impairments in future periods.
59527_13_ITEM7_P121_S2	The fair value of goodwill for all of the Company's operating business units exceeded its carrying value by at least 10% as of the testing date during the fourth quarter of 2012.
59527_13_ITEM7_P121_S3	Key assumptions in estimating the reporting unit's fair value include assumed market participant assumptions of revenue growth, operating margins and the rate used to discount future cash flows.
59527_13_ITEM7_P121_S4	Actual revenue growth and operating margins below the assumed market participant assumptions or an increase in the discount rate would have a negative impact on the fair value of the reporting unit that could result in a goodwill impairment charge in a future period.
59527_13_ITEM7_P122_S0	The Company utilizes the Black-Scholes option pricing model for estimating fair values of options.
59527_13_ITEM7_P122_S1	The Black-Scholes model requires assumptions regarding the volatility of the Company's stock, the expected life of the stock award and the Company's dividend yield.
59527_13_ITEM7_P122_S2	The Company utilizes historical data in determining these assumptions.
59527_13_ITEM7_P122_S3	An increase or decrease in the assumptions or economic events outside of management's control could have a direct impact on the Black-Scholes model.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Included below is a sensitivity analysis based upon a hypothetical 10% weakening or strengthening in the U.S. dollar compared to foreign currency exchange rates at December 31, 2012 , a 10% change in commodity prices, and a 100 basis point increase in effective interest rates under the Company's current borrowing arrangements.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The contractual derivative and borrowing arrangements in effect at December 31, 2012 were compared to the hypothetical foreign exchange, commodity price, or interest rates in the sensitivity analysis to determine the effect on income before taxes, interest expense, or accumulated other comprehensive loss.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P1_S1	The analysis takes into consideration any offset that would result from changes in the value of the hedged asset or liability.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Foreign Currency Exchange Risk The Company enters into forward foreign exchange contracts principally to hedge the currency fluctuations in transactions denominated in foreign currencies, thereby limiting the Company's risk that would otherwise result from changes in exchange rates.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P2_S1	At December 31, 2012 , the Company hedged certain third-party and inter-company purchases and sales.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P2_S2	At December 31, 2012 , the Company had foreign exchange contracts with a notional value of approximately $39,597 .
59527_13_ITEM7A_P3_S0	At December 31, 2012 , a hypothetical 10% weakening of the U.S. dollar would not materially affect the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Commodity Price Risk From time to time, the Company uses various hedging arrangements to manage exposures to price risk from commodity purchases.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P4_S1	These hedging arrangements have the effect of locking in for specified periods the prices the Company will pay for the volume to which the hedge relates.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P5_S0	A hypothetical 10% adverse change in commodity prices on the Company's open commodity futures at December 31, 2012 would not materially affect the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Interest Rate Risk As of December 31, 2012 , the Company had no interest rate swaps outstanding.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P6_S1	Additionally, the Company had no outstanding borrowings under the Credit Agreement, therefore an interest rate increase would have no effect on interest expense.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The fair value of the Company's Cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2012 approximated carrying value.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P6_S3	The Company's financial instruments are subject to concentrations of credit risk.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P6_S4	The Company has minimized this risk by entering into investments with a number of major banks and financial institutions and investing in high-quality instruments.
59527_13_ITEM7A_P6_S5	The Company does not expect any counter-parties to fail to meet their obligations.

59527_13_ITEM15_P22_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc.
59527_13_ITEM15_P22_S1	We have audited Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries' internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2012 , based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
59527_13_ITEM15_P22_S2	Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries' management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management's Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting in Item 9A.
59527_13_ITEM15_P22_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company's internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
59527_13_ITEM15_P22_S4	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
59527_13_ITEM15_P22_S5	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
59527_13_ITEM15_P22_S6	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
59527_13_ITEM15_P22_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
59527_13_ITEM15_P23_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
59527_13_ITEM15_P23_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P23_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P23_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
59527_13_ITEM15_P24_S0	In our opinion, Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2012 , based on the COSO criteria.
59527_13_ITEM15_P24_S1	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2012 and 2011 , and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2012 of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries and our report dated February 22, 2013 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.

59527_13_ITEM15_P26_S0	See notes to these consolidated financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P27_S0	See notes to these consolidated financial statements.

59527_13_ITEM15_P31_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and its wholly-owned and majority-owned subsidiaries for which it has a controlling interest (the "Company") after elimination of all inter-company accounts, transactions and profits.
59527_13_ITEM15_P32_S0	General Information The Company is a manufacturer of welding, cutting and brazing products.
59527_13_ITEM15_P32_S1	Welding products include arc welding power sources, wire feeding systems, robotic welding packages, fume extraction equipment, consumable electrodes and fluxes.
59527_13_ITEM15_P32_S2	The Company's product offering also includes CNC plasma and oxy-fuel cutting systems, regulators and torches used in oxy-fuel welding, cutting and brazing and consumables used in the brazing and soldering alloys market.
59527_13_ITEM15_P33_S0	Translation of Foreign Currencies Asset and liability accounts are translated into U.S. dollars using exchange rates in effect at the dates of the Consolidated Balance Sheets; revenue and expense accounts are translated at average monthly exchange rates.
59527_13_ITEM15_P33_S1	Translation adjustments are reflected as a component of Total equity.
59527_13_ITEM15_P33_S2	For subsidiaries operating in highly inflationary economies, both historical and current exchange rates are used in translating balance sheet accounts, and translation adjustments are included in Net income.
59527_13_ITEM15_P34_S0	The translation of assets and liabilities originally denominated in foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is for consolidation purposes, and does not necessarily indicate that the Company could realize or settle the reported value of those assets and liabilities in U.S. dollars.
59527_13_ITEM15_P34_S1	Additionally, such a translation does not necessarily indicate that the Company could return or distribute the reported U.S. dollar value of the net equity of its foreign operations to shareholders.
59527_13_ITEM15_P34_S2	Foreign currency transaction losses are included in Selling, general administrative expenses and were $4,608 , $4,904 and $118 in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
59527_13_ITEM15_P35_S0	Venezuela Highly Inflationary Economy Venezuela is a highly inflationary economy under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP").
59527_13_ITEM15_P35_S1	As a result, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation are reported under highly inflationary accounting rules as of January 1, 2010.
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S0	Under highly inflationary accounting, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation have been remeasured into the Company's reporting currency and exchange gains and losses from the re-measurement of monetary assets and liabilities are reflected in current earnings.
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S1	In remeasuring the financial statements, the official exchange rate for non-essential goods of 4.3 bolivars to the U.S. dollar (the "Non-Essential Rate") is used as this is the rate expected to be applicable to dividend repatriations.
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S2	Future impacts to earnings of applying highly inflationary accounting for Venezuela on the Company's consolidated financial statements will be dependent upon movements in the applicable exchange rates between the bolivar and the U.S. dollar and the amount of monetary assets and liabilities included in the Company's Venezuelan operation's balance sheet.
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S3	The bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position was $31,545 at December 31, 2012 and $6,826 at December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S4	The increased exposure was due to the limited opportunities to convert bolivars into U.S. dollars.
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S5	In 2010, the Company participated in Venezuelan sovereign debt offerings as a means of converting bolivars to U.S. dollars.
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S6	The conversion of bolivars to U.S. dollars through Venezuelan sovereign debt offerings generated foreign currency transaction losses as the debt was purchased at the Non-Essential Rate and subsequently sold at a discount.
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S7	During 2010, the Company acquired $7,672 of Venezuelan sovereign debt at the Non-Essential Rate, which was immediately sold at a discount for $6,022 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S8	The sale of the Venezuelan sovereign debt resulted in a loss of $1,650 recognized in Selling, general and administrative expenses.
59527_13_ITEM15_P36_S9	The devaluation of the bolivar and the change to the U.S. dollar as the functional currency resulted in a foreign currency transaction gain of $2,632 in Selling, general administrative expenses and higher Cost of goods sold of $5,755 due to the liquidation of inventory valued at the historical exchange rate for the year ended December 31, 2010.
59527_13_ITEM15_P37_S0	On February 8, 2013, the Venezuelan government announced the devaluation of its currency relative to the U.S. dollar.
59527_13_ITEM15_P37_S1	The Non-Essential Rate moved from 4.3 to 6.3 bolivars to one U.S. dollar.
59527_13_ITEM15_P37_S2	The devaluation of the bolivar is expected to result in a foreign currency transaction charge of approximately $8,500 in Selling, general administrative expenses.
59527_13_ITEM15_P37_S3	This charge will be recognized during the first quarter of 2013.
59527_13_ITEM15_P38_S0	to decrease gross profit by approximately $4,000 in 2013.
59527_13_ITEM15_P38_S1	These charges will be recognized during the first half of 2013.
59527_13_ITEM15_P38_S2	The Company also expects that its Venezuelan subsidiary's results of operations will decrease significantly in 2013 due to the new exchange rate.
59527_13_ITEM15_P39_S0	The Company considers all highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.
59527_13_ITEM15_P39_S1	The Company maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses from the failure of its customers to make required payments for products delivered.
59527_13_ITEM15_P39_S2	The Company estimates this allowance based on the age of the related receivable, knowledge of the financial condition of customers, review of historical receivables and reserve trends and other pertinent information.
59527_13_ITEM15_P39_S3	If the financial condition of customers deteriorates or an unfavorable trend in receivable collections is experienced in the future, additional allowances may be required.
59527_13_ITEM15_P40_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_13_ITEM15_P41_S0	Inventories Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
59527_13_ITEM15_P41_S1	Fixed manufacturing overhead costs are allocated to inventory based on normal production capacity and abnormal manufacturing costs are recognized as period costs.
59527_13_ITEM15_P42_S0	For most domestic inventories, cost is determined principally by the last-in, first-out ("LIFO") method, and for non-U.S. inventories, cost is determined by the first-in, first-out ("FIFO") method.
59527_13_ITEM15_P43_S0	Reserves are maintained for estimated obsolescence or excess inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated market value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
59527_13_ITEM15_P44_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_13_ITEM15_P45_S0	Equity Investments Investments in businesses in which the Company does not have a controlling interest and holds between a 20% and 50% ownership interest are accounted for using the equity method of accounting on a one-month lag basis.
59527_13_ITEM15_P45_S1	The Company's 50% ownership interest in equity investments includes investments in Turkey and Chile.
59527_13_ITEM15_P45_S2	The amount of retained earnings that represents undistributed earnings of 50% or less owned equity investments was $15,034 at December 31, 2012 and $15,190 at December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P46_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment Property, plant and equipment are stated at cost and include improvements which significantly increase capacities or extend the useful lives of existing plant and equipment.
59527_13_ITEM15_P47_S0	Depreciation and amortization are computed using a straight-line method over useful lives ranging from three to 20 years for machinery, tools and equipment, and up to 50 years for buildings.
59527_13_ITEM15_P48_S0	Net gains or losses related to asset dispositions are recognized in earnings in the period in which dispositions occur.
59527_13_ITEM15_P48_S1	Routine maintenance, repairs and replacements are expensed as incurred.
59527_13_ITEM15_P49_S0	The Company capitalizes interest costs associated with long-term construction in progress.
59527_13_ITEM15_P50_S0	Goodwill and Intangibles Goodwill is recorded when the cost of acquired businesses exceeds the fair value of the identifiable net assets acquired.
59527_13_ITEM15_P50_S1	Intangible assets other than goodwill are recorded at fair value at the time acquired or at cost, if applicable.
59527_13_ITEM15_P50_S2	Intangible assets that do not have indefinite lives are amortized in line with the pattern in which the economic benefits of the intangible asset are consumed.
59527_13_ITEM15_P50_S3	If the pattern of economic benefit cannot be reliably determined, the intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line basis over the shorter of the legal or estimated life.
59527_13_ITEM15_P50_S4	Goodwill and indefinite-lived intangibles assets are not amortized, but are tested for impairment in the fourth quarter using the same dates each year or more frequently if changes in circumstances or the occurrence of events indicate potential impairment.
59527_13_ITEM15_P50_S5	The fair value of each indefinite-lived intangible asset is compared to its carrying value and an impairment charge is recorded if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
59527_13_ITEM15_P51_S0	Goodwill is tested by comparing the fair value of each reporting unit with its carrying value.
59527_13_ITEM15_P52_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company evaluates whether current facts or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of its depreciable long-lived assets to be held and used may not be recoverable.
59527_13_ITEM15_P52_S1	If such circumstances are determined to exist, an estimate of undiscounted future cash flows produced by the long-lived asset, or the appropriate grouping of assets, is compared to the carrying value to determine whether impairment exists.
59527_13_ITEM15_P53_S0	If an asset is determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized to the extent that carrying value exceeds fair value.
59527_13_ITEM15_P54_S0	Fair value is measured based on quoted market prices in active markets, if available.
59527_13_ITEM15_P54_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, the estimate of fair value is based on various valuation techniques, including the discounted value of estimated future cash flows.
59527_13_ITEM15_P55_S0	Fair Value Measurements Financial assets and liabilities, such as the Company's defined benefit pension plan assets and derivative contracts, are valued at fair value using the market and income valuation approaches.
59527_13_ITEM15_P55_S1	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
59527_13_ITEM15_P55_S2	The Company uses the market approach to value similar assets and liabilities in active markets and the income approach that consists of discounted cash flow models that take into account the present value of future cash flows under the terms of the contracts using current market information as of the reporting date.
59527_13_ITEM15_P56_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
59527_13_ITEM15_P57_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
59527_13_ITEM15_P58_S0	Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or other means.
59527_13_ITEM15_P59_S0	If the asset or liability has a specific (contractual) term, the Level 2 input must be observable for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
59527_13_ITEM15_P60_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair value measurement.
59527_13_ITEM15_P61_S0	The Company accrues for product warranty claims based on historical experience and the expected material and labor costs to provide warranty service.
59527_13_ITEM15_P61_S1	Warranty services are provided for periods up to three years from the date of sale.
59527_13_ITEM15_P62_S0	Revenue Recognition Substantially all of the Company's revenues are recognized when the risks and rewards of ownership and title to the product have transferred to the customer which generally occurs at point of shipment.
59527_13_ITEM15_P62_S1	The Company recognizes any discounts, credits, returns, rebates and incentive programs based on reasonable estimates as a reduction of Sales to arrive at Net sales at the same time the related revenue is recorded.
59527_13_ITEM15_P63_S0	For contracts accounted for under the percentage of completion method, revenue recognition is based upon the ratio of costs incurred to date compared with estimated total costs to complete.
59527_13_ITEM15_P63_S1	The cumulative impact of revisions to total estimated costs is reflected in the period of the change, including anticipated losses.
59527_13_ITEM15_P64_S0	Stock-Based Compensation Expense is recognized for all awards of stock-based compensation by allocating the aggregate grant date fair value over the vesting period.
59527_13_ITEM15_P64_S1	No expense is recognized for any stock options, restricted or deferred shares or restricted stock units ultimately forfeited because the recipients fail to meet vesting requirements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P64_S2	Common stock issuable upon the exercise of employee stock options is excluded from the calculation of diluted earnings per share when the calculation of option equivalent shares is anti-dilutive.
59527_13_ITEM15_P65_S0	Financial Instruments The Company uses forward contracts to hedge exposures to commodity prices and exchange rate fluctuations on certain purchase and sales transactions and balance sheet exposures.
59527_13_ITEM15_P65_S1	Contracts are generally written on a short-term basis but may cover exposures for up to two years and are not held for trading or speculative purposes.
59527_13_ITEM15_P66_S0	The Company uses interest rate swaps from time to time to hedge changes in the fair value of debt.
59527_13_ITEM15_P66_S1	The Company recognizes derivative instruments as either assets or liabilities at fair value.
59527_13_ITEM15_P66_S2	The accounting for changes in the fair value of derivative instruments depends on whether it has been designated and qualifies as part of a hedging relationship and on the type of hedging relationship.
59527_13_ITEM15_P66_S3	For derivative instruments that qualify as a fair value hedge (i.e., hedging the exposure to changes in the fair value of an asset or a liability), the gain or loss on the derivative instrument, as well as the offsetting loss or gain on the hedged item are recognized in earnings.
59527_13_ITEM15_P66_S4	For derivative instruments that qualify as a cash flow hedge (i.e., hedging the exposure to variability in expected future cash flows), the effective portion of the unrealized gain or loss on the derivative instrument is reported as a component of "Accumulated other comprehensive loss" with offsetting amounts recorded as "Other current assets," "Other non-current assets," "Other current liabilities" or "Other long-term liabilities" depending on the position and the duration of the contract.
59527_13_ITEM15_P67_S0	At settlement, the realized gain or loss is reflected in earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings.
59527_13_ITEM15_P67_S1	Any remaining gain or loss on the derivative instrument is recognized in earnings.
59527_13_ITEM15_P67_S2	For derivative instruments not designated as hedges, the gain or loss from changes in the fair value of the instruments is recognized in earnings.
59527_13_ITEM15_P68_S0	The Company does not hedge its net investments in foreign subsidiaries.
59527_13_ITEM15_P69_S0	Advertising Costs Advertising costs are charged to "Selling, general administrative expenses" as incurred and totaled $12,376 , $11,269 and $9,222 in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
59527_13_ITEM15_P69_S1	Research and Development Research and development costs are charged to "Selling, general administrative expenses" as incurred and totaled $37,305 , $32,834 and $29,489 in 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
59527_13_ITEM15_P70_S0	Bonus Included in "Selling, general administrative expenses" are the costs related to the Company's discretionary employee bonus programs, which for certain U.S.- based employees are net of hospitalization costs.
59527_13_ITEM15_P70_S1	Bonus costs were $124,947 in 2012 , $104,361 in 2011 and $73,197 in 2010 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P71_S0	Income Taxes Deferred income taxes are recognized at currently enacted tax rates for temporary differences between the financial reporting and income tax basis of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carry-forwards.
59527_13_ITEM15_P72_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, the Company assesses whether it is more likely than not that a portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
59527_13_ITEM15_P73_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions in certain circumstances that affect the amounts reported in the accompanying consolidated financial statements and notes.
59527_13_ITEM15_P73_S1	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
59527_13_ITEM15_P74_S0	Reclassification Certain reclassifications have been made to prior year financial statements to conform to current year classifications.
59527_13_ITEM15_P74_S1	New Accounting Pronouncements New Accounting Standards Adopted:
59527_13_ITEM15_P75_S0	ASU 2011-08 provides an entity the option to first assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events or circumstance leads to the determination that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount.
59527_13_ITEM15_P75_S1	If the entity determines it is not more likely than not that the fair value is less than the carrying amount, then performing the two-step impairment test is unnecessary.
59527_13_ITEM15_P75_S2	However, if the entity concludes otherwise, it is required to perform the first step of the two-step impairment test.
59527_13_ITEM15_P75_S3	The amendments are effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
59527_13_ITEM15_P75_S4	ASU 2011-08 was adopted by the Company on January 1, 2012 and did not have a significant impact on the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P76_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-05, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Presentation of Comprehensive Income.
59527_13_ITEM15_P76_S1	This update provides amendments to Accounting Standards Codification ( ASC ) Topic 220, Comprehensive Income.
59527_13_ITEM15_P77_S0	ASU 2011-05 provides an entity the option to present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income and the components of other comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement of comprehensive income or in two separate but consecutive statements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P77_S1	Under both options, an entity is required to present each component of net income along with total net income, each component of other comprehensive income along with a total for other comprehensive income and a total amount for comprehensive income.
59527_13_ITEM15_P77_S2	Further, ASU 2011-05 requires the presentation on the face of the financial statements items that are reclassified from other comprehensive income to net income in the statement(s) where the components of net income and the components of other comprehensive income are presented.
59527_13_ITEM15_P77_S3	The amendment to present reclassification adjustments was deferred when the FASB issued ASU 2011-12.
59527_13_ITEM15_P78_S0	ASU 2011-05 should be applied retrospectively and is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2011.
59527_13_ITEM15_P78_S1	The Company adopted ASU 2011-05, excluding deferred portions, on January 1, 2012.
59527_13_ITEM15_P78_S2	Refer to the consolidated financial statements herein.
59527_13_ITEM15_P79_S0	ASU 2011-04 amends ASC Topic 820, resulting in common fair value measurement and disclosure requirements in GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards ("IFRS").
59527_13_ITEM15_P79_S1	Consequently, the amendments change the wording used to describe many of the requirements in GAAP for measuring fair value and for disclosing information about fair value measurements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P79_S2	These amendments are to be applied prospectively and are effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2011.
59527_13_ITEM15_P79_S3	ASU 2011-04 was adopted by the Company on January 1, 2012 and did not have a significant impact on the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P79_S4	New Accounting Standards to be Adopted:
59527_13_ITEM15_P80_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-02, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Reporting of Amounts Reclassified Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income.
59527_13_ITEM15_P80_S1	ASU 2013-02 requires an entity to provide information about the amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by component.
59527_13_ITEM15_P80_S2	In addition, an entity is required to present, either on the face of the statement where net income is presented or in the notes, significant amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by the respective line items of net income but only if the amount reclassified is required under U.S. GAAP to be reclassified to net income in its entirety in the same reporting period.
59527_13_ITEM15_P80_S3	For other amounts, an entity is required to cross-reference to other disclosures required under U.S. GAAP that provide additional detail about those amounts.
59527_13_ITEM15_P80_S4	The amendments are effective prospectively for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2012.
59527_13_ITEM15_P80_S5	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of ASU 2013-02 on the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P81_S0	In July 2012, the FASB issued ASU No. 2012-02, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Testing Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets for Impairment.
59527_13_ITEM15_P81_S1	ASU 2012-02 permits an entity first to assess qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that an indefinite-lived intangible asset is impaired as a basis for determining whether it is necessary to perform the quantitative impairment test in accordance with Subtopic 350-30, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other - General Intangibles Other than Goodwill .
59527_13_ITEM15_P82_S0	The more-likely-than-not threshold is defined as having a likelihood of more than 50 percent.
59527_13_ITEM15_P82_S1	In accordance with this update, an entity will have an option not to calculate annually the fair value of an indefinite-lived intangible asset if the entity determines that it is not more likely than not that the asset is impaired.
59527_13_ITEM15_P82_S2	The amendments are effective for annual and interim impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after September 15, 2012.
59527_13_ITEM15_P83_S0	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of ASU 2012-02 on the Company's financial statements.
59527_13_ITEM15_P84_S0	ASU 2011-11 requires an entity to disclose information about financial instruments and derivative instruments that are subject to offsetting, master netting or other similar arrangements, to illustrate the effect or potential effect of those arrangements on the Company's financial position.
59527_13_ITEM15_P84_S1	In January 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-01, Balance Sheet (Topic 210): Clarifying the Scope of Disclosures about Offsetting Assets and Liabilities , which clarifies the scope of ASU 2011-11.
59527_13_ITEM15_P84_S2	The amendments are effective for annual periods beginning on or after January 1, 2013 and interim periods within those annual periods.
59527_13_ITEM15_P84_S3	The amendments should be applied retrospectively for all prior periods presented.
59527_13_ITEM15_P84_S4	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of ASU 2011-11 on the Company's financial statements.

59527_13_ITEM15_P87_S0	NOTE 3 ACQUISITIONS On December 31, 2012, the Company completed the acquisition of the privately-held automated systems and tooling manufacturer, Tennessee Rand, Inc. ("Tenn Rand").
59527_13_ITEM15_P87_S1	Tenn Rand, based in Chattanooga, Tennessee, is a leader in the design and manufacture of tooling and robotic systems for welding applications.
59527_13_ITEM15_P87_S2	The acquisition added tool design, system building and machining capabilities that will enable the Company to further expand its welding automation business.
59527_13_ITEM15_P87_S3	Annual sales for Tenn Rand in 2012 were approximately $35,000 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P87_S4	On November 13, 2012, the Company completed the acquisition of the Kaliburn, Burny and Cleveland Motion Control businesses (collectively, "Kaliburn") from ITT Corporation.
59527_13_ITEM15_P88_S0	Kaliburn, headquartered in Ladson, South Carolina, is a designer and manufacturer of shape cutting solutions, producer of shape cutting control systems and manufacturer of web tension transducers and engineered machine systems.
59527_13_ITEM15_P88_S1	The acquisitions added to the Company's cutting business portfolio.
59527_13_ITEM15_P88_S2	Annual sales for Kaliburn at the date of acquisition were approximately $36,000 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P89_S0	On May 17, 2012, the Company completed the acquisition of Wayne Trail Technologies, Inc. ( Wayne Trail ).
59527_13_ITEM15_P90_S0	Loramie, Ohio, is a manufacturer of automated systems and tooling, serving a wide range of applications in the metal processing market.
59527_13_ITEM15_P90_S1	The acquisition added to the Company s welding and automated solutions portfolio.
59527_13_ITEM15_P90_S2	Annual sales for Wayne Trail at the date of acquisition were approximately $50,000 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P91_S0	On March 6, 2012, the Company completed the acquisition of Weartech International, Inc. ( Weartech ).
59527_13_ITEM15_P91_S1	Weartech, based in Anaheim, California, is a producer of cobalt-based hard facing and wear-resistant welding consumables.
59527_13_ITEM15_P91_S2	The acquisition added to the Company s consumables portfolio.
59527_13_ITEM15_P91_S3	Sales for Weartech during 2011 were approximately $40,000 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P92_S0	The Company acquired Tenn Rand, Kaliburn, Wayne Trail and Weartech for approxima tely $143,504 in cash, net of cash acquired, and assumed debt.
59527_13_ITEM15_P92_S1	The fair value of net assets acquired was $75,764 , resulting in goodwill of $67,740 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P93_S0	Some of the purchase price allocations are preliminary and subject to final opening balance sheet adjustments.

59527_13_ITEM15_P95_S0	Techalloy, based in Baltimore, Maryland, was a privately-held manufacturer of nickel alloy and stainless steel welding consumables.
59527_13_ITEM15_P95_S1	The acquisition added to the Company's consumables portfolio.
59527_13_ITEM15_P95_S2	Annual sales for Techalloy at the date of acquisition were approximately $70,000 .

59527_13_ITEM15_P96_S1	Torchmate, based in Reno, Nevada, provides a wide selection of computer numeric controlled plasma cutter and oxy-fuel cutting systems.
59527_13_ITEM15_P96_S2	The acquisition added to the Company's plasma and oxy-fuel cutting product offering.
59527_13_ITEM15_P96_S3	Annual sales for Torchmate at the date of acquisition were approximately $13,000 .

59527_13_ITEM15_P97_S1	Severstal is a leading manufacturer of welding consumables in Russia and was a subsidiary of OAO Severstal, one of the world's leading vertically integrated steel and mining companies.
59527_13_ITEM15_P97_S2	This acquisition expanded the Company's capacity and distribution channels in Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States ("CIS").
59527_13_ITEM15_P97_S3	Sales for Severstal during 2010 were approximately $40,000 .

59527_13_ITEM15_P98_S1	Arc Products was a privately-held manufacturer of orbital welding systems and welding automation components based in Southern California.
59527_13_ITEM15_P98_S2	Orbital welding systems are designed to automatically weld pipe and tube in difficult to access locations and for mission-critical applications requiring high weld integrity and sophisticated quality monitoring capabilities.
59527_13_ITEM15_P98_S3	The acquisition will complement the Company's ability to serve global customers in the nuclear, power generation and process industries worldwide.
59527_13_ITEM15_P99_S0	Sales for Arc Products during 2010 were not significant .

59527_13_ITEM15_P102_S0	The Company performs an annual impairment test of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets in the fourth quarter using the same dates each year or more frequently if changes in circumstances or the occurrence of events indicate potential impairment.
59527_13_ITEM15_P102_S1	The fair value of each indefinite-lived intangible asset is compared to its carrying value and an impairment charge is recorded if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
59527_13_ITEM15_P103_S0	Goodwill is tested by comparing the fair value of each reporting unit with its carrying value.
59527_13_ITEM15_P103_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the implied value of goodwill is compared to its carrying value and impairment is recognized to the extent that the carrying value exceeds the implied fair value.
59527_13_ITEM15_P104_S0	Fair values are determined using established business valuation multiples and models developed by the Company that incorporate allocations of certain assets and cash flows among reporting units, estimates of market participant assumptions of future cash flows, future growth rates and the applicable discount rates to value estimated cash flows.
59527_13_ITEM15_P104_S1	Changes in economic and operating conditions impacting these assumptions could result in asset impairments in future periods.
59527_13_ITEM15_P104_S2	The Company's annual impairment test of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets in 2012 resulted in no impairment loss being recognized.
59527_13_ITEM15_P104_S3	The changes in the carrying amount of goodwill by reportable segment for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011 were as follows:
59527_13_ITEM15_P105_S0	Additions to goodwill primarily reflect goodwill recognized in the acquisitions of Weartech, Wayne Trail, Kaliburn and Tenn Rand in 2012 and the acquisitions of Arc Products, Severstal, Torchmate and Techalloy in 2011 (see Note 3).
59527_13_ITEM15_P105_S1	Reductions to goodwill result from the tax benefit attributable to the amortization of tax deductible goodwill in excess of goodwill recorded for financial reporting purposes.

59527_13_ITEM15_P108_S0	The Company's primary business is the design and manufacture of arc welding and cutting products, manufacturing a broad line of arc welding equipment, consumable welding products and other welding and cutting products.
59527_13_ITEM15_P108_S1	The Company also has a leading global position in the brazing and soldering alloys market.
59527_13_ITEM15_P109_S0	The Company has aligned its business units into five operating segments to enhance the utilization of the Company's worldwide resources and global end user and sourcing initiatives.
59527_13_ITEM15_P109_S1	The operating segments consist of North America Welding, Europe Welding, Asia Pacific Welding, South America Welding and The Harris Products Group.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S0	The North America Welding segment includes welding operations in the United States, Canada and Mexico.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S1	The Europe Welding segment includes welding operations in Europe, Russia, Africa and the Middle East.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S2	The other two welding segments include welding operations in Asia Pacific and South America, respectively.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S3	The fifth segment, The Harris Products Group, includes the Company's global cutting, soldering and brazing businesses as well as the retail business in the United States.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S4	Segment performance is measured and resources are allocated based on a number of factors, the primary profit measure being earnings before interest and income taxes ("EBIT"), as adjusted.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S5	Segment EBIT is adjusted for special items as determined by management such as the impact of rationalization activities, certain asset impairment charges and gains or losses on disposals of assets.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S6	The accounting principles applied at the operating segment level are generally the same as those applied at the consolidated financial statement level with the exception of LIFO.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S7	Segment assets include inventories measured on a FIFO basis while consolidated inventories are reported on a LIFO basis.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S8	Segment and consolidated income before interest and income taxes are reported on a LIFO basis.
59527_13_ITEM15_P110_S9	At December 31, 2012 , 2011 and 2010 , approximately 34% , 31% and 30% , respectively, of total inventories were valued using the LIFO method.
59527_13_ITEM15_P111_S0	LIFO is used for certain domestic inventories included in the North America Welding segment.
59527_13_ITEM15_P111_S1	Inter-segment sales are recorded at agreed upon prices that approximate arm's length prices and are eliminated in consolidation.
59527_13_ITEM15_P111_S2	Corporate-level expenses are allocated to the operating segments on a basis that management believes to be reasonable.

59527_13_ITEM15_P122_S4	Since considerable judgment is required in interpreting market information, the fair value of the debt is not necessarily the amount which could be realized in a current market exchange.

59527_13_ITEM15_P183_S0	In July 2012, the Company received a Notice of Reassessment from the Canada Revenue Agency (the CRA ) for 2004 to 2011, which would disallow the deductibility of inter-company dividends.
59527_13_ITEM15_P183_S1	These adjustments would increase Canadian federal and provincial tax due by $62,120 plus approximately $17,156 of interest, net of tax.
59527_13_ITEM15_P184_S0	The Company disagrees with the position taken by the CRA and believes it is without merit.
59527_13_ITEM15_P184_S1	The Company will vigorously contest the assessment through the Tax Court of Canada.
59527_13_ITEM15_P184_S2	A trial date has not yet been scheduled.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S0	In connection with the litigation process, the Company is required to deposit no less than one-half of the tax and interest assessed by the CRA.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S1	The Company has elected to deposit the entire amount of the dispute in order to suspend the continuing accrual of a 5% interest charge.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S2	Additionally, deposited amounts will earn interest of approximately 1% due upon a favorable outcome.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S3	A deposit was made and is recorded as a non-current asset valued at $89,220 as of December 31, 2012 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S4	Any Canadian tax ultimately due will be creditable in the parent company's U.S. federal tax return.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S5	The Company expects to be able to utilize the full amount of foreign tax credits generated in the statutorily allowed carry-back and carry-forward periods.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S6	Accordingly, should the Company not prevail in this dispute, the income statement charge will approximate the deficiency interest, net of tax.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S7	The Company believes it will prevail on the merits of the tax position.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S8	In accordance with prescribed recognition and measurement thresholds, no income tax accrual has been made for any uncertain tax positions related to the CRA reassessment.
59527_13_ITEM15_P185_S9	An unfavorable resolution of this matter could have a material effect on the Company's financial statements in the quarter in which a judgment is reached.
59527_13_ITEM15_P186_S0	DERIVATIVES The Company uses derivatives to manage exposures to currency exchange rates, interest rates and commodity prices arising in the normal course of business.
59527_13_ITEM15_P186_S1	Derivative contracts to hedge currency and commodity exposures are generally written on a short-term basis but may cover exposures for up to two years while interest rate contracts may cover longer periods consistent with the terms of the underlying debt.
59527_13_ITEM15_P186_S2	The Company does not enter into derivatives for trading or speculative purposes.
59527_13_ITEM15_P186_S3	All derivatives are recognized at fair value on the Company's Consolidated Balance Sheets.
59527_13_ITEM15_P186_S4	The accounting for gains and losses resulting from changes in fair value depends on the use of the derivative and whether it is designated and qualifies for hedge accounting.
59527_13_ITEM15_P186_S5	The Company formally documents the relationship of the hedge with the hedged item as well as the risk-management strategy for all designated hedges.
59527_13_ITEM15_P187_S0	Both at inception and on an ongoing basis, the hedging instrument is assessed as to its effectiveness, when applicable.
59527_13_ITEM15_P188_S0	underlying hedged transaction is no longer likely to occur, or the derivative is terminated, hedge accounting is discontinued.
59527_13_ITEM15_P189_S0	The cash flows from settled derivative contracts are recognized in operating activities in the Company's Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
59527_13_ITEM15_P189_S1	Hedge ineffectiveness was immaterial for the three years ended December 31, 2012.
59527_13_ITEM15_P190_S0	The Company is subject to the credit risk of the counterparties to derivative instruments.
59527_13_ITEM15_P190_S1	Counterparties include a number of major banks and financial institutions.
59527_13_ITEM15_P190_S2	The Company manages individual counterparty exposure by monitoring the credit rating of the counterparty and the size of financial commitments and exposures between the Company and the counterparty.
59527_13_ITEM15_P190_S3	None of the concentrations of risk with any individual counterparty was considered significant at December 31, 2012 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P191_S0	The Company does not expect any counterparties to fail to meet their obligations.

59527_13_ITEM15_P203_S4	The fair value of the contingent consideration is a Level 3 valuation and fair valued using a probability weighted discounted cash flow analysis.
59527_13_ITEM15_P203_S5	The discounted cash flow utilized weighted average inputs, including a risk based discount rate of 9.7% and a compounded annual revenue growth rate of 33.7% .
59527_13_ITEM15_P203_S6	The discount rate was determined using discount rates of 3.5% reflective of the Company's cost of debt and 14.1% as a risk adjusted cost of capital and the compounded annual revenue growth rate was determined using various scenarios with growth ranging from remaining relatively flat to growth rates of up to 66.2% .
59527_13_ITEM15_P204_S0	The deferred compensation liability is the Company's obligation under its executive deferred compensation plan.
59527_13_ITEM15_P204_S1	The Company measures the fair value of the liability using the market values of the participants' underlying investment fund elections.
59527_13_ITEM15_P205_S0	The Company has various financial instruments, including cash and cash equivalents, short-and long-term debt and forward contracts.
59527_13_ITEM15_P205_S1	While these financial instruments are subject to concentrations of credit risk, the Company has minimized this risk by entering into arrangements with a number of major banks and financial institutions and investing in several high-quality instruments.
59527_13_ITEM15_P205_S2	The Company does not expect any counterparties to fail to meet their obligations.
59527_13_ITEM15_P206_S0	The fair value of "Cash and cash equivalents," "Accounts receivable," "Amounts due banks" and "Trade accounts payable" approximated book value due to the short-term nature of these instruments at both December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P206_S1	See Note 8 for the fair value estimate of debt.
59527_13_ITEM15_P206_S2	NOTE 15 INVENTORY For most domestic inventories, cost is determined principally by the LIFO method, and for non-U.S. inventories, cost is determined by the FIFO method.
59527_13_ITEM15_P207_S0	The valuation of LIFO inventories is made at the end of each year based on inventory levels and costs at that time.
59527_13_ITEM15_P207_S1	Accordingly, interim LIFO calculations are based on management's estimates of expected year-end inventory levels and costs.
59527_13_ITEM15_P207_S2	Because these estimates are subject to many factors beyond management's control, annual results may differ from interim results as they are subject to the final year-end LIFO inventory valuation.
59527_13_ITEM15_P207_S3	At December 31, 2012 and 2011 , approximately 34% and 31% , respectively, of total inventories were valued using the LIFO method.
59527_13_ITEM15_P207_S4	The excess of current cost over LIFO cost was $72,173 at December 31, 2012 and $78,292 at December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P208_S0	The Company leases sales offices, warehouses and distribution centers, transportation equipment, office equipment and data processing equipment.
59527_13_ITEM15_P208_S1	Such leases, some of which are noncancelable and, in many cases, include renewals, expire at various dates.
59527_13_ITEM15_P208_S2	The Company pays most insurance, maintenance and taxes relating to leased assets.
59527_13_ITEM15_P208_S3	Rental expense was $17,751 in 2012 , $15,221 in 2011 and $14,155 in 2010 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P208_S4	At December 31, 2012 , total future minimum lease payments for noncancelable operating leases were $12,624 in 2013 , $9,385 in 2014 , $6,872 in 2015 , $5,695 in 2016 , $4,561 in 2017 and $7,082 thereafter.

59527_13_ITEM15_P209_S0	NOTE 17 CONTINGENCIES The Company, like other manufacturers, is subject from time to time to a variety of civil and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
59527_13_ITEM15_P209_S1	Such claims and litigation include, without limitation, product liability claims and health, safety and environmental claims, some of which relate to cases alleging asbestos induced illnesses.
59527_13_ITEM15_P209_S2	The claimants in the asbestos cases seek compensatory and punitive damages, in most cases for unspecified amounts.
59527_13_ITEM15_P209_S3	The Company believes it has meritorious defenses to these claims and intends to contest such suits vigorously.
59527_13_ITEM15_P210_S0	The Company's accrual for contingent liabilities was $5,636 as of December 31, 2012 and $11,312 as of December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P210_S1	The Company also recognized an asset for recoveries from insurance carriers related to the insured claims outstanding of $1,311 as of December 31, 2012 and $4,516 as of December 31, 2011 .
59527_13_ITEM15_P210_S2	The decrease in the accrual for contingent liabilities is primarily due to a payment made in conjunction with the agreement entered into in January 2012 that provides for the dismissal with prejudice of substantially all of the pending manganese claims.
59527_13_ITEM15_P211_S0	The decrease in the asset for recoveries from insurance carriers reflects the collection of insurance receivables.
59527_13_ITEM15_P211_S1	The Company accrues its best estimate of the probable costs, after a review of the facts with management and counsel and taking into account past experience.
59527_13_ITEM15_P211_S2	If an unfavorable outcome is determined to be reasonably possible but not probable, or if the amount of loss cannot be reasonably estimated, disclosure is provided for material claims or litigation.
59527_13_ITEM15_P212_S0	Many of the current cases are in differing procedural stages and information on the circumstances of each claimant, which forms the basis for judgments as to the validity or ultimate disposition of such actions, varies greatly.
59527_13_ITEM15_P212_S1	Therefore, in many situations a range of possible losses cannot be made.
59527_13_ITEM15_P212_S2	Reserves are adjusted as facts and circumstances change and related management assessments of the underlying merits and the likelihood of outcomes change.
59527_13_ITEM15_P212_S3	Moreover, reserves only cover identified and/or asserted claims.
59527_13_ITEM15_P212_S4	Future claims could, therefore, give rise to increases to such reserves.
59527_13_ITEM15_P212_S5	Based on the Company's historical experience in litigating product liability claims, including a significant number of dismissals, summary judgments and defense verdicts in many cases and immaterial settlement amounts, as well as the Company's current assessment of the underlying merits of the claims and applicable insurance, the Company believes resolution of these claims and proceedings, individually or in the aggregate, will not have a material effect on the Company's consolidated financial statements.

59527_14_ITEM1_P10_S2	Any purported transfer or encumbrance in violation of the provisions of this Section 3 shall be void, and the other party to any such purported transaction shall not obtain any rights to or interest in such RSUs or the underlying Common Shares.
