59527_15_ITEM7_P58_S0	Product Liability Costs Product liability costs have historically been significant particularly with respect to asbestos claims.
59527_15_ITEM7_P58_S1	Costs incurred are volatile and are largely related to trial activity.
59527_15_ITEM7_P58_S2	The costs associated with these claims are predominantly defense costs which are recognized in the periods incurred.
59527_15_ITEM7_P58_S3	The long-term impact of the asbestos loss contingency, in the aggregate, on operating results, operating cash flows and access to capital markets is difficult to assess, particularly since claims are in many different stages of development and the Company benefits significantly from cost sharing with co-defendants and insurance carriers.
59527_15_ITEM7_P58_S4	Moreover, the Company has been largely successful to date in its defense of these claims.
59527_15_ITEM7_P59_S0	The Company utilizes letters of credit to back certain payment and performance obligations.
59527_15_ITEM7_P59_S1	Letters of credit are subject to limits based on amounts outstanding under the Company's Credit Agreement.
59527_15_ITEM7_P60_S0	New Accounting Pronouncements Refer to Note 1 to the consolidated financial statements for a discussion of new accounting pronouncements.
59527_15_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company's consolidated financial statements are based on the selection and application of significant accounting policies, which require management to make estimates and assumptions.
59527_15_ITEM7_P61_S1	These estimates and assumptions are reviewed periodically by management and compared to historical trends to determine the accuracy of estimates and assumptions used.
59527_15_ITEM7_P61_S2	If warranted, these estimates and assumptions may be changed as current trends are assessed and updated.
59527_15_ITEM7_P62_S0	Historically, the Company's estimates have been determined to be reasonable.
59527_15_ITEM7_P62_S1	No material changes to the Company's accounting policies were made during 2014 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P62_S2	The Company believes the following accounting policies are some of the more critical judgment areas affecting its financial condition and results of operations.
59527_15_ITEM7_P63_S0	Legal and Tax Contingencies The Company, like other manufacturers, is subject from time to time to a variety of civil and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
59527_15_ITEM7_P63_S1	Such claims and litigation include, without limitation, product liability claims, regulatory claims and health, safety and environmental claims, some of which relate to cases alleging asbestos induced illnesses.
59527_15_ITEM7_P63_S2	The costs associated with these claims are predominantly defense costs, which are recognized in the periods incurred.
59527_15_ITEM7_P63_S3	Insurance reimbursements mitigate these costs and, where reimbursements are probable, they are recognized in the applicable period.
59527_15_ITEM7_P64_S0	With respect to costs other than defense costs (i.e., for liability and/or settlement or other resolution), reserves are recorded when it is probable that the contingencies will have an unfavorable outcome.
59527_15_ITEM7_P64_S1	The Company accrues its best estimate of the probable costs, after a review of the facts with management and counsel and taking into account past experience.
59527_15_ITEM7_P64_S2	If an unfavorable outcome is determined to be reasonably possible but not probable, or if the amount of loss cannot be reasonably estimated, disclosure is provided for material claims or litigation.
59527_15_ITEM7_P65_S0	Many of the current cases are in differing procedural stages and information on the circumstances of each claimant, which forms the basis for judgments as to the validity or ultimate disposition of such actions, varies greatly.
59527_15_ITEM7_P65_S1	Therefore, in many situations a range of possible losses cannot be made.
59527_15_ITEM7_P65_S2	Reserves are adjusted as facts and circumstances change and related management assessments of the underlying merits and the likelihood of outcomes change.
59527_15_ITEM7_P65_S3	Moreover, reserves only cover identified and/or asserted claims.
59527_15_ITEM7_P65_S4	Future claims could, therefore, give rise to increases to such reserves.
59527_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	The Company is subject to taxation from U.S. federal, state, municipal and international jurisdictions.
59527_15_ITEM7_P67_S0	The calculation of current income tax expense is based on the best information available and involves significant management judgment.
59527_15_ITEM7_P67_S1	The actual income tax liability for each jurisdiction in any year can in some instances be ultimately determined several years after the financial statements are published.
59527_15_ITEM7_P67_S2	The Company maintains reserves for estimated income tax exposures for many jurisdictions.
59527_15_ITEM7_P67_S3	Exposures are settled primarily through the completion of audits within each individual tax jurisdiction or the closing of a statute of limitation.
59527_15_ITEM7_P67_S4	Exposures can also be affected by changes in applicable tax law or other factors, which may cause management to believe a revision of past estimates is appropriate.
59527_15_ITEM7_P67_S5	Management believes that an appropriate liability has been established for income tax exposures; however, actual results may materially differ from these estimates.
59527_15_ITEM7_P67_S6	See Note 12 to the Company's consolidated financial statements for further discussion of tax contingencies.
59527_15_ITEM7_P68_S0	Translation of Foreign Currencies Asset and liability accounts are translated into U.S. dollars using exchange rates in effect at the dates of the Consolidated Balance Sheets; revenue and expense accounts are translated at average monthly exchange rates.
59527_15_ITEM7_P68_S1	Translation adjustments are reflected as a component of Total equity.
59527_15_ITEM7_P68_S2	For subsidiaries operating in highly inflationary economies, both historical and current exchange rates are used in translating balance sheet accounts and translation adjustments are included in Net income.
59527_15_ITEM7_P69_S0	Foreign currency transaction losses are included in Selling, general administrative expenses and were $22,351 , $7,759 and $4,608 in 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
59527_15_ITEM7_P70_S0	Venezuela Highly Inflationary Economy Venezuela is a highly inflationary economy under U.S. GAAP.
59527_15_ITEM7_P70_S1	As a result, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation are reported under highly inflationary accounting rules as of January 1, 2010.
59527_15_ITEM7_P71_S0	Under highly inflationary accounting, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation have been remeasured into the Company's reporting currency and exchange gains and losses from the re-measurement of monetary assets and liabilities are reflected in current earnings.
59527_15_ITEM7_P72_S0	On February 8, 2013, the Venezuelan government announced the devaluation of its currency relative to the U.S. dollar.
59527_15_ITEM7_P72_S1	Effective February 13, 2013 the official rate moved from 4.3 to 6.3 bolivars to the U.S. dollar.
59527_15_ITEM7_P72_S2	In 2013, the devaluation of the bolivar resulted in a foreign currency transaction loss of $8,081 in Selling, general administrative expenses and higher Cost of goods sold of $4,117 due to the liquidation of inventory valued at the historical exchange rate.
59527_15_ITEM7_P73_S0	In January 2014, the Venezuela government announced the formation of the National Center of Foreign Trade ( CENCOEX ) to replace the Commission for the Administration of Currency Exchange ( CADIVI ).
59527_15_ITEM7_P73_S1	Effective January 24, 2014, the exchange rate applicable to the settlement of certain transactions through CENCOEX, including payments of dividends and royalties, changed to utilize the Complementary System of Foreign Currency Administration ("SICAD") auction-based exchange rate (the "SICAD I rate") as opposed to the official rate.
59527_15_ITEM7_P73_S2	Further, in January 2014, the Venezuelan government also enacted the "Fair Prices Law" limiting prices and establishing a maximum profit margin on goods and services.
59527_15_ITEM7_P74_S0	In February 2014, the government announced a new market based foreign exchange system, the SICAD II.
59527_15_ITEM7_P74_S1	The exchange rate established through SICAD II fluctuates daily and is significantly higher than both the official rate and the SICAD I rate.
59527_15_ITEM7_P75_S0	As of March 31, 2014, the Company determined that the rate used in remeasuring the Venezuelan operation's financial statements into U.S. dollars would change to the SICAD I rate as future remittances for dividend payments could be transacted at the SICAD I rate.
59527_15_ITEM7_P75_S1	As of March 31, 2014, the SICAD I rate was 10.7 bolivars to the U.S. dollar, which resulted in a remeasurement loss on the bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position of $17,665 which was recorded in Selling, general administrative expenses in the three months ended March 31, 2014.
59527_15_ITEM7_P75_S2	Additionally, the Company incurred higher Cost of goods sold of $3,468 during the second quarter of 2014 related to the adoption of the SICAD I rate.
59527_15_ITEM7_P76_S0	The SICAD I rate is determined by periodic auctions which may result in additional losses or gains on a remeasurement of the bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position.
59527_15_ITEM7_P77_S0	In February 2015, the Venezuelan government announced a new exchange market called the Marginal Currency System ( SIMADI ), which will replace the SICAD II exchange and allow for trading based on supply and demand.
59527_15_ITEM7_P77_S1	An initial exchange rate for the SIMADI market was established at approximately 170.0 bolivars to the U.S. dollar.
59527_15_ITEM7_P77_S2	While there remains considerable uncertainty as to the nature and volume of transactions that will flow through the various currency exchange mechanisms, the Company determined that the SICAD I rate remained the most appropriate exchange rate for the Company to utilize in remeasuring the Venezuelan operation's financial statements into U.S. dollars as of December 31, 2014 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P77_S3	As of December 31, 2014 , the SICAD I rate was 12.0 bolivars to the U.S dollar.
59527_15_ITEM7_P77_S4	If in the future the Company were to convert bolivars at a rate other than the SICAD I rate the Company may realize additional losses or gains to earnings.
59527_15_ITEM7_P77_S5	At December 31, 2014 , the amount of bolivar requests awaiting government approval to be paid in U.S. dollars at the SICAD I rate include $8,446 for dividend payments, of which $4,386 have been outstanding for more than a year, and $7,904 to be paid at the official rate, of which $7,661 have been outstanding for more than a year.
59527_15_ITEM7_P78_S0	In the 2014 , the Company s Venezuela operations contributed $71,793 to Net sales for the Company.
59527_15_ITEM7_P78_S1	Net income included a loss of $8,238 , or $0.10 per diluted share from Venezuela.
59527_15_ITEM7_P78_S2	Adjusted net income for the 2014 included $13,279 , or $0.17 per diluted share, from Venezuela.
59527_15_ITEM7_P78_S3	Future impacts to earnings of applying highly inflationary accounting for Venezuela on the Company s consolidated financial statements will be dependent upon the applied currency exchange mechanisms, the movements in the applicable exchange rates between the bolivar and the U.S. dollar and the amount of monetary assets and liabilities included in the Company s Venezuelan operation s balance sheet.
59527_15_ITEM7_P78_S4	The bolivar-denominated monetary net liability position was $1,264 at December 31, 2014 , which includes $2,124 of cash and cash equivalents and the bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position was $38,633 at December 31, 2013 , which includes $50,642 of cash and cash equivalents.
59527_15_ITEM7_P79_S0	The Company s ability to effectively manage sales and profit levels in Venezuela will be impacted by several factors.
59527_15_ITEM7_P79_S1	In addition to those factors previously mentioned, these include the Company s ability to mitigate the effect of any potential future devaluation and Venezuelan government price or exchange controls.
59527_15_ITEM7_P79_S2	For example, a future devaluation in the Venezuelan currency to the SIMADI rate would result in the Company realizing additional charges of approximately $22,000 to Cost of goods sold based on December 31, 2014 inventory levels and gains of approximately $1,000 to Selling, general and administrative expenses based upon the December 31, 2014 bolivar-denominated monetary net liability position.
59527_15_ITEM7_P79_S3	The various restrictions on the distribution of foreign currency by the Venezuelan government could also affect the Company s ability to pay obligations and maintain normal productions levels in Venezuela.
59527_15_ITEM7_P80_S0	Deferred Income Taxes Deferred income taxes are recognized at currently enacted tax rates for temporary differences between the GAAP and income tax basis of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carry-forwards.
59527_15_ITEM7_P80_S1	The Company does not provide deferred income taxes on unremitted earnings of certain non-U.S. subsidiaries, which are deemed permanently reinvested.
59527_15_ITEM7_P80_S2	It is not practicable to calculate the deferred taxes associated with the remittance of these earnings.
59527_15_ITEM7_P80_S3	Deferred income taxes associated with earnings of $16,032 that are not expected to be permanently reinvested were not significant.
59527_15_ITEM7_P80_S4	At December 31, 2014 , the Company had approximately $94,797 of gross deferred tax assets related to deductible temporary differences and tax loss and credit carry-forwards which may reduce taxable income in future years.
59527_15_ITEM7_P81_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, the Company assesses whether it is more likely than not that a portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
59527_15_ITEM7_P81_S1	The Company considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities, tax planning strategies, and projected future taxable income in making this assessment.
59527_15_ITEM7_P81_S2	At December 31, 2014 , a valuation allowance of $48,840 was recorded against these deferred tax assets based on this assessment.
59527_15_ITEM7_P81_S3	The Company believes it is more likely than not that the tax benefit of the remaining net deferred tax assets will be realized.
59527_15_ITEM7_P81_S4	The amount of net deferred tax assets considered realizable could be increased or reduced in the future if the Company's assessment of future taxable income or tax planning strategies changes.
59527_15_ITEM7_P82_S0	Pensions The Company maintains a number of defined benefit and defined contribution plans to provide retirement benefits for employees.
59527_15_ITEM7_P82_S1	These plans are maintained and contributions are made in accordance with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ("ERISA"), local statutory law or as determined by the Board of Directors.
59527_15_ITEM7_P82_S2	The plans generally provide benefits based upon years of service and compensation.
59527_15_ITEM7_P82_S3	Pension plans are funded except for a domestic non-qualified pension plan for certain key employees and certain foreign plans.
59527_15_ITEM7_P82_S4	A substantial portion of the Company's pension amounts relate to its defined benefit plan in the United States.
59527_15_ITEM7_P83_S0	The fair value of plan assets is determined at December 31 of each year.
59527_15_ITEM7_P84_S0	A significant element in determining the Company's pension expense is the expected return on plan assets.
59527_15_ITEM7_P84_S1	At the end of each year, the expected return on plan assets is determined based on the weighted average expected return of the various asset classes in the plan's portfolio and the targeted allocation of plan assets.
59527_15_ITEM7_P84_S2	The asset class return is developed using historical asset return performance as well as current market conditions such as inflation, interest rates and equity market performance.
59527_15_ITEM7_P84_S3	The Company determined this rate to be 7.3% and 7.4% at December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
59527_15_ITEM7_P85_S0	The assumed long-term rate of return on assets is applied to the market value of plan assets.
59527_15_ITEM7_P85_S1	This produces the expected return on plan assets included in pension expense.
59527_15_ITEM7_P85_S2	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is deferred and amortized over the average remaining service period of active employees expected to receive benefits under the plan.
59527_15_ITEM7_P85_S3	The amortization of the net deferral of past losses will increase future pension expense.
59527_15_ITEM7_P86_S0	During 2014 , investment returns were 11.5% compared with a return of 12.4% in 2013 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P86_S1	A 25 basis point change in the expected return on plan assets would increase or decrease pension expense by approximately $2,100 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S0	Another significant element in determining the Company's pension expense is the discount rate for plan liabilities.
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S1	To develop the discount rate assumption, the Company refers to the yield derived from matching projected pension payments with maturities of a portfolio of available non-callable bonds rated AA or an equivalent quality.
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S2	The Company determined this rate to be 4.1% at December 31, 2014 and 4.7% at December 31, 2013 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S3	A 10 basis point change in the discount rate would increase or decrease pension expense by approximately $1,200 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S4	Pension expense relating to the Company's defined benefit plans was $12,395 , $29,908 and $36,258 in 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S5	The Company expects 2015 defined benefit pension expense to increase by a range of approximately $10,000 to $12,000 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S6	The Accumulated other comprehensive loss, excluding tax effects, recognized on the Consolidated Balance Sheet was $314,411 as of December 31, 2014 and $256,260 as of December 31, 2013 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S7	The increase is primarily the result of actuarial losses recorded during the year.
59527_15_ITEM7_P87_S8	Actuarial losses arising during 2014 are primarily attributable to a lower discount rate and the adoption of new mortality tables.
59527_15_ITEM7_P88_S0	The Company made voluntary contributions to its U.S. defined benefit plans of $21,175 , $75,216 and $60,277 in 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
59527_15_ITEM7_P88_S1	The Company expects to voluntarily contribute $21,000 to the U.S. plans in 2015 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P88_S2	Based on current pension funding rules, the Company does not anticipate that contributions to the plans would be required in 2015 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P89_S0	Inventories Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
59527_15_ITEM7_P89_S1	Fixed manufacturing overhead costs are allocated to inventory based on normal production capacity and abnormal manufacturing costs are recognized as period costs.
59527_15_ITEM7_P90_S0	For most domestic inventories, cost is determined principally by the last-in, first-out ("LIFO") method, and for non-U.S. inventories, cost is determined by the first-in, first-out ("FIFO") method.
59527_15_ITEM7_P91_S0	The valuation of LIFO inventories is made at the end of each year based on inventory levels and costs at that time.
59527_15_ITEM7_P91_S1	Accordingly, interim LIFO calculations are based on management's estimates of expected year-end inventory levels and costs.
59527_15_ITEM7_P91_S2	Actual year-end costs and inventory levels may differ from interim LIFO inventory valuations.
59527_15_ITEM7_P91_S3	The excess of current cost over LIFO cost was $71,311 at December 31, 2014 and $70,882 at December 31, 2013 .
59527_15_ITEM7_P92_S0	The Company reviews the net realizable value of inventory on an on-going basis, with consideration given to deterioration, obsolescence and other factors.
59527_15_ITEM7_P92_S1	If actual market conditions differ from those projected by management, and the Company's estimates prove to be inaccurate, write-downs of inventory values and adjustments to Cost of goods sold may be required.
59527_15_ITEM7_P93_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_15_ITEM7_P93_S1	The Company maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses from the failure of its customers to make required payments for products delivered.
59527_15_ITEM7_P93_S2	The Company estimates this allowance based on the age of the related receivable, knowledge of the financial condition of customers, review of historical receivables and reserve trends and other pertinent information.
59527_15_ITEM7_P93_S3	If the financial condition of customers deteriorates or an unfavorable trend in receivable collections is experienced in the future, additional allowances may be required.
59527_15_ITEM7_P94_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_15_ITEM7_P95_S0	Goodwill and Intangibles The Company performs an annual impairment test of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets in the fourth quarter using the same dates each year or more frequently if changes in circumstances or the occurrence of events indicate potential impairment.
59527_15_ITEM7_P95_S1	The fair value of each indefinite-lived intangible asset is compared to its carrying value and an impairment charge is recorded if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
59527_15_ITEM7_P96_S0	Goodwill is tested by comparing the fair value of each reporting unit with its carrying value.
59527_15_ITEM7_P96_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the implied value of goodwill is compared to its carrying value and impairment is recognized to the extent that the carrying value exceeds the implied fair value.
59527_15_ITEM7_P97_S0	Fair values are determined using established business valuation multiples and models developed by the Company that incorporate allocations of certain assets and cash flows among reporting units, estimates of market participant assumptions of future cash flows, future growth rates and the applicable discount rates to value estimated cash flows.
59527_15_ITEM7_P97_S1	Changes in economic and operating conditions impacting these assumptions could result in asset impairments in future periods.
59527_15_ITEM7_P97_S2	The fair value of goodwill for all of the Company's operating business units exceeded its carrying value by at least 10% as of the testing date during the fourth quarter of 2014.
59527_15_ITEM7_P97_S3	Key assumptions in estimating the reporting unit's fair value include assumed market participant assumptions of revenue growth, operating margins and the rate used to discount future cash flows.
59527_15_ITEM7_P97_S4	Actual revenue growth and operating margins below the assumed market participant assumptions or an increase in the discount rate would have a negative impact on the fair value of the reporting unit that could result in a goodwill impairment charge in a future period.
59527_15_ITEM7_P98_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company periodically evaluates whether current facts or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of its depreciable long-lived assets to be held and used may not be recoverable.
59527_15_ITEM7_P98_S1	If such circumstances are determined to exist, an estimate of undiscounted future cash flows produced by the long-lived asset, or the appropriate grouping of assets, is compared to the carrying value to determine whether impairment exists.
59527_15_ITEM7_P99_S0	If an asset is determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized to the extent that carrying value exceeds fair value.
59527_15_ITEM7_P100_S0	Fair value is measured based on quoted market prices in active markets, if available.
59527_15_ITEM7_P100_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, the estimate of fair value is based on various valuation techniques, including the discounted value of estimated future cash flows.
59527_15_ITEM7_P101_S0	During 2014, the Company identified long-lived assets for planned divestiture.
59527_15_ITEM7_P101_S1	In anticipation of the divestiture, the Company reviewed the carrying values and future cash flows of certain long-lived assets for potential impairment.
59527_15_ITEM7_P101_S2	The Company determined that for certain assets, including the planned divestiture, the carrying values of the assets exceeded the fair values resulting in non-cash impairment charges of $32,617 recorded in Rationalization and asset impairment charges.
59527_15_ITEM7_P101_S3	As of December 31, 2014 , the assets identified for divestiture were classified as held for sale.
59527_15_ITEM7_P102_S0	The Company utilizes the Black-Scholes option pricing model for estimating fair values of options.
59527_15_ITEM7_P102_S1	The Black-Scholes model requires assumptions regarding the volatility of the Company's common shares, the expected life of the stock award and the Company's dividend yield.
59527_15_ITEM7_P102_S2	The Company utilizes historical data in determining these assumptions.
59527_15_ITEM7_P102_S3	An increase or decrease in the assumptions or economic events outside of management's control could have an impact on the Black-Scholes model.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Included below is a sensitivity analysis based upon a hypothetical 10% weakening or strengthening in the U.S. dollar compared to foreign currency exchange rates at December 31, 2014 , a 10% change in commodity prices, and a 100 basis point increase in effective interest rates.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The contractual derivative, borrowing and investment arrangements in effect at December 31, 2014 were compared to the hypothetical foreign exchange, commodity price, or interest rates in the sensitivity analysis to determine the effect on income before taxes, interest expense, or accumulated other comprehensive loss.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P0_S2	The analysis takes into consideration any offset that would result from changes in the value of the hedged asset or liability.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Foreign Currency Exchange Risk The Company enters into forward foreign exchange contracts principally to hedge the currency fluctuations in transactions denominated in foreign currencies, thereby limiting the Company's risk that would otherwise result from changes in exchange rates.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P1_S1	At December 31, 2014 , the Company hedged certain third-party and inter-company purchases and sales.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P1_S2	At December 31, 2014 , the Company had foreign exchange contracts with a notional value of approximately $87,999 , which includes net investment hedges.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P2_S0	At December 31, 2014 , a hypothetical 10% weakening of the U.S. dollar would not materially affect the Company's financial statements.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Commodity Price Risk From time to time, the Company uses various hedging arrangements to manage exposures to price risk from commodity purchases.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P3_S1	These hedging arrangements have the effect of fixing for specified periods the prices the Company will pay for the volume to which the hedge relates.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P4_S0	A hypothetical 10% adverse change in commodity prices on the Company's open commodity futures at December 31, 2014 would not materially affect the Company's financial statements.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Interest Rate Risk The Company's debt portfolio contains variable rate debt, inherently exposing the Company to interest rate risk.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P5_S1	A hypothetical 1.0% increase in interest rates would not materially affect the Company's financial statements.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P6_S0	The Company uses interest rate derivatives to manage interest rate risk.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P6_S1	The Company had no interest rate derivatives outstanding during 2014 or 2013.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The Company's return on cash and cash equivalents are also subject to interest rate risk.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P6_S3	As of December 31, 2014 , the Company had $278,379 in cash and cash equivalents.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P6_S4	A hypothetical change of 1.0% in interest rates would not materially affect the Company's financial statements.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P6_S5	The fair value of the Company's Cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2014 approximated carrying value.
59527_15_ITEM7A_P6_S6	The Company's financial instruments are subject to concentrations of credit risk.

59527_15_ITEM15_P13_S2	Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries' management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management's Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting in Item 9A.
59527_15_ITEM15_P13_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company's internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
59527_15_ITEM15_P13_S4	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
59527_15_ITEM15_P13_S5	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
59527_15_ITEM15_P13_S6	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
59527_15_ITEM15_P13_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
59527_15_ITEM15_P14_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
59527_15_ITEM15_P14_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
59527_15_ITEM15_P14_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
59527_15_ITEM15_P14_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
59527_15_ITEM15_P15_S0	In our opinion, Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2014 , based on the COSO criteria.
59527_15_ITEM15_P15_S1	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2014 of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries and our report dated February 20, 2015 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.

59527_15_ITEM15_P18_S0	See notes to these consolidated financial statements.

59527_15_ITEM15_P22_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and its wholly-owned and majority-owned subsidiaries for which it has a controlling interest (the "Company") after elimination of all inter-company accounts, transactions and profits.
59527_15_ITEM15_P23_S0	General Information The Company is a manufacturer of welding, cutting and brazing products.
59527_15_ITEM15_P23_S1	Welding products include arc welding power sources, wire feeding systems, robotic welding packages, fume extraction equipment, consumable electrodes and fluxes.
59527_15_ITEM15_P23_S2	The Company's product offering also includes computer numeric controlled ("CNC") plasma and oxy-fuel cutting systems, regulators and torches used in oxy-fuel welding, cutting and brazing and consumables used in the brazing and soldering alloys market.
59527_15_ITEM15_P24_S0	Translation of Foreign Currencies Asset and liability accounts are translated into U.S. dollars using exchange rates in effect at the dates of the Consolidated Balance Sheets; revenue and expense accounts are translated at average monthly exchange rates.
59527_15_ITEM15_P24_S1	Translation adjustments are reflected as a component of Total equity.
59527_15_ITEM15_P24_S2	For subsidiaries operating in highly inflationary economies, both historical and current exchange rates are used in translating balance sheet accounts and translation adjustments are included in Net income.
59527_15_ITEM15_P25_S0	The translation of assets and liabilities originally denominated in foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is for consolidation purposes, and does not necessarily indicate that the Company could realize or settle the reported value of those assets and liabilities in U.S. dollars.
59527_15_ITEM15_P25_S1	Additionally, such a translation does not necessarily indicate that the Company could return or distribute the reported U.S. dollar value of the net equity of its foreign operations to shareholders.
59527_15_ITEM15_P25_S2	Foreign currency transaction losses are included in Selling, general administrative expenses and were $22,351 , $7,759 and $4,608 in 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
59527_15_ITEM15_P26_S0	Venezuela Highly Inflationary Economy Venezuela is a highly inflationary economy under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP").
59527_15_ITEM15_P26_S1	As a result, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation are reported under highly inflationary accounting rules as of January 1, 2010.
59527_15_ITEM15_P27_S0	Under highly inflationary accounting, the financial statements of the Company's Venezuelan operation have been remeasured into the Company's reporting currency and exchange gains and losses from the re-measurement of monetary assets and liabilities are reflected in current earnings.
59527_15_ITEM15_P28_S0	On February 8, 2013, the Venezuelan government announced the devaluation of its currency relative to the U.S. dollar.
59527_15_ITEM15_P28_S1	Effective February 13, 2013 the official rate moved from 4.3 to 6.3 bolivars to the U.S. dollar.
59527_15_ITEM15_P28_S2	In 2013, the devaluation of the bolivar resulted in a foreign currency transaction loss of $8,081 in Selling, general administrative expenses and higher Cost of goods sold of $4,117 due to the liquidation of inventory valued at the historical exchange rate.
59527_15_ITEM15_P29_S0	In January 2014, the Venezuela government announced the formation of the National Center of Foreign Trade ( CENCOEX ) to replace the Commission for the Administration of Currency Exchange ( CADIVI ).
59527_15_ITEM15_P29_S1	Effective January 24, 2014, the exchange rate applicable to the settlement of certain transactions through CENCOEX, including payments of dividends and royalties, changed to utilize the Complementary System of Foreign Currency Administration ("SICAD") auction-based exchange rate (the "SICAD I rate") as opposed to the official rate.
59527_15_ITEM15_P29_S2	Further, in January 2014, the Venezuelan government also enacted the "Fair Prices Law" limiting prices and establishing a maximum profit margin on goods and services.
59527_15_ITEM15_P30_S0	In February 2014, the government announced a new market based foreign exchange system, the SICAD II.
59527_15_ITEM15_P30_S1	The exchange rate established through SICAD II fluctuates daily and is significantly higher than both the official rate and the SICAD I rate.
59527_15_ITEM15_P31_S0	As of March 31, 2014, the Company determined that the rate used in remeasuring the Venezuelan operation's financial statements into U.S. dollars would change to the SICAD I rate as future remittances for dividend payments could be transacted at the SICAD I rate.
59527_15_ITEM15_P31_S1	As of March 31, 2014, the SICAD I rate was 10.7 bolivars to the U.S. dollar, which resulted in a remeasurement loss on the bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position of $17,665 which was recorded in Selling, general administrative expenses in the three months ended March 31, 2014.
59527_15_ITEM15_P31_S2	Additionally, the Company incurred higher Cost of goods sold of $3,468 during the second quarter of 2014 related to the adoption of the SICAD I rate.
59527_15_ITEM15_P32_S0	The SICAD I rate is determined by periodic auctions which may result in additional losses or gains on a remeasurement of the bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S0	In February 2015, the Venezuelan government announced a new exchange market called the Marginal Currency System ( SIMADI ), which will replace the SICAD II exchange and allow for trading based on supply and demand.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S1	An initial exchange rate for the SIMADI market was established at approximately 170.0 bolivars to the U.S. dollar.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S2	While there remains considerable uncertainty as to the nature and volume of transactions that will flow through the various currency exchange mechanisms, the Company determined that the SICAD I rate remained the most appropriate exchange rate for the Company to utilize in remeasuring the Venezuelan operation's financial statements into U.S. dollars as of December 31, 2014 .
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S3	As of December 31, 2014 , the SICAD I rate was 12.0 bolivars to the U.S dollar.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S4	If in the future the Company were to convert bolivars at a rate other than the SICAD I rate the Company may realize additional losses or gains to earnings.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S5	Future impacts to earnings of applying highly inflationary accounting for Venezuela on the Company s consolidated financial statements will be dependent upon the applied currency exchange mechanisms, the movements in the applicable exchange rates between the bolivar and the U.S. dollar and the amount of monetary assets and liabilities included in the Company s Venezuelan operation s balance sheet.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S6	The bolivar-denominated monetary net liability position was $1,264 at December 31, 2014 , which includes $2,124 of cash and cash equivalents and the bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position was $38,633 at December 31, 2013 , which includes $50,642 of cash and cash equivalents.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S7	The Company considers all highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S8	The Company maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses from the failure of its customers to make required payments for products delivered.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S9	The Company estimates this allowance based on the age of the related receivable, knowledge of the financial condition of customers, review of historical receivables and reserve trends and other pertinent information.
59527_15_ITEM15_P33_S10	If the financial condition of customers deteriorates or an unfavorable trend in receivable collections is experienced in the future, additional allowances may be required.
59527_15_ITEM15_P34_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_15_ITEM15_P35_S0	Inventories Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
59527_15_ITEM15_P35_S1	Fixed manufacturing overhead costs are allocated to inventory based on normal production capacity and abnormal manufacturing costs are recognized as period costs.
59527_15_ITEM15_P36_S0	For most domestic inventories, cost is determined principally by the last-in, first-out ("LIFO") method, and for non-U.S. inventories, cost is determined by the first-in, first-out ("FIFO") method.
59527_15_ITEM15_P37_S0	Reserves are maintained for estimated obsolescence or excess inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated market value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
59527_15_ITEM15_P38_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_15_ITEM15_P39_S0	Equity Investments Investments in businesses in which the Company does not have a controlling interest and holds between a 20% and 50% ownership interest are accounted for using the equity method of accounting.
59527_15_ITEM15_P39_S1	The Company's 50% ownership interest in equity investments includes investments in Turkey and Chile.
59527_15_ITEM15_P39_S2	The amount of retained earnings that represents undistributed earnings of 50% or less owned equity investments was $18,542 at December 31, 2014 and $16,694 at December 31, 2013 .
59527_15_ITEM15_P40_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment Property, plant and equipment are stated at cost and include improvements which significantly increase capacities or extend the useful lives of existing plant and equipment.
59527_15_ITEM15_P41_S0	Depreciation and amortization are computed using a straight-line method over useful lives ranging from three to 20 years for machinery, tools and equipment, and up to 50 years for buildings.
59527_15_ITEM15_P42_S0	Net gains or losses related to asset dispositions are recognized in earnings in the period in which dispositions occur.
59527_15_ITEM15_P42_S1	Routine maintenance, repairs and replacements are expensed as incurred.
59527_15_ITEM15_P43_S0	The Company capitalizes interest costs associated with long-term construction in progress.
59527_15_ITEM15_P44_S0	Goodwill and Intangibles Goodwill is recorded when the cost of acquired businesses exceeds the fair value of the identifiable net assets acquired.
59527_15_ITEM15_P44_S1	Intangible assets other than goodwill are recorded at fair value at the time acquired or at cost, if applicable.
59527_15_ITEM15_P44_S2	Intangible assets that do not have indefinite lives are amortized in line with the pattern in which the economic benefits of the intangible asset are consumed.
59527_15_ITEM15_P44_S3	If the pattern of economic benefit cannot be reliably determined, the intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line basis over the shorter of the legal or estimated life.
59527_15_ITEM15_P44_S4	Goodwill and indefinite-lived intangibles assets are not amortized, but are tested for impairment in the fourth quarter using the same dates each year or more frequently if changes in circumstances or the occurrence of events indicate potential impairment.
59527_15_ITEM15_P44_S5	The fair value of each indefinite-lived intangible asset is compared to its carrying value and an impairment charge is recorded if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
59527_15_ITEM15_P45_S0	Goodwill is tested by comparing the fair value of each reporting unit with its carrying value.
59527_15_ITEM15_P45_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the implied value of goodwill is compared to its carrying value and impairment is recognized to the extent that the carrying value exceeds the implied fair value.
59527_15_ITEM15_P46_S0	Fair values are determined using established business valuation multiples and models developed by the Company that incorporate allocations of certain assets and cash flows among reporting units, estimates of market participant assumptions of future cash flows, future growth rates and the applicable discount rates to value estimated cash flows.
59527_15_ITEM15_P46_S1	Changes in economic and operating conditions impacting these assumptions could result in asset impairments in future periods.
59527_15_ITEM15_P47_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company periodically evaluates whether current facts or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of its depreciable long-lived assets to be held and used may not be recoverable.
59527_15_ITEM15_P47_S1	If such circumstances are determined to exist, an estimate of undiscounted future cash flows produced by the long-lived asset, or the appropriate grouping of assets, is compared to the carrying value to determine whether impairment exists.
59527_15_ITEM15_P48_S0	If an asset is determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized to the extent that carrying value exceeds fair value.
59527_15_ITEM15_P49_S0	Fair value is measured based on quoted market prices in active markets, if available.
59527_15_ITEM15_P49_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, the estimate of fair value is based on various valuation techniques, including the discounted value of estimated future cash flows.
59527_15_ITEM15_P50_S0	Fair Value Measurements Financial assets and liabilities, such as the Company's defined benefit pension plan assets and derivative contracts, are valued at fair value using the market and income valuation approaches.
59527_15_ITEM15_P50_S1	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
59527_15_ITEM15_P50_S2	The Company uses the market approach to value similar assets and liabilities in active markets and the income approach that consists of discounted cash flow models that take into account the present value of future cash flows under the terms of the contracts using current market information as of the reporting date.
59527_15_ITEM15_P51_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
59527_15_ITEM15_P52_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
59527_15_ITEM15_P53_S0	Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or other means.
59527_15_ITEM15_P54_S0	If the asset or liability has a specific (contractual) term, the Level 2 input must be observable for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
59527_15_ITEM15_P55_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair value measurement.
59527_15_ITEM15_P56_S0	The Company accrues for product warranty claims based on historical experience and the expected material and labor costs to provide warranty service.
59527_15_ITEM15_P56_S1	Warranty services are provided for periods up to three years from the date of sale.
59527_15_ITEM15_P57_S0	Revenue Recognition Substantially all of the Company's revenues are recognized when the risks and rewards of ownership and title to the product have transferred to the customer which generally occurs at point of shipment.
59527_15_ITEM15_P57_S1	The Company recognizes any discounts, credits, returns, rebates and incentive programs based on reasonable estimates as a reduction of Sales to arrive at Net sales at the same time the related revenue is recorded.
59527_15_ITEM15_P58_S0	For contracts accounted for under the percentage of completion method, revenue recognition is based upon the ratio of costs incurred to date compared with estimated total costs to complete.
59527_15_ITEM15_P58_S1	The cumulative impact of revisions to total estimated costs is reflected in the period of the change, including anticipated losses.
59527_15_ITEM15_P59_S0	Distribution Costs Distribution costs, including warehousing and freight related to product shipments, are included in Cost of goods sold.
59527_15_ITEM15_P60_S0	Stock-Based Compensation Expense is recognized for all awards of stock-based compensation by allocating the aggregate grant date fair value over the vesting period.
59527_15_ITEM15_P60_S1	No expense is recognized for any stock options, restricted or deferred shares or restricted stock units ultimately forfeited because the recipients fail to meet vesting requirements.
59527_15_ITEM15_P60_S2	Common stock issuable upon the exercise of employee stock options is excluded from the calculation of diluted earnings per share when the calculation of option equivalent shares is anti-dilutive.
59527_15_ITEM15_P61_S0	The Company uses forward contracts to hedge exposures to commodity prices and exchange rate fluctuations on certain purchase and sales transactions, balance sheet and net investment exposures.
59527_15_ITEM15_P61_S1	Contracts are generally written on a short-term basis but may cover exposures for up to two years and are not held for trading or speculative purposes.
59527_15_ITEM15_P62_S0	The Company uses interest rate swaps from time to time to hedge changes in the fair value of debt.
59527_15_ITEM15_P62_S1	The Company recognizes derivative instruments as either assets or liabilities at fair value.
59527_15_ITEM15_P62_S2	The accounting for changes in the fair value of derivative instruments depends on whether it has been designated and qualifies as part of a hedging relationship and on the type of hedging relationship.
59527_15_ITEM15_P62_S3	For derivative instruments that qualify as a fair value hedge (i.e., hedging the exposure to changes in the fair value of an asset or a liability), the gain or loss on the derivative instrument, as well as the offsetting loss or gain on the hedged item are recognized in earnings.
59527_15_ITEM15_P62_S4	For derivative instruments that qualify as a cash flow hedge (i.e., hedging the exposure to variability in expected future cash flows), the effective portion of the unrealized gain or loss on the derivative instrument is reported as a component of Accumulated other comprehensive income with offsetting amounts recorded as Other current assets, Other non-current assets, Other current liabilities or Other long-term liabilities depending on the position and the duration of the contract.
59527_15_ITEM15_P63_S0	At settlement, the realized gain or loss is reflected in earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings.
59527_15_ITEM15_P63_S1	Any remaining gain or loss on the derivative instrument is recognized in earnings.
59527_15_ITEM15_P63_S2	For derivative instruments that qualify as a net investment hedge (i.e., hedging the foreign currency exposure of a net investment in a foreign operation), the effective portion of the gain or loss on this derivative instrument is recognized in Accumulated other comprehensive loss with offsetting amounts recorded as Other current assets, Other non-current assets, Other current liabilities or Other long-term liabilities depending on the position and the duration of the contract.
59527_15_ITEM15_P63_S3	The gain or loss is subsequently reclassified to Selling, general, and administrative expenses, as the underlying hedged investment is liquidated.
59527_15_ITEM15_P63_S4	For derivative instruments not designated as hedges, the gain or loss from changes in the fair value of the instruments is recognized in earnings.
59527_15_ITEM15_P64_S0	Research and Development Research and development costs are charged to Selling, general administrative expenses as incurred and totaled $43,256 , $42,126 and $37,305 in 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
59527_15_ITEM15_P65_S0	Bonus Included in Selling, general administrative expenses are the costs related to the Company's discretionary employee bonus programs, which for certain U.S.-based employees are net of hospitalization costs.
59527_15_ITEM15_P65_S1	Bonus costs were $128,478 in 2014 , $123,571 in 2013 and $124,947 in 2012 .
59527_15_ITEM15_P66_S0	Income Taxes Deferred income taxes are recognized at currently enacted tax rates for temporary differences between the GAAP and income tax basis of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carry-forwards.
59527_15_ITEM15_P67_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, the Company assesses whether it is more likely than not that a portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
59527_15_ITEM15_P68_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions in certain circumstances that affect the amounts reported in the accompanying consolidated financial statements and notes.
59527_15_ITEM15_P68_S1	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
59527_15_ITEM15_P69_S0	Reclassification Certain reclassifications have been made to prior year financial statements to conform to current year classifications.
59527_15_ITEM15_P70_S0	ASU 2014-09 requires an entity to recognize revenue in a manner that depicts the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
59527_15_ITEM15_P70_S1	To achieve that core principle, the amendment provides five steps that an entity should apply when recognizing revenue.
59527_15_ITEM15_P70_S2	The amendment also specifies the accounting of some costs to obtain or fulfill a contract with a customer and expands the disclosure requirements around contracts with customers.
59527_15_ITEM15_P70_S3	An entity can either adopt this amendment retrospectively to each prior reporting period presented or retrospectively with the cumulative effect of initially applying the update recognized at the date of initial application.
59527_15_ITEM15_P70_S4	The amendment is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
59527_15_ITEM15_P70_S5	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of ASU 2014-09 on the Company's financial statements.

59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S0	NOTE 3 ACQUISITIONS During October 2014, the Company acquired substantially all of the assets of Easom Automation Systems, Inc. ("Easom").
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S1	Easom, based in Detroit, Michigan, is an integrator and manufacturer of automation and positioning solutions, serving heavy fabrication, aerospace and automotive OEMs and suppliers.
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S2	The acquisition advances the Company's leadership position in automated welding and cutting solutions.
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S3	Easom has annual sales of approximately $30,000 .
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S4	In addition, during 2014, the Company acquired the remaining interest in its majority-owned joint venture, Harris Soldas Especiais S.A. During November 2013, the Company completed the acquisition of Robolution GmbH ("Robolution").
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S5	Robolution, based outside of Frankfurt, Germany, is a leading European provider of robotic arc welding systems.
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S6	The acquisition added to the Company's growing automation business and will enable the Company to better support automation customers across three continents.
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S7	During November 2013, the Company acquired an ownership interest in Burlington Automation Corporation ("Burlington").
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S8	Burlington, based in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, is a leader in the design and manufacture of 3D robotic plasma cutting systems whose products are sold under the brand name Python X .
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S9	The acquisition broadens the Company's portfolio of automated cutting and welding process solutions.
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S10	Combined revenues for Robolution and Burlington in 2013 were approximately $35,000 .
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S11	In addition, during 2013, the Company acquired a greater interest in its majority-owned joint venture, Lincoln Electric Heli (Zhengzhou) Welding Materials Company Ltd.
59527_15_ITEM15_P73_S12	During 2012, the Company completed the acquisitions of Tennessee Rand, Inc. ("Tenn Rand"), Kaliburn, Burny and Cleveland Motion Control businesses (collectively, "Kaliburn"), Wayne Trail Technologies, Inc. ( Wayne Trail ), and Weartech International, Inc. ( Weartech ).
59527_15_ITEM15_P74_S0	Tenn Rand, based in Chattanooga, Tennessee, is a leader in the design and manufacture of tooling and robotic systems for welding applications.
59527_15_ITEM15_P74_S1	The acquisition added tool design, system building and machining capabilities that will enable the Company to further expand its welding automation business.
59527_15_ITEM15_P75_S0	Kaliburn, headquartered in Ladson, South Carolina, is a designer and manufacturer of shape cutting solutions, producer of shape cutting control systems and manufacturer of web tension transducers and engineered machine systems.
59527_15_ITEM15_P75_S1	The acquisitions added to the Company's cutting business portfolio.
59527_15_ITEM15_P76_S0	Wayne Trail, based in Fort Loramie, Ohio, is a manufacturer of automated systems and tooling, serving a wide range of applications in the metal processing market.
59527_15_ITEM15_P76_S1	The acquisition added to the Company s welding and automated solutions portfolio.
59527_15_ITEM15_P77_S0	Weartech, based in Anaheim, California, is a producer of cobalt-based hard facing and wear-resistant welding consumables.
59527_15_ITEM15_P77_S1	The acquisition added to the Company s consumables portfolio.
59527_15_ITEM15_P77_S2	Combined annual revenues for Tenn Rand, Kaliburn, Wayne Trail and Weartech at the dates of acquisition were approximately $161,000 .
59527_15_ITEM15_P77_S3	Pro forma information related to these acquisitions has not been presented because the impact on the Company's Consolidated Statements of Income is not material.
59527_15_ITEM15_P78_S0	Acquired companies are included in the Company's consolidated financial statements as of the date of acquisition.

59527_15_ITEM15_P83_S0	The Company's primary business is the design and manufacture of arc welding and cutting products, manufacturing a broad line of arc welding equipment, consumable welding products and other welding and cutting products.
59527_15_ITEM15_P83_S1	The Company also has a leading global position in the brazing and soldering alloys market.
59527_15_ITEM15_P84_S0	The Company has aligned its business units into five operating segments to enhance the utilization of the Company's worldwide resources and global end user and sourcing initiatives.
59527_15_ITEM15_P84_S1	The operating segments consist of North America Welding, Europe Welding, Asia Pacific Welding, South America Welding and The Harris Products Group.
59527_15_ITEM15_P85_S0	The North America Welding segment includes welding operations in the United States, Canada and Mexico.
59527_15_ITEM15_P85_S1	The Europe Welding segment includes welding operations in Europe, Russia, Africa and the Middle East.
59527_15_ITEM15_P85_S2	The Asia Pacific Welding segment primarily includes welding operations in China and Australia.
59527_15_ITEM15_P85_S3	The South America Welding segment primarily includes welding operations in Brazil, Colombia and Venezuela.
59527_15_ITEM15_P86_S0	The Harris Products Group includes the Company's global cutting, soldering and brazing businesses as well as the retail business in the United States.
59527_15_ITEM15_P87_S0	Segment performance is measured and resources are allocated based on a number of factors, the primary profit measure being earnings before interest and income taxes ("EBIT"), as adjusted.
59527_15_ITEM15_P87_S1	Segment EBIT is adjusted for special items as determined by management such as the impact of rationalization activities, certain asset impairment charges and gains or losses on disposals of assets.
59527_15_ITEM15_P87_S2	The accounting principles applied at the operating segment level are generally the same as those applied at the consolidated financial statement level with the exception of LIFO.
59527_15_ITEM15_P87_S3	Segment assets include inventories measured on a FIFO basis while consolidated inventories include inventories reported on a LIFO basis.
59527_15_ITEM15_P87_S4	Segment and consolidated income before interest and income taxes include the effect of inventories reported on a LIFO basis.
59527_15_ITEM15_P87_S5	At December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , approximately 40% , 38% and 34% , respectively, of total inventories were valued using the LIFO method.
59527_15_ITEM15_P88_S0	LIFO is used for certain domestic inventories included in the North America Welding segment.
59527_15_ITEM15_P88_S1	Inter-segment sales are recorded at agreed upon prices that approximate arm's length prices and are eliminated in consolidation.

59527_15_ITEM15_P125_S0	NOTE 11 RETIREMENT ANNUITY AND GUARANTEED CONTINUOUS EMPLOYMENT PLANS The Company maintains a number of defined benefit and defined contribution plans to provide retirement benefits for employees.

59527_15_ITEM15_P125_S3	Pension plans are funded except for a domestic non-qualified pension plan for certain key employees and certain foreign plans.

59527_15_ITEM15_P166_S0	NOTE 13 DERIVATIVES The Company uses derivatives to manage exposures to currency exchange rates, interest rates and commodity prices arising in the normal course of business.
59527_15_ITEM15_P166_S1	Derivative contracts to hedge currency and commodity exposures are generally written on a short-term basis but may cover exposures for up to two years while interest rate contracts may cover longer periods consistent with the terms of the underlying debt.
59527_15_ITEM15_P166_S2	The Company does not enter into derivatives for trading or speculative purposes.
59527_15_ITEM15_P166_S3	All derivatives are recognized at fair value on the Company's Consolidated Balance Sheets.
59527_15_ITEM15_P166_S4	The accounting for gains and losses resulting from changes in fair value depends on the use of the derivative and whether it is designated and qualifies for hedge accounting.
59527_15_ITEM15_P166_S5	The Company formally documents the relationship of the hedge with the hedged item as well as the risk-management strategy for all designated hedges.
59527_15_ITEM15_P167_S0	Both at inception and on an ongoing basis, the hedging instrument is assessed as to its effectiveness, when applicable.
59527_15_ITEM15_P167_S1	If and when a derivative is determined not to be highly effective as a hedge, the underlying hedged transaction is no longer likely to occur, or the derivative is terminated, hedge accounting is discontinued.
59527_15_ITEM15_P168_S0	The cash flows from settled derivative contracts are recognized in operating activities in the Company's Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
59527_15_ITEM15_P168_S1	Hedge ineffectiveness was immaterial for the three years ended December 31, 2014.
59527_15_ITEM15_P169_S0	The Company is subject to the credit risk of the counterparties to derivative instruments.
59527_15_ITEM15_P169_S1	Counterparties include a number of major banks and financial institutions.
59527_15_ITEM15_P169_S2	The Company manages individual counterparty exposure by monitoring the credit rating of the counterparty and the size of financial commitments and exposures between the Company and the counterparty.
59527_15_ITEM15_P169_S3	None of the concentrations of risk with any individual counterparty was considered significant at December 31, 2014 .
59527_15_ITEM15_P170_S0	The Company does not expect any counterparties to fail to meet their obligations.

59527_15_ITEM15_P190_S0	NOTE 15 INVENTORY For most domestic inventories, cost is determined principally by the LIFO method, and for non-U.S. inventories, cost is determined by the FIFO method.
59527_15_ITEM15_P191_S0	The valuation of LIFO inventories is made at the end of each year based on inventory levels and costs at that time.
59527_15_ITEM15_P191_S1	Accordingly, interim LIFO calculations are based on management's estimates of expected year-end inventory levels and costs.
59527_15_ITEM15_P191_S2	Because these estimates are subject to many factors beyond management's control, annual results may differ from interim results as they are subject to the final year-end LIFO inventory valuation.
59527_15_ITEM15_P191_S3	At December 31, 2014 and 2013 , approximately 40% and 38% , respectively, of total inventories were valued using the LIFO method.
59527_15_ITEM15_P191_S4	The excess of current cost over LIFO cost was $71,311 at December 31, 2014 and $70,882 at December 31, 2013 .

59527_15_ITEM15_P194_S0	NOTE 17 CONTINGENCIES The Company, like other manufacturers, is subject from time to time to a variety of civil and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
59527_15_ITEM15_P194_S1	Such claims and litigation include, without limitation, product liability claims, regulatory claims and health, safety and environmental claims, some of which relate to cases alleging asbestos induced illnesses.
59527_15_ITEM15_P195_S0	The claimants in the asbestos cases seek compensatory and punitive damages, in most cases for unspecified amounts.
59527_15_ITEM15_P195_S1	The Company believes it has meritorious defenses to these claims and intends to contest such suits vigorously.
59527_15_ITEM15_P196_S0	The Company accrues its best estimate of the probable costs, after a review of the facts with management and counsel and taking into account past experience.
59527_15_ITEM15_P196_S1	If an unfavorable outcome is determined to be reasonably possible but not probable, or if the amount of loss cannot be reasonably estimated, disclosure is provided for material claims or litigation.
59527_15_ITEM15_P197_S0	Many of the current cases are in differing procedural stages and information on the circumstances of each claimant, which forms the basis for judgments as to the validity or ultimate disposition of such actions, varies greatly.
59527_15_ITEM15_P197_S1	Therefore, in many situations a range of possible losses cannot be made.
59527_15_ITEM15_P197_S2	Reserves are adjusted as facts and circumstances change and related management assessments of the underlying merits and the likelihood of outcomes change.
59527_15_ITEM15_P197_S3	Moreover, reserves only cover identified and/or asserted claims.
59527_15_ITEM15_P197_S4	Future claims could, therefore, give rise to increases to such reserves.
59527_15_ITEM15_P197_S5	Based on the Company's historical experience in litigating product liability claims, including a significant number of dismissals, summary judgments and defense verdicts in many cases and immaterial settlement amounts, as well as the Company's current assessment of the underlying merits of the claims and applicable insurance, the Company believes resolution of these claims and proceedings, individually or in the aggregate, will not have a material effect on the Company's consolidated financial statements.

59527_16_ITEM1_P3_S0	ARTICLE I PURPOSE The Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. 2005 Deferred Compensation Plan (the Plan ) was established by Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc., effective December 30, 2004, to allow designated management and highly compensated employees to defer a portion of their current salary and bonus compensation.
59527_16_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Plan is hereby amended and restated as of January 1, 2016.
59527_16_ITEM1_P3_S2	This amendment and restatement shall apply to Deferral Commitments made for Deferral Periods commencing on or after January 1, 2016.
59527_16_ITEM1_P3_S3	The Plan is intended to comply with Section 409A of the Code, and shall be construed and interpreted in accordance with such intent.
59527_16_ITEM1_P3_S4	It is intended that the Plan will aid in attracting and retaining employees of exceptional ability by providing these benefits.
59527_16_ITEM1_P3_S5	The terms and conditions of the Plan are set forth below.

59527_16_ITEM1_P26_S0	ARTICLE III PARTICIPATION AND DEFERRALS Section 3.1.
59527_16_ITEM1_P27_S0	Eligibility to participate in the Plan for any Deferral Period is limited to those management and/or highly compensated Employees of the Corporation who are designated, from time to time, by the Committee.
59527_16_ITEM1_P27_S1	An eligible Employee may elect to participate in the Plan with respect to any Deferral Period by submitting a Participation Agreement to the Administrator by the last business day immediately preceding the applicable Deferral Period.
59527_16_ITEM1_P27_S2	A Participation Agreement must be submitted with respect to each Deferral Period for which a Participant elects a Deferral Commitment.
59527_16_ITEM1_P27_S3	Elections made in a Participation Agreement for a specific Deferral Period shall not carry over to subsequent Deferral Periods.
59527_16_ITEM1_P28_S0	Except as provided in Section 3.l(d), in the event that an individual first becomes eligible to participate during a Plan Year and wishes to elect a Deferral Commitment with respect to the Compensation, Performance Shares or RSUs earned by and payable to the individual during such Plan Year, a Participation Agreement must be submitted to the Administrator no later than thirty (30) days following such individual s initial eligibility.
59527_16_ITEM1_P28_S1	Any Deferral Commitments elected in such Participation Agreement shall be effective only with regard to Compensation or Performance Shares earned following the submission of the Participation Agreement to the Administrator.
59527_16_ITEM1_P29_S0	regard to RSUs that begin vesting on or following the submission of the Participation Agreement to the Administrator.
59527_16_ITEM1_P29_S1	If an eligible Employee does not submit a Participation Agreement within such period of time, such individual will not be eligible to participate in the Plan until the first day of a Deferral Period subsequent to the Deferral Period in which the individual initially became eligible to participate.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S0	In the event that an individual wishes to elect a Deferral Commitment with respect to the Compensation earned by and payable to the individual during the Plan Year beginning January 1, 2005, a Participation Agreement must be submitted to the Administrator on or before March 15, 2005.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S1	Any Deferral Commitments elected in such Participation Agreement shall be effective only with regard to Compensation that has not been paid or become payable at the time of submission.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S2	If an Eligible Employee does not submit a Participation Agreement within such period of time, such individual will not be eligible to participate in the Plan until the first day of a Deferral Period subsequent to the 2005 Plan Year.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S3	Participation in the Plan shall continue as long as the Participant is eligible to receive benefits under the Plan.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S4	If the Administrator determines that any Participant may not qualify as a member of a select group of management or highly compensated employees within the meaning of ERISA, or regulations promulgated thereunder, the Administrator may determine, in its sole discretion, that such Participant shall not be permitted to elect to defer Compensation, Performance Shares or RSUs with respect to any subsequent Deferral Period.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S5	(a) With respect to each Deferral Period, a Participant may elect to defer a specified dollar amount or percentage of his or her Compensation, provided the amount the Participant elects to defer under this Plan shall not exceed the sum of eighty percent (80%) of his or her Base Salary plus eighty percent (80%) of his or her Bonus plus eighty percent (80%) of his or her Cash LTIP with respect to such Deferral Period.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S6	With respect to each Deferral Period, a Participant may elect to defer a specified percentage of his or her Performance Shares or RSUs, provided that the amount the Participant elects to defer under this Plan shall not exceed one hundred percent (100%) of his or her Performance Shares or RSUs with respect to such Deferral Period.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S7	Such amount to be deferred shall be indicated in the Participant s Participation Agreement applicable to such Deferral Period.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S8	A Participant may choose to have amounts deferred under this Plan deducted from his or her Base Salary, Bonus, Cash LTIP, Performance Shares, RSUs or a combination of the foregoing, which shall also be indicated in the Participant s Participation Agreement applicable to such Deferral Period.
59527_16_ITEM1_P30_S9	(b) For the first Deferral Period with respect to each category of Compensation, Performance Shares or RSUs, a Participant may elect to defer all or any portion of his or her Base Salary, Bonus, Cash LTIP, Performance Shares and/or RSUs earned or payable after the later of the effective date of the Participation Agreement or the date of filing the Participation Agreement with the Administrator, provided each deferred amount for each Deferral Period does not exceed the annual limitations under this Section 3.3 computed for the calendar year in which such Deferral Period commences.
59527_16_ITEM1_P31_S0	ARTICLE IV PARTICIPANTS ACCOUNTS Section 4.1.
59527_16_ITEM1_P31_S1	The Corporation, through its accounting records, shall establish an Account for each Participant.
59527_16_ITEM1_P32_S0	appropriate in administering the Plan, including, but not limited to, a Deferred Performance Share Sub-account or a Deferred RSU Sub-account.
59527_16_ITEM1_P32_S1	Elective Deferred Compensation, Performance Shares and RSUs.
59527_16_ITEM1_P32_S2	A Participant s Compensation, Performance Shares and RSUs that are deferred pursuant to a Deferral Commitment shall be credited to the Participant s Account within thirty (30) days following the date the corresponding non-deferred portion of his or her Compensation or Performance Shares would have been paid to the Participant or the non-deferred portion of his or her RSUs (and any sequestered dividend equivalent rights) would have vested, as applicable.
59527_16_ITEM1_P32_S3	Any withholding of taxes or other amounts with respect to deferred Compensation, Performance Shares or RSUs which is required by state, federal or local laws shall be withheld from the Participant s deferred Compensation, Performance Shares or RSUs.
