59527_17_ITEM7_P66_S0	Product Liability Costs Product liability costs incurred can be volatile and are largely related to trial activity.
59527_17_ITEM7_P66_S1	The costs associated with these claims are predominantly defense costs which are recognized in the periods incurred.
59527_17_ITEM7_P66_S2	The long-term impact of product liability contingencies, in the aggregate, on operating results, operating cash flows and access to capital markets is difficult to assess, particularly since claims are in many different stages of development and the Company benefits significantly from cost sharing with co-defendants and insurance carriers.
59527_17_ITEM7_P66_S3	Moreover, the Company has been largely successful to date in its defense of these claims.
59527_17_ITEM7_P67_S0	The Company utilizes letters of credit to back certain payment and performance obligations.
59527_17_ITEM7_P67_S1	Letters of credit are subject to limits based on amounts outstanding under the Company's Credit Agreement.
59527_17_ITEM7_P68_S0	New Accounting Pronouncements Refer to Note 1 to the consolidated financial statements for a discussion of new accounting pronouncements.
59527_17_ITEM7_P69_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates The Company's consolidated financial statements are based on the selection and application of significant accounting policies, which require management to make estimates and assumptions.
59527_17_ITEM7_P69_S1	These estimates and assumptions are reviewed periodically by management and compared to historical trends to determine the accuracy of estimates and assumptions used.
59527_17_ITEM7_P69_S2	If warranted, these estimates and assumptions may be changed as current trends are assessed and updated.
59527_17_ITEM7_P70_S0	Historically, the Company's estimates have been determined to be reasonable.
59527_17_ITEM7_P70_S1	No material changes to the Company's accounting policies were made during 2016 .
59527_17_ITEM7_P70_S2	The Company believes the following accounting policies are some of the more critical judgment areas affecting its financial condition and results of operations.
59527_17_ITEM7_P71_S0	Legal and Tax Contingencies The Company, like other manufacturers, is subject from time to time to a variety of civil and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
59527_17_ITEM7_P71_S1	Such claims and litigation include, without limitation, product liability claims, regulatory claims and health, safety and environmental claims, some of which relate to cases alleging asbestos induced illnesses.
59527_17_ITEM7_P71_S2	The costs associated with these claims are predominantly defense costs, which are recognized in the periods incurred.
59527_17_ITEM7_P71_S3	Insurance reimbursements mitigate these costs and, where reimbursements are probable, they are recognized in the applicable period.
59527_17_ITEM7_P72_S0	With respect to costs other than defense costs (i.e., for liability and/or settlement or other resolution), reserves are recorded when it is probable that the contingencies will have an unfavorable outcome.
59527_17_ITEM7_P72_S1	The Company accrues its best estimate of the probable costs after a review of the facts with management and counsel and taking into account past experience.
59527_17_ITEM7_P72_S2	If an unfavorable outcome is determined to be reasonably possible but not probable, or if the amount of loss cannot be reasonably estimated, disclosure would be provided for material claims or litigation.
59527_17_ITEM7_P73_S0	Many of the current cases are in differing procedural stages and information on the circumstances of each claimant, which forms the basis for judgments as to the validity or ultimate disposition of such actions, varies greatly.
59527_17_ITEM7_P73_S1	Therefore, in many situations a range of possible losses cannot be made.
59527_17_ITEM7_P73_S2	Reserves are adjusted as facts and circumstances change and related management assessments of the underlying merits and the likelihood of outcomes change.
59527_17_ITEM7_P73_S3	Moreover, reserves only cover identified and/or asserted claims.
59527_17_ITEM7_P73_S4	Future claims could, therefore, give rise to increases to such reserves.
59527_17_ITEM7_P74_S0	The Company is subject to taxation from U.S. federal, state, municipal and international jurisdictions.
59527_17_ITEM7_P75_S0	The calculation of current income tax expense is based on the best information available and involves significant management judgment.
59527_17_ITEM7_P75_S1	The actual income tax liability for each jurisdiction in any year can in some instances be ultimately determined several years after the financial statements are published.
59527_17_ITEM7_P76_S0	The Company maintains liabilities for uncertain income tax positions for many jurisdictions.
59527_17_ITEM7_P76_S1	Liabilities are settled primarily through the completion of audits within each individual tax jurisdiction or the closing of a statute of limitation.
59527_17_ITEM7_P76_S2	Liabilities can also be affected by changes in applicable tax law or other factors, which may cause management to believe a revision of past estimates is appropriate.
59527_17_ITEM7_P76_S3	Management believes that an appropriate liability has been established for uncertain income tax positions; however, actual results may materially differ from these estimates.
59527_17_ITEM7_P76_S4	See Note 12 to the Company's consolidated financial statements for further discussion of uncertain income tax positions.
59527_17_ITEM7_P77_S0	Translation of Foreign Currencies Asset and liability accounts are translated into U.S. dollars using exchange rates in effect at the dates of the Consolidated Balance Sheets; revenue and expense accounts are translated at average monthly exchange rates.
59527_17_ITEM7_P77_S1	Translation adjustments are reflected as a component of Total equity.
59527_17_ITEM7_P77_S2	For subsidiaries operating in highly inflationary economies, both historical and current exchange rates are used in translating balance sheet accounts and translation adjustments are included in Net income.
59527_17_ITEM7_P78_S0	The translation of assets and liabilities originally denominated in foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is for consolidation purposes, and does not necessarily indicate that the Company could realize or settle the reported value of those assets and liabilities in U.S. dollars.
59527_17_ITEM7_P78_S1	Additionally, such a translation does not necessarily indicate that the Company could return or distribute the reported U.S. dollar value of the net equity of its foreign operations to shareholders.
59527_17_ITEM7_P79_S0	Foreign currency transaction gains and losses are included in Selling, general administrative expenses and were gains of $3,741 in 2016 and losses of $6,023 and $22,351 in 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
59527_17_ITEM7_P80_S0	Venezuela Highly Inflationary Economy The Company deconsolidated its subsidiary in Venezuela effective June 30, 2016 and began reporting the results under the cost method of accounting.
59527_17_ITEM7_P80_S1	Beginning July 1, 2016, the Company no longer includes the results of the Venezuelan subsidiary in its consolidated financial statements.
59527_17_ITEM7_P80_S2	Refer to Note 1 for additional information.
59527_17_ITEM7_P81_S0	Deferred Income Taxes Deferred income taxes are recognized at currently enacted tax rates for temporary differences between the GAAP and income tax basis of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carry-forwards.
59527_17_ITEM7_P81_S1	The Company does not provide deferred income taxes on unremitted earnings of certain non-U.S. subsidiaries, which are deemed indefinitely reinvested.
59527_17_ITEM7_P81_S2	It is not practicable to calculate the deferred taxes associated with the remittance of these earnings.
59527_17_ITEM7_P81_S3	Deferred income taxes associated with earnings that are not expected to be indefinitely reinvested were not significant.
59527_17_ITEM7_P81_S4	At December 31, 2016 , the Company had approximately $101,655 of gross deferred tax assets related to deductible temporary differences and tax loss and credit carry-forwards which may reduce taxable income in future years.
59527_17_ITEM7_P82_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, the Company assesses whether it is more likely than not that a portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
59527_17_ITEM7_P82_S1	The Company considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities, tax planning strategies and projected future taxable income in making this assessment.
59527_17_ITEM7_P82_S2	At December 31, 2016 , a valuation allowance of $47,849 was recorded against these deferred tax assets based on this assessment.
59527_17_ITEM7_P83_S0	more likely than not that the tax benefit of the remaining net deferred tax assets will be realized.
59527_17_ITEM7_P83_S1	The amount of net deferred tax assets considered realizable could be increased or reduced in the future if the Company's assessment of future taxable income or tax planning strategies changes.
59527_17_ITEM7_P84_S0	Pensions The Company maintains a number of defined benefit ("Pension") and defined contribution plans to provide retirement benefits for employees.
59527_17_ITEM7_P84_S1	These plans are maintained and contributions are made in accordance with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ("ERISA"), local statutory law or as determined by the Board of Directors.
59527_17_ITEM7_P84_S2	The plans generally provide benefits based upon years of service and compensation.
59527_17_ITEM7_P84_S3	Pension plans are funded except for a domestic non-qualified pension plan for certain key employees and certain foreign plan.
59527_17_ITEM7_P85_S0	In October 2016, the Company amended the Lincoln Electric Retirement Annuity Program ("RAP") and the Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan ("SERP") to freeze all benefit accruals for participants under the plans effective as of December 31, 2016.
59527_17_ITEM7_P85_S1	Refer to Note 11 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information.
59527_17_ITEM7_P86_S0	A substantial portion of the Company's pension amounts relate to its defined benefit plan in the United States.
59527_17_ITEM7_P87_S0	The fair value of plan assets is determined at December 31 of each year.
59527_17_ITEM7_P88_S0	A significant element in determining the Company's pension expense is the expected return on plan assets.
59527_17_ITEM7_P88_S1	At the end of each year, the expected return on plan assets is determined based on the weighted average expected return of the various asset classes in the plan's portfolio and the targeted allocation of plan assets.
59527_17_ITEM7_P88_S2	The asset class return is developed using historical asset return performance as well as current market conditions such as inflation, interest rates and equity market performance.
59527_17_ITEM7_P88_S3	The Company determined this rate to be 6.1% and 6.3% at December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
59527_17_ITEM7_P89_S0	The assumed long-term rate of return on assets is applied to the market value of plan assets.
59527_17_ITEM7_P89_S1	This produces the expected return on plan assets included in pension expense.
59527_17_ITEM7_P89_S2	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is deferred and, for frozen plans, is amortized over the average remaining life expectancy of plan participants expected to receive benefits under the plan.
59527_17_ITEM7_P90_S0	During 2016 , investment returns were 6.6% compared with a return of 0.9% in 2015 .
59527_17_ITEM7_P90_S1	A 25 basis point change in the expected return on plan assets would increase or decrease pension expense by approximately $1,200 .
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S0	Another significant element in determining the Company's pension expense is the discount rate for plan liabilities.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S1	To develop the discount rate assumption, the Company refers to the yield derived from matching projected pension payments with maturities of a portfolio of available non-callable bonds rated AA or an equivalent quality.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S2	The Company determined this rate to be 4.1% at December 31, 2016 and 4.5% at December 31, 2015 .
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S3	A 10 basis point change in the discount rate would increase or decrease pension expense by approximately $800 .
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S4	The Company's defined benefit plan expense was $13,988 , $162,815 and $12,395 in 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S5	Pension expense in 2016 includes net curtailment gains of $1,062, 2015 includes $142,738 in settlement charges and 2014 includes $1,773 in settlement charges.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S6	The Company's defined contribution plan expense was $8,361 , $10,082 and $11,088 in 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S7	Excluding the net curtailment gains in 2016, the Company expects total 2017 expense related to retirement plans to decrease by a range of approximately $6,000 to $8,000.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S8	The decrease is the result of lower amortization of deferred losses related to the defined benefit plan freeze, partially offset by higher defined contribution plan expense because of the new defined contribution plan.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S9	Refer to Note 11 for additional information.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S10	The Accumulated other comprehensive loss, excluding tax effects, recognized on the Consolidated Balance Sheet was $146,604 as of December 31, 2016 and $154,756 as of December 31, 2015 .
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S11	The decrease is primarily the result of the amortization of net losses and curtailments in 2016.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S12	The Company made voluntary contributions to its U.S. defined benefit plans of $20,086 , $47,124 and $21,175 in 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
59527_17_ITEM7_P91_S13	The Company does not expect to contribute to the defined benefit plans in the United States in 2017.
59527_17_ITEM7_P92_S0	Inventories Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
59527_17_ITEM7_P92_S1	Fixed manufacturing overhead costs are allocated to inventory based on normal production capacity and abnormal manufacturing costs are recognized as period costs.
59527_17_ITEM7_P93_S0	Cost for a substantial portion of U.S. inventories is determined on a LIFO basis.
59527_17_ITEM7_P93_S1	LIFO was used for 40% of total inventories at both December 31, 2016 and 2015.
59527_17_ITEM7_P94_S0	Cost of other inventories is determined by costing methods that approximate a first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) basis.
59527_17_ITEM7_P94_S1	The valuation of LIFO inventories is made at the end of each year based on inventory levels and costs at that time.
59527_17_ITEM7_P94_S2	Accordingly, interim LIFO calculations are based on management's estimates of expected year-end inventory levels and costs.
59527_17_ITEM7_P94_S3	Actual year-end inventory levels and costs may differ from interim LIFO inventory valuations.
59527_17_ITEM7_P94_S4	The excess of current cost over LIFO cost was $61,329 at December 31, 2016 and $59,765 at December 31, 2015 .
59527_17_ITEM7_P95_S0	The Company reviews the net realizable value of inventory on an on-going basis, with consideration given to deterioration, obsolescence and other factors.
59527_17_ITEM7_P95_S1	If actual market conditions differ from those projected by management, and the Company's estimates prove to be inaccurate, write-downs of inventory values and adjustments to Cost of goods sold may be required.
59527_17_ITEM7_P96_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_17_ITEM7_P96_S1	The Company maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses from the failure of its customers to make required payments for products delivered.
59527_17_ITEM7_P96_S2	The Company estimates this allowance based on the age of the related receivable, knowledge of the financial condition of customers, review of historical receivables and reserve trends and other pertinent information.
59527_17_ITEM7_P96_S3	If the financial condition of customers deteriorates or an unfavorable trend in receivable collections is experienced in the future, additional allowances may be required.
59527_17_ITEM7_P97_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_17_ITEM7_P98_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company periodically evaluates whether current facts or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of its depreciable long-lived assets to be held and used may not be recoverable.
59527_17_ITEM7_P98_S1	If such circumstances are determined to exist, an estimate of undiscounted future cash flows produced by the long-lived asset, or the appropriate grouping of assets, is compared to the carrying value to determine whether impairment exists.
59527_17_ITEM7_P99_S0	If an asset is determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized to the extent that carrying value exceeds fair value.
59527_17_ITEM7_P100_S0	Fair value is measured based on quoted market prices in active markets, if available.
59527_17_ITEM7_P100_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, the estimate of fair value is based on various valuation techniques, including the discounted value of estimated future cash flows.
59527_17_ITEM7_P101_S0	Goodwill and Intangibles The Company performs an annual impairment test of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets in the fourth quarter using the same dates each year or more frequently if changes in circumstances or the occurrence of events indicate potential impairment.
59527_17_ITEM7_P101_S1	The fair value of each indefinite-lived intangible asset is compared to its carrying value and an impairment charge is recorded if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
59527_17_ITEM7_P102_S0	For goodwill, the Company first assesses qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, and whether it is necessary to perform the quantitative goodwill impairment test.
59527_17_ITEM7_P102_S1	The quantitative test is required only if the Company concludes that it is more likely than not that a reporting unit s fair value is less than its carrying amount.
59527_17_ITEM7_P103_S0	The quantitative goodwill impairment analysis is a two-step process.
59527_17_ITEM7_P104_S0	Goodwill is tested by first comparing the fair value of each reporting unit with its carrying value.
59527_17_ITEM7_P104_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the implied value of goodwill is compared to its carrying value and impairment is recognized to the extent that the carrying value exceeds the implied fair value.
59527_17_ITEM7_P105_S0	Fair values are determined using established business valuation techniques and models developed by the Company, estimates of market participant assumptions of future cash flows, future growth rates and the applicable discount rates to value estimated cash flows.
59527_17_ITEM7_P105_S1	Changes in economic and operating conditions impacting these assumptions could result in asset impairments in future periods.
59527_17_ITEM7_P105_S2	The fair value of goodwill for all of the Company's reporting units exceeded its carrying value by at least 10% as of the testing date during the fourth quarter of 2016.
59527_17_ITEM7_P105_S3	Key assumptions in estimating the reporting unit's fair value include assumed market participant assumptions of revenue growth, operating margins and the rate used to discount future cash flows.
59527_17_ITEM7_P105_S4	Actual revenue growth and operating margins below the assumed market participant assumptions or an increase in the discount rate would have a negative impact on the fair value of the reporting unit that could result in a goodwill impairment charge in a future period.
59527_17_ITEM7_P106_S0	Revenue Recognition Substantially all of the Company's revenues are recognized when the risks and rewards of ownership and title to the product have transferred to the customer, which generally occurs at point of shipment.
59527_17_ITEM7_P106_S1	The Company recognizes any discounts, credits, returns, rebates and incentive programs based on reasonable estimates as a reduction of sales to arrive at Net sales at the same time the related revenue is recorded.
59527_17_ITEM7_P107_S0	For contracts accounted for under the percentage of completion method, revenue recognition is based upon the ratio of costs incurred to date compared with estimated total costs to complete.
59527_17_ITEM7_P107_S1	The cumulative impact of revisions to total estimated costs is reflected in the period of the change, including anticipated losses.
59527_17_ITEM7_P108_S0	The Company uses the Black-Scholes option pricing model for estimating fair values of options.
59527_17_ITEM7_P109_S0	The Company utilizes historical data in determining these assumptions.
59527_17_ITEM7_P109_S1	An increase or decrease in the assumptions or economic events outside of management's control could have an impact on the Black-Scholes model.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Included below is a sensitivity analysis based upon a hypothetical 10% weakening or strengthening in the U.S. dollar compared to foreign currency exchange rates at December 31, 2016 and a 100 basis point increase in effective interest rates at December 31, 2016 .
59527_17_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The derivative, borrowing and investment arrangements in effect at December 31, 2016 were compared to the hypothetical foreign exchange or interest rates in the sensitivity analysis to determine the effect on the Company's current period consolidated financial statements.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Foreign Currency Exchange Risk The Company enters into forward foreign exchange contracts principally to hedge the currency fluctuations in transactions denominated in foreign currencies, thereby limiting the Company's risk that would otherwise result from changes in exchange rates.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P1_S1	At December 31, 2016 , the Company hedged certain third-party and inter-company purchases and sales.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P1_S2	The gross notional amount of these foreign exchange contracts at December 31, 2016 was $36,385 .
59527_17_ITEM7A_P1_S3	At December 31, 2016 , a hypothetical 10% strengthening or weakening in the U.S. dollar would have changed Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) by $1,601.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P2_S0	In addition, the Company enters into forward foreign exchange contracts to hedge transaction exposures or significant cross-border intercompany loans by either purchasing or selling specified amounts of foreign currency at a specified date.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The gross notional amount of these foreign exchange contracts at December 31, 2016 was $261,168 .
59527_17_ITEM7A_P2_S2	A hypothetical 10% change in the year-end exchange rates would have resulted in an increase or decrease to Income before income taxes of $19,556 related to these positions.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P2_S3	However, any loss (or gain) resulting from a hypothetical 10% change would be offset by the associated gain (or loss) on the underlying balance sheet exposure and would ultimately not materially affect the Company s financial statements.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Commodity Price Risk From time to time, the Company uses various hedging arrangements to manage exposures to price risk from commodity purchases.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P3_S1	These hedging arrangements have the effect of fixing for specified periods the prices the Company will pay for the volume to which the hedge relates.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company had no commodity contracts outstanding during 2016 .
59527_17_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Interest Rate Risk At December 31, 2016 , the Company had various floating interest rate swaps used to convert $100,000 of its outstanding fixed-rate, long-term borrowings into short-term variable interest rates.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The fixed-rate nature of the remaining long-term borrowings limits the Company's exposure to changes in near-term interest rates.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P5_S2	An increase in interest expense resulting from a hypothetical increase of 100 basis points in the December 31, 2016 floating rate, would not materially affect the Company s financial statements.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P5_S3	A hypothetical 100 basis point increase to effective interest rates would also impact the fair value of interest rate swap.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P5_S4	However, any loss resulting from this hypothetical scenario would be offset by the associated gain on the underlying debt and have no impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P6_S0	The fair value of the Company's cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities at December 31, 2016 approximated cost due to their short-term duration.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P6_S1	These financial instruments are subject to concentrations of credit risk.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The Company has minimized this risk by entering into investments with a number of major banks and financial institutions and investing in high-quality instruments.
59527_17_ITEM7A_P6_S3	The Company does not expect any counter-parties to fail to meet their obligations.

59527_17_ITEM15_P12_S6	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
59527_17_ITEM15_P12_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
59527_17_ITEM15_P13_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
59527_17_ITEM15_P13_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
59527_17_ITEM15_P13_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
59527_17_ITEM15_P13_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
59527_17_ITEM15_P13_S4	In our opinion, Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2016 , based on the COSO criteria.
59527_17_ITEM15_P13_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2016 of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries and our report dated February 24, 2017 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.

59527_17_ITEM15_P19_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. and its wholly-owned and majority-owned subsidiaries for which it has a controlling interest (the "Company") after elimination of all inter-company accounts, transactions and profits.
59527_17_ITEM15_P20_S0	General Information The Company is a manufacturer of welding, cutting and brazing products.
59527_17_ITEM15_P20_S1	Welding products include arc welding power sources, plasma cutters, wire feeding systems, robotic welding packages, integrated automation systems, fume extraction equipment, consumable electrodes, fluxes and welding accessories and specialty welding consumables and fabrication.
59527_17_ITEM15_P20_S2	The Company's product offering also includes computer numeric controlled ("CNC") plasma and oxy-fuel cutting systems, regulators and torches used in oxy-fuel welding, cutting and brazing and consumables used in the brazing and soldering alloys market.
59527_17_ITEM15_P21_S0	Translation of Foreign Currencies Asset and liability accounts are translated into U.S. dollars using exchange rates in effect at the dates of the Consolidated Balance Sheets; revenue and expense accounts are translated at average monthly exchange rates.
59527_17_ITEM15_P21_S1	Translation adjustments are reflected as a component of Total equity.
59527_17_ITEM15_P21_S2	For subsidiaries operating in highly inflationary economies, both historical and current exchange rates are used in translating balance sheet accounts and translation adjustments are included in Net income.
59527_17_ITEM15_P22_S0	The translation of assets and liabilities originally denominated in foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is for consolidation purposes, and does not necessarily indicate that the Company could realize or settle the reported value of those assets and liabilities in U.S. dollars.
59527_17_ITEM15_P22_S1	Additionally, such a translation does not necessarily indicate that the Company could return or distribute the reported U.S. dollar value of the net equity of its foreign operations to shareholders.
59527_17_ITEM15_P23_S0	Foreign currency transaction gains and losses are included in Selling, general administrative expenses and were gains of $3,741 in 2016 and losses of $6,023 and $22,351 in 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
59527_17_ITEM15_P24_S0	Venezuela Deconsolidation Effective June 30, 2016, the Company determined that deteriorating conditions in Venezuela had led the Company to no longer meet the accounting criteria for control over its Venezuelan subsidiary.
59527_17_ITEM15_P25_S0	The restrictive exchange controls in Venezuela and the lack of access to U.S. dollars through official currency exchange mechanisms resulted in an other-than-temporary lack of exchangeability between the Venezuela bolivar and the U.S. dollar, and restricted the Venezuela operations ability to pay dividends and satisfy other obligations denominated in U.S. dollars.
59527_17_ITEM15_P25_S1	Additionally, other operating restrictions including government controls on pricing, profits, imports and restrictive labor laws significantly impacted the Company s ability to make key operational decisions, including the ability to manage its capital structure, purchasing, product pricing and labor relations.
59527_17_ITEM15_P25_S2	Therefore, as of June 30, 2016, the Company deconsolidated the financial statements of its subsidiary in Venezuela and began reporting the results under the cost method of accounting.
59527_17_ITEM15_P25_S3	As a result of the deconsolidation, the Company recorded a pretax charge of $34,348 ( $33,251 after-tax) in the second quarter of 2016.
59527_17_ITEM15_P25_S4	The pretax charge includes the write-off of the Company s investment in Venezuela, including all inter-company balances and $283 of Cash and cash equivalents.
59527_17_ITEM15_P25_S5	Additionally, the charge includes foreign currency translation losses and pension losses previously included in Accumulated other comprehensive loss.
59527_17_ITEM15_P25_S6	Beginning July 1, 2016, the Company no longer includes the results of the Venezuelan subsidiary in its consolidated financial statements.
59527_17_ITEM15_P26_S0	Under the cost method of accounting, if cash were to be received from the Venezuela entity in future periods from the sale of inventory, dividends or royalties, income would be recognized.
59527_17_ITEM15_P26_S1	The Company does not anticipate dividend or royalty payments being made in the foreseeable future and has no outstanding receivables or payables with the Venezuelan entity.
59527_17_ITEM15_P26_S2	The factors that led to the Company s conclusion to deconsolidate at June 30, 2016 continued to exist through December 31, 2016.
59527_17_ITEM15_P26_S3	The Company expects these conditions to continue for the foreseeable future.
59527_17_ITEM15_P27_S0	Subsequent to the deconsolidation under the voting interest consolidation model, the Company determined that the Venezuelan subsidiary is considered to be a variable interest entity ("VIE").
59527_17_ITEM15_P27_S1	As the Company does not have the power to direct the activities that most significantly affect the Venezuela subsidiary's economic performance, the Company is not the primary beneficiary of the VIE and therefore would not consolidate the entity under the VIE consolidation model.
59527_17_ITEM15_P28_S0	Additionally, the Company has no remaining financial commitments to the Venezuelan subsidiary and therefore believes the exposure to future losses are not material.
59527_17_ITEM15_P28_S1	Prior to deconsolidation, the financial statements of the Company s Venezuelan operation had been reported under highly inflationary accounting rules since January 1, 2010.
59527_17_ITEM15_P28_S2	Under highly inflationary accounting, the financial statements of the Company s Venezuelan operation had been remeasured into the Company s reporting currency and exchange gains and losses from the remeasurement of monetary assets and liabilities were reflected in current earnings.
59527_17_ITEM15_P29_S0	In February 2015, the Venezuelan government announced a new exchange market called the Marginal Currency System ( SIMADI ), which allowed for trading based on supply and demand.
59527_17_ITEM15_P29_S1	At September 30, 2015, the Company determined that the rate used in remeasuring the Venezuelan operation's financial statements into U.S. dollars would change to the SIMADI rate (now known as "DICOM"), as the SIMADI rate most appropriately approximated the rates used to transact business in its Venezuelan operations.
59527_17_ITEM15_P29_S2	At September 30, 2015, the SIMADI rate was 199.4 bolivars to the U.S. dollar, resulting in a remeasurement charge on the bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position of $4,334 .
59527_17_ITEM15_P29_S3	This foreign exchange loss was recorded in Selling, general administrative expenses during the three months ended September 30, 2015.
59527_17_ITEM15_P29_S4	Additionally, the Company recorded a lower of cost or net realizable value inventory adjustments of $22,880 within Cost of goods sold, related to the adoption of the SIMADI rate.
59527_17_ITEM15_P30_S0	In January 2014, the exchange rate applicable to the settlement of certain transactions, including payments of dividends and royalties, changed to utilize the Complementary System of Foreign Currency Administration ("SICAD") auction-based exchange rate (the "SICAD rate").
59527_17_ITEM15_P30_S1	As of March 31, 2014, the Company determined that the rate used in remeasuring the Venezuelan operation's financial statements into U.S. dollars would change to the SICAD rate as future remittances for dividend payments could be transacted at the SICAD rate.
59527_17_ITEM15_P30_S2	As of March 31, 2014, the SICAD rate was 10.7 bolivars to the U.S. dollar, which resulted in a remeasurement loss on the bolivar-denominated monetary net asset position of $17,665 which was recorded in Selling, general administrative expenses in the three months ended March 31, 2014.
59527_17_ITEM15_P30_S3	Additionally, the Company incurred higher Cost of goods sold of $3,468 during the second quarter of 2014 related to the adoption of the SICAD rate.
59527_17_ITEM15_P31_S0	The Company considers all highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.
59527_17_ITEM15_P31_S1	The Company maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses from the failure of its customers to make required payments for products delivered.
59527_17_ITEM15_P31_S2	The Company estimates this allowance based on the age of the related receivable, knowledge of the financial condition of customers, review of historical receivables and reserve trends and other pertinent information.
59527_17_ITEM15_P31_S3	If the financial condition of customers deteriorates or an unfavorable trend in receivable collections is experienced in the future, additional allowances may be required.
59527_17_ITEM15_P32_S0	Historically, the Company's reserves have approximated actual experience.
59527_17_ITEM15_P32_S1	Inventories Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
59527_17_ITEM15_P32_S2	Fixed manufacturing overhead costs are allocated to inventory based on normal production capacity and abnormal manufacturing costs are recognized as period costs.
59527_17_ITEM15_P33_S0	Cost for a substantial portion of U.S. inventories is determined on a last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) basis.
59527_17_ITEM15_P33_S1	LIFO was used for 40% of total inventories at both December 31, 2016 and 2015.
59527_17_ITEM15_P34_S0	Cost of other inventories is determined by costing methods that approximate a first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) basis.
59527_17_ITEM15_P34_S1	Refer to Note 15 for additional details.
59527_17_ITEM15_P35_S0	Reserves are maintained for estimated obsolescence or excess inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated net realizable value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
59527_17_ITEM15_P35_S1	The reserve for excess and obsolete inventory was $19,252 and $19,198 at December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
59527_17_ITEM15_P36_S0	Marketable Securities The Company's marketable securities consist of short-term highly liquid investments classified as available-for-sale and recorded at fair value using quoted market prices for similar assets at the end of the reporting period.
59527_17_ITEM15_P36_S1	The marketable securities are included in Other current assets in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets.
59527_17_ITEM15_P36_S2	Refer to Note 14 for fair value information.
59527_17_ITEM15_P37_S0	Prepaid Expenses Prepaid expenses include prepaid insurance, prepaid rent, prepaid service contracts and other prepaid items.
59527_17_ITEM15_P37_S1	Prepaid expenses are included in Other current assets in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets and amounted to $12,139 at December 31, 2016 and $11,624 at December 31, 2015.
59527_17_ITEM15_P38_S0	Equity Investments Investments in businesses in which the Company does not have a controlling interest and holds between a 20% and 50% ownership interest are accounted for using the equity method of accounting.
59527_17_ITEM15_P38_S1	The Company's 50% ownership interest in equity investments includes investments in Turkey and Chile.
59527_17_ITEM15_P38_S2	The amount of retained earnings that represents undistributed earnings of 50% or less owned equity investments was $19,333 at December 31, 2016 and $19,072 at December 31, 2015 .
59527_17_ITEM15_P39_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment Property, plant and equipment are stated at cost and include improvements which significantly increase capacities or extend the useful lives of existing plant and equipment.
59527_17_ITEM15_P40_S0	Depreciation and amortization are computed using a straight-line method over useful lives ranging from three to 20 years for machinery, tools and equipment, and up to 40 years for buildings.
59527_17_ITEM15_P41_S0	Net gains or losses related to asset dispositions are recognized in earnings in the period in which dispositions occur.
59527_17_ITEM15_P41_S1	Routine maintenance, repairs and replacements are expensed as incurred.
59527_17_ITEM15_P42_S0	The Company capitalizes interest costs associated with long-term construction in progress.
59527_17_ITEM15_P42_S1	Property, plant and equipment, net in the Consolidated Balance Sheet is comprised of the following components:
59527_17_ITEM15_P43_S0	Goodwill and Intangibles Goodwill is recorded when the cost of acquired businesses exceeds the fair value of the identifiable net assets acquired.
59527_17_ITEM15_P43_S1	Intangible assets other than goodwill are recorded at fair value at the time acquired or at cost, if applicable.
59527_17_ITEM15_P43_S2	Intangible assets that do not have indefinite lives are amortized in line with the pattern in which the economic benefits of the intangible asset are consumed.
59527_17_ITEM15_P43_S3	If the pattern of economic benefit cannot be reliably determined, the intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line basis over the shorter of the legal or estimated life.
59527_17_ITEM15_P43_S4	Goodwill and indefinite-lived intangibles assets are not amortized, but are tested for impairment in the fourth quarter using the same dates each year or more frequently if changes in circumstances or the occurrence of events indicate potential impairment.
59527_17_ITEM15_P43_S5	The fair value of each indefinite-lived intangible asset is compared to its carrying value and an impairment charge is recorded if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
59527_17_ITEM15_P44_S0	For goodwill, the Company first assesses qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, and whether it is necessary to perform the quantitative goodwill impairment test.
59527_17_ITEM15_P44_S1	The quantitative test is required only if the Company concludes that it is more likely than not that a reporting unit s fair value is less than its carrying amount.
59527_17_ITEM15_P45_S0	The quantitative goodwill impairment analysis is a two-step process.
59527_17_ITEM15_P46_S0	Goodwill is tested by first comparing the fair value of each reporting unit with its carrying value.
59527_17_ITEM15_P46_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the implied value of goodwill is compared to its carrying value and impairment is recognized to the extent that the carrying value exceeds the implied fair value.
59527_17_ITEM15_P47_S0	Fair values are determined using established business valuation techniques and models developed by the Company, estimates of market participant assumptions of future cash flows, future growth rates and the applicable discount rates to value estimated cash flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P47_S1	Changes in economic and operating conditions impacting these assumptions could result in asset impairments in future periods.
59527_17_ITEM15_P47_S2	Refer to Note 4 for additional details.
59527_17_ITEM15_P48_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company periodically evaluates whether current facts or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of its depreciable long-lived assets to be held and used may not be recoverable.
59527_17_ITEM15_P49_S0	undiscounted future cash flows produced by the long-lived asset, or the appropriate grouping of assets, is compared to the carrying value to determine whether impairment exists.
59527_17_ITEM15_P49_S1	If an asset is determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized to the extent that carrying value exceeds fair value.
59527_17_ITEM15_P50_S0	Fair value is measured based on quoted market prices in active markets, if available.
59527_17_ITEM15_P50_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, the estimate of fair value is based on various valuation techniques, including the discounted value of estimated future cash flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P50_S2	Refer to Notes 4 and 6 for additional details.
59527_17_ITEM15_P51_S0	Fair Value Measurements Financial assets and liabilities, such as the Company's defined benefit pension plan assets and derivative contracts, are valued at fair value using the market and income valuation approaches.
59527_17_ITEM15_P51_S1	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
59527_17_ITEM15_P51_S2	The Company uses the market approach to value similar assets and liabilities in active markets and the income approach that consists of discounted cash flow models that take into account the present value of future cash flows under the terms of the contracts using current market information as of the reporting date.
59527_17_ITEM15_P52_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
59527_17_ITEM15_P53_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
59527_17_ITEM15_P54_S0	Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or other means.
59527_17_ITEM15_P55_S0	If the asset or liability has a specific (contractual) term, the Level 2 input must be observable for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
59527_17_ITEM15_P56_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair value measurement.
59527_17_ITEM15_P57_S0	Refer to Notes 11 and 14 for additional details.
59527_17_ITEM15_P58_S0	The Company accrues for product warranty claims based on historical experience and the expected material and labor costs to provide warranty service.
59527_17_ITEM15_P58_S1	Warranty services are generally provided for periods up to three years from the date of sale.
59527_17_ITEM15_P58_S2	The accrual for product warranty claims is included in Other current liabilities.
59527_17_ITEM15_P59_S0	Revenue Recognition Substantially all of the Company's revenues are recognized when the risks and rewards of ownership and title to the product have transferred to the customer, which generally occurs at point of shipment.
59527_17_ITEM15_P59_S1	The Company recognizes any discounts, credits, returns, rebates and incentive programs based on reasonable estimates as a reduction of sales to arrive at Net sales at the same time the related revenue is recorded.
59527_17_ITEM15_P60_S0	For contracts accounted for under the percentage of completion method, revenue recognition is based upon the ratio of costs incurred to date compared with estimated total costs to complete.
59527_17_ITEM15_P60_S1	The cumulative impact of revisions to total estimated costs is reflected in the period of the change, including anticipated losses.
59527_17_ITEM15_P61_S0	Distribution Costs Distribution costs, including warehousing and freight related to product shipments, are included in Cost of goods sold.
59527_17_ITEM15_P62_S0	Stock-Based Compensation Expense is recognized for all awards of stock-based compensation by allocating the aggregate grant date fair value over the vesting period.
59527_17_ITEM15_P62_S1	No expense is recognized for any stock options, restricted or deferred shares or restricted stock units ultimately forfeited because the recipients fail to meet vesting requirements.
59527_17_ITEM15_P62_S2	Common stock issuable upon the exercise of employee stock options is excluded from the calculation of diluted earnings per share when the calculation of option equivalent shares is anti-dilutive.
59527_17_ITEM15_P62_S3	Refer to Note 9 for additional details.
59527_17_ITEM15_P63_S0	Financial Instruments The Company uses derivative instruments to manage exposures to interest rates, commodity prices and currency exchange rate fluctuations on certain purchase and sales transactions, balance sheet and net investment exposures.
59527_17_ITEM15_P64_S0	hedge currency and commodity exposures are generally written on a short-term basis but may cover exposures for up to two years while interest rate contracts may cover longer periods consistent with the terms of the underlying debt.
59527_17_ITEM15_P64_S1	The Company does not enter into derivatives for trading or speculative purposes.
59527_17_ITEM15_P64_S2	All derivatives are recognized at fair value on the Company's Consolidated Balance Sheets.
59527_17_ITEM15_P64_S3	The accounting for gains and losses resulting from changes in fair value depends on the use of the derivative and whether it is designated and qualifies for hedge accounting.
59527_17_ITEM15_P64_S4	The Company formally documents the relationship of the hedge with the hedged item as well as the risk-management strategy for all designated hedges.
59527_17_ITEM15_P65_S0	Both at inception and on an ongoing basis, the hedging instrument is assessed as to its effectiveness, when applicable.
59527_17_ITEM15_P65_S1	If and when a derivative is determined not to be highly effective as a hedge, the underlying hedged transaction is no longer likely to occur, or the derivative is terminated, hedge accounting is discontinued.
59527_17_ITEM15_P66_S0	The cash flows from settled derivative contracts are recognized in operating activities in the Company's Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P66_S1	The Company is subject to the credit risk of the counterparties to derivative instruments.
59527_17_ITEM15_P66_S2	Counterparties include a number of major banks and financial institutions.
59527_17_ITEM15_P66_S3	The Company manages individual counterparty exposure by monitoring the credit rating of the counterparty and the size of financial commitments and exposures between the Company and the counterparty.
59527_17_ITEM15_P67_S0	Cash flow hedges Certain foreign currency forward contracts are qualified and designated as cash flow hedges (i.e., hedging the exposure to variability in expected future cash flows).
59527_17_ITEM15_P67_S1	The effective portion of the fair value unrealized gain or loss on cash flow hedges are reported as a component of Accumulated other comprehensive income ("AOCI") with offsetting amounts recorded as Other current assets, Other assets, Other current liabilities or Other liabilities depending on the position and the duration of the contract.
59527_17_ITEM15_P67_S2	At settlement, the realized gain or loss is recorded in Cost of goods sold or sales for hedges of purchases and sales, respectively, in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings.
59527_17_ITEM15_P68_S0	The ineffective portion on cash flow hedges is recognized in current earnings.
59527_17_ITEM15_P69_S0	Fair value hedges Certain interest rate swap agreements were qualified and designated as fair value hedges.
59527_17_ITEM15_P69_S1	The interest rate swap agreements designated as fair value hedges meet the shortcut method requirements under accounting standards for derivatives and hedging.
59527_17_ITEM15_P69_S2	Accordingly, changes in the fair value of these agreements are considered to exactly offset changes in the fair value of the underlying long-term debt.
59527_17_ITEM15_P69_S3	The effective portion of the changes in fair value are recorded in Other assets or Other liabilities with offsetting amounts recorded as a fair value adjustment to the carrying value of Long-term debt, less current portion.
59527_17_ITEM15_P69_S4	Net investment hedges For derivative instruments that qualify as a net investment hedge (i.e., hedging the foreign currency exposure of a net investment in a foreign operation), the effective portion of the fair value gains or losses are recognized in AOCI with offsetting amounts recorded as Other current assets, Other assets, Other current liabilities or Other liabilities depending on the position and the duration of the contract.
59527_17_ITEM15_P69_S5	The gains or losses are subsequently reclassified to Selling, general and administrative expenses, as the underlying hedged investment is liquidated.
59527_17_ITEM15_P70_S0	Derivatives not designated as hedging instruments The Company has certain derivative instruments which are not designated as hedging instruments including foreign exchange forward contracts and commodity price contracts.
59527_17_ITEM15_P70_S1	Foreign exchange forward contracts are held as economic hedges of certain balance sheet exposures and qualify as fair value hedges (i.e., hedging the exposure to changes in the fair value of an asset or a liability).
59527_17_ITEM15_P70_S2	The gains or losses on t hese contracts are recognized in Selling, general and administrative expenses, offsetting the losses or gains on the exposures being hedged.
59527_17_ITEM15_P71_S0	Short-term commodity price contracts are not designated as hedges.
59527_17_ITEM15_P71_S1	Realized and unrealized gains and losses on these contracts are recognized in Costs of goods sold.
59527_17_ITEM15_P71_S2	Refer to Note 13 for additional details.
59527_17_ITEM15_P72_S0	Research and Development Research and development costs are charged to Selling, general administrative expenses as incurred and totaled $44,720 , $47,182 and $43,256 in 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
59527_17_ITEM15_P73_S0	Bonus Included in Selling, general administrative expenses are the costs related to the Company's discretionary employee bonus programs, which for certain U.S.-based employees are net of hospitalization costs.
59527_17_ITEM15_P73_S1	Bonus costs were $83,620 in 2016 , $98,651 in 2015 and $128,478 in 2014 .
59527_17_ITEM15_P74_S0	Income Taxes Deferred income taxes are recognized at currently enacted tax rates for temporary differences between the GAAP and income tax basis of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carry-forwards.
59527_17_ITEM15_P75_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, the Company assesses whether it is more likely than not that a portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
59527_17_ITEM15_P75_S1	Refer to Note 12 for additional details.

59527_17_ITEM15_P76_S1	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
59527_17_ITEM15_P77_S0	Reclassification Certain reclassifications have been made to prior year financial statements to conform to current year classifications.
59527_17_ITEM15_P78_S0	The following section provides a description of new accounting pronouncements ("Accounting Standard Update" or "ASU") issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") that are applicable to the Company.
59527_17_ITEM15_P78_S1	The following ASUs were adopted as of January 1, 2016 and did not have a significant financial impact on the Company's financial statements:
59527_17_ITEM15_P79_S0	No. 2015-16, Business Combinations (Topic 805): Simplifying the Accounting for Measurement-Period Adjustments , issued September 2015 ASU 2015-16 requires an acquiring entity to: recognize adjustments to provisional amounts identified during the measurement period in the reporting period in which the adjustment amounts are determined; record the effect on earnings of changes in depreciation, amortization or other income effects, if any, as a result of the change to the provisional amounts; present separately on the face of the statement of operations or disclose in the notes the portion of the amount recorded in current-period earnings that would have been recorded in previous reporting periods if the adjustment had been recognized as of the acquisition date.
59527_17_ITEM15_P79_S1	ASU No. 2015-07, Fair Value Measurement (Topic 820): Disclosures for Investments in Certain Entities That Calculate Net Asset Value per Share , issued May 2015 ASU 2015-07 removes the requirement to categorize within the fair value hierarchy all investments for which fair value is measured using the net asset value per share practical expedient and removes the requirement to make certain disclosures for these investments.
59527_17_ITEM15_P79_S2	ASU No. 2015-02, Consolidation (Topic 810): Amendments to the Consolidation Analysis , issued February 2015 ASU 2015-02 modifies the evaluation of whether limited partnership and similar legal entities are VIEs or voting interest entities, affects the consolidation analysis of reporting entities that are involved with VIEs and provides scope exceptions.
59527_17_ITEM15_P80_S0	New Accounting Pronouncements to be Adopted:
59527_17_ITEM15_P81_S0	ASU 2016-09 amends several aspects of the accounting for share-based payment transactions including the income tax consequences, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities and classification on the statement of cash flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P81_S1	The Company adopted ASU 2016-09 effective January 1, 2017.
59527_17_ITEM15_P81_S2	ASU 2016-09 requires prospective recognition of excess tax benefits and deficiencies resulting from stock-based compensation awards vesting and exercises be recognized as a discrete income tax adjustment in the income statement.
59527_17_ITEM15_P81_S3	Previously, these amounts were recognized in Additional paid-in capital.
59527_17_ITEM15_P82_S0	The impact of the tax adjustment will vary depending on the amount and timing of stock options.
59527_17_ITEM15_P82_S1	In addition, ASU 2016-09 requires excess tax benefits and deficiencies to be prospectively excluded from the assumed future proceeds in the calculation of diluted shares.
59527_17_ITEM15_P82_S2	The Company expects this change to increase the number of diluted shares in subsequent periods, but not have a material impact on diluted earnings per share.
59527_17_ITEM15_P83_S0	ASU 2016-09 requires that excess tax benefits from share based compensation awards be reported as operating activities in the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P83_S1	Previously, this activity was included in financing activities on the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P83_S2	The Company has elected to apply this change on a retrospective basis.
59527_17_ITEM15_P84_S0	activities to increase by the amount reported as Excess tax benefits from stock-based compensation on the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P84_S1	ASU 2016-09 requires that employee taxes paid when an employer withholds shares for tax-withholding purposes be reported as financing activities in the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows on a retrospective basis.
59527_17_ITEM15_P84_S2	Previously, this activity was included in operating activities.
59527_17_ITEM15_P84_S3	The Company expects the impact of this change to be immaterial to the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P84_S4	The Company has elected to continue to estimate the number of stock-based awards expected to vest, as permitted by ASU 2016-09, rather than electing to account for forfeitures as they occur.
59527_17_ITEM15_P85_S0	ASU 2014-09 requires an entity to recognize revenue in a manner that depicts the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
59527_17_ITEM15_P85_S1	The amendment also specifies the accounting of some costs to obtain or fulfill a contract with a customer and expands the disclosure requirements around contracts with customers.
59527_17_ITEM15_P86_S0	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-14, " Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Deferral of the Effective Date ," which deferred the effective date of ASU 2014-09 to annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, and interim periods within those fiscal years.
59527_17_ITEM15_P86_S1	Early adoption is permitted as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
59527_17_ITEM15_P86_S2	An entity can either adopt this amendment retrospectively to each prior reporting period presented or retrospectively with the cumulative effect of initially applying the update recognized at the date of initial application.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S0	To evaluate the impact of adopting this new guidance on the consolidated financial statements, the Company completed a scoping analysis of revenue streams against the requirements of the standard.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S1	In addition, the Company is in the process of reviewing customer contracts, as well as identifying and implementing changes to processes and controls to meet the standard s reporting and disclosure requirements.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S2	ASU 2014-09 will accelerate the timing of when certain transactions are recognized as revenue upon adoption of the guidance s control model.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S3	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of ASU 2014-09.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S4	The Company is currently evaluating the impact on its financial statements of the following ASUs: Standard Description ASU No. 2017-04, Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment , issued January 2017.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S5	ASU 2017-04 simplifies the subsequent measurement of goodwill by eliminating Step 2 from the goodwill impairment test.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S6	Under this ASU, an entity should perform the Step 1 annual, or interim, goodwill impairment test by comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S7	If the carrying amount exceeds the fair value, an entity should recognize an impairment charge for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit s fair value, not to exceed the total amount of goodwill allocated to that reporting unit.
59527_17_ITEM15_P87_S8	An entity still has the option to perform the qualitative assessment for a reporting unit to determine if the quantitative impairment test is necessary.
59527_17_ITEM15_P88_S0	The ASU is effective January 1, 2020, early adoption is permitted and the ASU should be applied prospectively.
59527_17_ITEM15_P89_S0	ASU No. 2016-18, Statement of Cash Flows(Topic 230): Restricted Cash, issued November 2016.
59527_17_ITEM15_P89_S1	ASU 2016-18 requires amounts generally described as restricted cash and restricted cash equivalents be included with cash and cash equivalents when reconciling the beginning-of-period and end-of-period total amounts shown on the statement of cash flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P89_S2	The ASU is effective January 1, 2018, early adoption is permitted and the ASU should be applied retrospectively.
59527_17_ITEM15_P90_S0	ASU No. 2016-16 , Income Taxes (Topic 740): Intra-Entity Transfers of Assets Other Than Inventory, issued October 2016.
59527_17_ITEM15_P90_S1	ASU 2016-16 requires an entity to recognize the income tax consequences of an intra-entity transfer of an asset other than inventory when the transfer occurs.
59527_17_ITEM15_P90_S2	The ASU is effective January 1, 2018, early adoption is permitted and the ASU should be applied using a modified retrospective approach, through a cumulative-effect adjustment directly to retained earnings, as of the beginning of the period of adoption.
59527_17_ITEM15_P91_S0	ASU 2016-15, Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230): Classification of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments, issued August 2016.
59527_17_ITEM15_P91_S1	ASU 2016-15 reduces existing diversity in practice by addressing eight specific cash flow issues related to how certain cash receipts and cash payments are presented and classified in the statement of cash flows.
59527_17_ITEM15_P91_S2	The ASU is effective January 1, 2018, early adoption is permitted and the ASU should be applied retrospectively (or prospectively as of earliest date practicable).
59527_17_ITEM15_P92_S0	ASU No. 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842) , issued February 2016.
59527_17_ITEM15_P92_S1	ASU 2016-02 aims to increase transparency and comparability among organizations by recognizing lease assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet and requiring disclosure of key information about leasing agreements.
59527_17_ITEM15_P93_S0	Entities are required to recognize and measure leases at the beginning of the earliest period presented using a modified retrospective approach.
59527_17_ITEM15_P93_S1	The ASU is effective January 1, 2019, early adoption is permitted and the ASU should be applied using either a modified retrospective or modified retrospective with practical expedients approach.

59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S0	NOTE 3 ACQUISITIONS During May 2016, the Company acquired Vizient Manufacturing Solutions ("Vizient").
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S1	Vizient, based in Bettendorf, Iowa, is a robotic integrator specializing in custom engineered tooling and automated arc welding systems for general and heavy fabrication applications.
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S2	The acquisition assisted in diversifying end-market exposure and broadening global growth opportunities.
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S3	During August 2015, the Company acquired Specialised Welding Products ("SWP").
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S4	SWP, based in Melbourne, Australia, is a provider of specialty welding consumables and fabrication, maintenance and repair services for alloy and wear resistant products commonly used in mining and energy sector applications.
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S5	The acquisition broadened the Company's presence and specialty alloy offering in Australia and New Zealand.
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S6	Also in August 2015, the Company acquired Rimrock Holdings Corporation ("Rimrock").
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S7	Rimrock is a manufacturer of industrial automation products and robotic systems with two divisions, Wolf Robotics LLC, based in Fort Collins, Colorado, and Rimrock Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio.
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S8	Wolf Robotics integrates robotic welding and cutting systems predominantly for heavy fabrication and transportation OEMs and suppliers.
59527_17_ITEM15_P96_S9	The acquisition advanced the Company's leadership position in automated welding and cutting solutions.
59527_17_ITEM15_P97_S0	Rimrock Corporation designs and manufactures automated spray systems and turnkey robotic systems for the die casting, foundry and forging markets.
59527_17_ITEM15_P98_S0	During October 2014, the Company acquired substantially all of the assets of Easom Automation Systems, Inc. ("Easom").
59527_17_ITEM15_P98_S1	Easom, based in Detroit, Michigan, is an integrator and manufacturer of automation and positioning solutions, serving heavy fabrication, aerospace and automotive OEMs and suppliers.
59527_17_ITEM15_P98_S2	The acquisition advanced the Company's leadership position in automated welding and cutting solutions.
59527_17_ITEM15_P98_S3	In addition, during 2014, the Company acquired the remaining interest in its majority-owned joint venture, Harris Soldas Especiais S.A. Pro forma information related to these acquisitions has not been presented because the impact on the Company's Consolidated Statements of Income is not material.
59527_17_ITEM15_P98_S4	Acquired companies are included in the Company's consolidated financial statements as of the date of acquisition.

59527_17_ITEM15_P105_S0	The Company's primary business is the design and manufacture of arc welding and cutting products, manufacturing a broad line of arc welding equipment, consumable welding products and other welding and cutting products.
59527_17_ITEM15_P105_S1	Welding products include arc welding power sources, CNC and plasma cutters, wire feeding systems, robotic welding packages, integrated automation systems, fume extraction equipment, consumable electrodes, fluxes and welding accessories and specialty welding consumables and fabrication.
59527_17_ITEM15_P105_S2	The Company's product offering also includes oxy-fuel cutting systems and regulators and torches used in oxy-fuel welding, cutting and brazing.
59527_17_ITEM15_P105_S3	In addition, the Company has a leading global position in the brazing and soldering alloys market.
59527_17_ITEM15_P105_S4	During the first quarter of 2016, the Company realigned its organizational and leadership structure into three operating segments to support growth strategies and enhance the utilization of the Company's worldwide resources and global sourcing initiatives.
59527_17_ITEM15_P105_S5	The operating segments consist of Americas Welding, International Welding and The Harris Products Group.
59527_17_ITEM15_P106_S0	The Americas Welding segment includes welding operations in North and South America.
59527_17_ITEM15_P106_S1	The International Welding segment primarily includes welding operations in Europe, Africa, Asia and Australia.
59527_17_ITEM15_P107_S0	The Harris Products Group includes the Company's global cutting, soldering and brazing businesses as well as its retail business in the United States.
59527_17_ITEM15_P107_S1	All prior period results have been revised to reflect the realigned segment structure.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S0	Segment performance is measured and resources are allocated based on a number of factors, the primary profit measure being adjusted earnings before interest and income taxes ("Adjusted EBIT").
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S1	EBIT is defined as Operating income plus Equity earnings in affiliates and Other income.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S2	Segment EBIT is adjusted for special items as determined by management such as the impact of rationalization activities, certain asset impairment charges and gains or losses on disposals of assets.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S3	The accounting principles applied at the operating segment level are generally the same as those applied at the consolidated financial statement level with the exception of LIFO.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S4	Segment assets include inventories measured on a FIFO basis while consolidated inventories include inventories reported on a LIFO basis.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S5	Segment and consolidated income before interest and income taxes include the effect of inventories reported on a LIFO basis.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S6	At December 31, 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , approximately 40% of total inventories were valued using the LIFO method.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S7	LIFO is used for a substantial portion of U.S. inventories included in Americas Welding.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S8	Inter-segment sales are recorded at agreed upon prices that approximate arm's length prices and are eliminated in consolidation.
59527_17_ITEM15_P108_S9	Corporate-level expenses are allocated to the operating segments.

59527_17_ITEM15_P217_S0	NOTE 17 CONTINGENCIES The Company, like other manufacturers, is subject from time to time to a variety of civil and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
59527_17_ITEM15_P217_S1	Such claims and litigation include, without limitation, product liability claims, regulatory claims and health, safety and environmental claims, some of which relate to cases alleging asbestos induced illnesses.
59527_17_ITEM15_P218_S0	The claimants in the asbestos cases seek compensatory and punitive damages, in most cases for unspecified amounts.
59527_17_ITEM15_P218_S1	The Company believes it has meritorious defenses to these claims and intends to contest such suits vigorously.
59527_17_ITEM15_P219_S0	The Company accrues its best estimate of the probable costs, after a review of the facts with management and counsel and taking into account past experience.
59527_17_ITEM15_P219_S1	If an unfavorable outcome is determined to be reasonably possible but not probable, or if the amount of loss cannot be reasonably estimated, disclosure would be provided for material claims or litigation.
59527_17_ITEM15_P220_S0	Many of the current cases are in differing procedural stages and information on the circumstances of each claimant, which forms the basis for judgments as to the validity or ultimate disposition of such actions, varies greatly.
59527_17_ITEM15_P220_S1	Therefore, in many situations a range of possible losses cannot be made.
59527_17_ITEM15_P220_S2	Reserves are adjusted as facts and circumstances change and related management assessments of the underlying merits and the likelihood of outcomes change.
59527_17_ITEM15_P220_S3	Moreover, reserves only cover identified and/or asserted claims.
59527_17_ITEM15_P220_S4	Future claims could, therefore, give rise to increases to such reserves.
59527_17_ITEM15_P220_S5	Based on the Company's historical experience in litigating product liability claims, including a significant number of dismissals, summary judgments and defense verdicts in many cases and immaterial settlement amounts, as well as the Company's current assessment of the underlying merits of the claims and applicable insurance, the Company believes resolution of these claims and proceedings, individually or in the aggregate, will not have a material effect on the Company's consolidated financial statements.

59527_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	ARTICLE I PURPOSE The Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc. 2005 Deferred Compensation Plan (the Plan ) was established by Lincoln Electric Holdings, Inc., effective December 30, 2004, to allow designated management and highly compensated employees to defer a portion of their current salary and bonus compensation.
59527_18_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Plan has been amended from time to time, was most recently amended and restated as of January 1, 2018 on July 28, 2017, and is hereby again amended and restated as of January 1, 2018.
59527_18_ITEM1_P3_S2	Except as provided herein, this amendment and restatement shall apply to Deferral Commitments made for Deferral Periods commencing on or after January 1, 2018.
59527_18_ITEM1_P3_S3	This amendment and restatement shall also apply to Investment Re-Allocation Requests that relate to amounts in Participant s Accounts that are attributable to Deferral Commitments made for Deferral Periods prior to January 1, 2018.
59527_18_ITEM1_P3_S4	This amendment and restatement supersedes and replaces the amendment and restatement adopted on July 28, 2017.
59527_18_ITEM1_P3_S5	The Plan is intended to comply with Section 409A of the Code, and shall be construed and interpreted in accordance with such intent.
59527_18_ITEM1_P3_S6	It is intended that the Plan will aid in attracting and retaining employees of exceptional ability by providing these benefits.
59527_18_ITEM1_P3_S7	The terms and conditions of the Plan are set forth below.
